revision.comment: Corrected a misunderstanding of the location of the mosaic in the House of the Faun.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Alexander Mosaic | artist = Unknown | year = c. 100 BC | type = [[Mosaic]] | height_metric = 272 | width_metric = 513 | height_imperial = 8 | height_inch = 11 | width_imperial = 16 | width_inch = 9 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = ft | museum = [[Naples National Archaeological Museum|National Archaeological Museum]] | city = [[Naples]] | image_file = Battle of Issus mosaic - Museo Archeologico Nazionale - Naples.jpg }} The '''Alexander Mosaic''', dating from circa 100 BC, is a [[Roman mosaic|Roman]] floor [[mosaic]] originally from the [[House of the Faun]] in [[Pompeii]].<ref>European History, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000712/http://europeanhistory.boisestate.edu/westciv/alexander/06.shtml Alexander the Great, The Battle of Issus]</ref> It depicts a battle between the armies of [[Alexander the Great]] and [[Darius III of Persia]] and measures {{convert|2.72|x|5.13|m|ftin}}.<ref name="HF">[[Hugh Honour|Honour, H.]] and J. Fleming, (2009) ''A World History of Art''. 7th edn. London: Laurence King Publishing, p. 178. {{ISBN|9781856695848}}</ref> The original is preserved in the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum]]. The mosaic is believed to be a copy of an early 3rd-century BC Hellenistic painting.<ref name="Wood">Woodford, Susan. (1982) ''The Art of Greece and Rome''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, p. 67. {{ISBN|0521298733}}</ref>
==Subject==
===Battle=== The mosaic illustrates a battle in which Alexander faced and attempted to capture or kill Darius. Alexander defeated him at the [[Battle of Issus]] and two years later at the [[Battle of Gaugamela]]. The work is traditionally believed to show the Battle of Issus.<ref>[http://www.historynet.com/wars-of-alexander-the-great-battle-of-issus.htm Battle of Issus], [[History.com]]</ref>
Since the mosaic emulates the appearance of a painting so accurately, it has been uniformly agreed that the mosaic is a copy of an original Hellenistic Greek painting.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Mosaics|last = L'Orange and Nordhagen|first = Hans Peter and Per Jonas|year = 1966|isbn = |location = Great Britain|pages = 8}}</ref> The mosaic is held to be a copy either of a painting by [[Aristides of Thebes]], or of a lost late 4th-century BC [[fresco]] by the painter [[Philoxenus of Eretria]].<ref>[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/alexander-mosaic.html Alexander Mosaic] by Dr. Beth Harris and Dr. Steven Zucker, ''Smarthistory'', 2013. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> The latter is mentioned by [[Pliny the Elder]] (XXXV, 110) as a commission for the [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonian]] king [[Cassander]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Gardner's Art Through the Ages: A Global History|first=Fred S.|last=Kleiner|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2008|isbn=0-495-11549-5|page=142}}</ref>
===Alexander and Darius=== [[File:Alexander the Great mosaic.jpg|thumb|300px|Detail showing Alexander]] [[Image:Reconstruction of the mosaic depiction of the Battle of Issus after a painting by Apelles found in the House of the Faun at Pompeii (published 1893).jpg|thumb|300px|1893 Reconstruction of the mosaic depiction.]] Despite being damaged, the two main figures are easy to recognize. *The portrait of Alexander is one of his most famous. Alexander's breastplate depicts [[Medusa]], the famous [[Gorgon]], and his wavy hair is typical of royal portraiture as established in Greek art of the fourth century BC. He is portrayed sweeping into battle at the left, on his famous horse, [[Bucephalus]],<ref>Winkes, Rolf: "Bukephalas”, Archaeologia Transantlantica XVIII, 2000, 101-107</ref> and focusing his gaze on the Persian leader. *Darius is shown in a chariot. He seems to be desperately commanding his frightened charioteer to flee the battle, while stretching out his hand either as a mute gesture to Alexander, or possibly after throwing a [[javelin]]. He has a worried expression on his face. The charioteer is whipping the horses as he tries to escape.
The Persian soldiers behind him have expressions of determination and consternation.
===Other features=== Darius's brother [[Oxyathres of Persia|Oxyathres]] is also portrayed, sacrificing himself to save the King.
Radical [[foreshortening]] – as in the central horse, seen from behind – and the use of shading to convey a sense of mass and volume enhance the naturalistic effect of the scene. Repeated diagonal spears, clashing metal, and the crowding of men and horses evoke the din of battle. At the same time, action is arrested by dramatic details such as the fallen horse and the Persian soldier in the foreground who watches his own death throes reflected in a shield.
==History of the mosaic==
===Production=== The mosaic is made of about one and a half million tiny colored tiles called [[tesserae]], arranged in gradual curves called ''[[opus vermiculatum]],'' (also known as "worm work," because they seem to replicate the slow motion of a crawling worm). The color scale of Roman mosaics are extremely rich in gradation. The process of gathering materials for mosaics was a complex undertaking since the color scale was based solely on the pieces of marble that could be found in nature.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Janson's History of Art|last = Davies|first = Penelope JE|publisher = Prentice Hall|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0135006887|location = New Jersey|pages = 246|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The mosaic is an unusually detailed work for a private residence and was likely commissioned by a wealthy person or family. The fact that this scene was made to be viewed in the house of a Roman civilian reveals that Alexander the Great was more than just a heroic image to the Romans. Because Roman leaders followed after Alexander's image, Roman civilians also aspired to emulate the power he represented.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Janson's History of Art|last = Davies|first = Penelope JE|publisher = Prentice Hall|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0135006887|location = New Jersey|pages = 146|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Since the mosaic was arranged on the floor where the patron could receive guests, it was the first decorative object a visitor would see upon entering that room.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Houses and Society in Pompeii and Herculaneum|last = Wallace-Hadrill|first = Andrew|publisher = |year = 1994|isbn = |location = |pages = 3}}</ref>
===Modern history=== The mosaic was rediscovered on October 24, 1831 in [[Pompeii]], and was moved to [[Naples]] in September 1843, where it is currently preserved on a wall (''not'' on a floor as it was found) in the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum|Museo Archeologico Nazionale]]. The mosaic is featured on 1,000 [[Greek drachma]] banknotes from 1956.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://history-of-macedonia.com/2012/03/04/16-04-1956-alexander-the-great-in-modern-greek-bank-note-of-one-thousand-drachmas/|title=16.04.1956: Alexander the Great in Modern Greek Bank Note of one thousand Drachmas=|publisher=History of Macedonia| accessdate =16 Aug 2015}}</ref>
===Modern copy=== [[File:Battle of Issus.jpg|thumb|300px|Modern reconstruction of the Alexander Mosaic.]] In 2003 the ''International Center for the Study and Teaching of Mosaic'' (CISIM) in [[Ravenna]], Italy, proposed to create a copy of the mosaic.<ref>[http://archive.archaeology.org/0601/abstracts/mosaic.html Alexander, Piece by Piece.] by Marco Merola, ''Archaeology'', Abstracts Vol. 59, No. 1, Jan/Feb 2006. Retrieved 26 May 2013. [https://www.webcitation.org/6GtFeiXeK Archived here.]</ref> When they had received approval, the mosaic master Severo Bignami and his eight-person team took a large photograph of the mosaic, made a tracing of the image with a dark marker and created a negative impression of the mosaic.
The team composed the mosaic in sections in 44 clay frames, trying to preserve the pieces of the mosaic in the exact positions they are in the original mosaic. They had to keep the plates wet all the time. Then they pressed a tissue on the clay to create an image of the outlines of the mosaic in the clay. The team recreated the mosaic with about 2 million pieces of various marble types. When they had placed all the pieces, they covered the result with a layer of glue and gauze and pulled it out of the clay. They placed each section on synthetic concrete and then united the sections with the compound of glasswool and plastic.
The project took 22 months and a cost equivalent to US $216,000. The copy was installed in the [[House of the Faun]] in 2005.
==Gallery== <Gallery> File:Alexander close up.JPG|Close up of Alexander. File:Darius close up.JPG|Close up of Darius. File:The Alexander Mosaic depicting the Battle of Issus between Alexander the Great & Darius III of Persia, from the House of the Faun in Pompeii, Naples Archaeological Museum .jpg|Centre detail of the Mosaic. File:Persians detail.JPG|Detail of the Persians on the right side of the Mosaic. File:Sword mosaic detail.JPG|Detail of a fallen sword from the bottom right of the Mosaic (showing the individual [[tesserae]]). </Gallery>
==References== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | video1 =[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/alexander-mosaic.html Smarthistory - Alexander Mosaic.]}} {{commons category|Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_(from_Pompeii)|Alexander Mosaic}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://alexandermosaik.de/en/ Reconstructed and completed Alexander mosaic.]
{{Archaeological site of Pompeii}}
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Anne Feeney''' (born July 1, 1951) is a [[activism|political activist]], [[folk music|folk]] [[musician]] and [[singer-songwriter]].
==Life and career== Feeney was born in [[Charleroi, Pennsylvania]] to Annabelle (née Runner) and Edward J. Feeney. She has a younger sister, Kathleen. The family moved to the nearby [[Brookline (Pittsburgh)|Brookline neighborhood]] of the city of [[Pittsburgh]] in 1954.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insisterhood.info/historical-library/activist-histories/|title=In Sisterhood Project - Activist Histories|website=www.insisterhood.info|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/18042216/anne_feeney/ The Pittsburgh Press], 08 Jul 1990, Sun, Page 122</ref> She graduated from [[Resurrection Elementary School (Pittsburgh)|Resurrection Elementary School]] in 1964.
Feeney graduated from [[Fontbonne Academy]],<ref name=PostGazette19900708>{{cite news|title=A rebel named Feeney: singer-activist-lawyer belts out her music and causes|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADE6E0897F97C7&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=July 8, 1990|accessdate=March 16, 2010|subscription=yes}}</ref> a Catholic girls' high school, in 1968.
After saving for one year, she purchased a [[C. F. Martin & Company|Martin]] [[C. F. Martin & Company#Six-string guitars|D-28]] guitar that she retired from service after 40 years. [[The Vietnam War]] and [[Civil Rights Movement]] were influential events that shaped her politics and songwriting. Feeney was also influenced by her grandfather, William Patrick Feeney,<ref name=PostGazette19900708/> who was a [[miner|mineworker]]s' [[union organizer|organizer]] and [[violin]]ist who also used his music in the service of political and labor causes.
In 1972 she was arrested in [[Miami]] at the [[Republican National Convention]] where she was protesting [[Richard Nixon]]'s re-nomination for President of the United States. The charges were subsequently dismissed. That same year Feeney attended the 2nd Annual Conference on Women and the Law. Inspired by the group that founded "Women Organized Against Rape" in [[Philadelphia]], Feeney began a campaign for a rape crisis center in Pittsburgh. The work begun by her committee evolved into Pittsburgh Action Against Rape,<ref>{{cite news |title=Women In Drive To End Secrecy and Stigma on Rape|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9N8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AG0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7431,3172362&dq=rape+anne-feeney&hl=en|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=September 24, 1973|accessdate=March 16, 2010 }}</ref> which still provides services to rape victims in the Pittsburgh area. She graduated from the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 1974 with a Liberal Studies degree.
In 1976 she joined a bluegrass band - Cucumber Rapids.<ref>{{cite news|title=Folk singer carries the torch for new generation|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BL&p_theme=bl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F21D5ADBB1E1A02&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=[[The Pantagraph]]|date=October 11, 1991|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref> Feeney played rhythm guitar and acoustic double bass. The other members of the band were John Wiley Nelson (guitar), Paul Boas (harmonica), Gary Mohler (guitar and dobro) and Bill Vandivier (banjo, bass and trumpet). Later on, Larry Zierath (mandolin) replaced Gary Mohler, and violinist John Mattes joined the band shortly thereafter. The group disbanded in 1977.
On November 19, 1977, she married labor attorney Ron Berlin.<ref name=PittsburghPress19890317>{{cite news |title=Activist musician sings out loudly for women's rights |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n7AqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bWMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6565,634199&dq=ron-berlin+anne-feeney&hl=en |work=[[The Pittsburgh Press]]|date=March 17, 1989|accessdate=March 16, 2010 }}</ref> She graduated from the [[University of Pittsburgh School of Law]]<ref name=PittsburghPress19890317/> in 1978. Feeney is the mother of two children, Dan (1979) and Amy (1981) Berlin. She worked for 12 years as a trial attorney and served as president of the Pittsburgh [[American Federation of Musicians|Musicians' Union]] (the only woman ever elected to this position) from 1997-1998.<ref name=PostGazette19981202>{{cite news|title=Music union elects new president|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB48EB8D33AE32C&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=December 2, 1998|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref>
Feeney's marriage to Ron Berlin ended in divorce in 1995 but she has remained involved in community activism and regional performances at political and labor rallies. She is a member of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]]<ref name=NPR20060904>{{cite news|title=Industrial Workers' Songbook Gets Big Update|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=5764742|work=[[National Public Radio]]|date=September 4, 2006|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref> as well as the American Federation of Musicians.<ref name=PostGazette19981202/>
Since 1991, Feeney has toured [[North America]] and the world to perform and participate in political and labor rallies and events.<ref name=Ledgin>{{cite book|title=Discovering Folk Music|last=Ledgin|first=Stephanie P.|page=69|year=2009|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-275-99387-0}}</ref> Her first recording, ''Look to the Left'', was released in 1992.<ref name=SingOut38>{{cite journal|title=none|year=1993|journal=[[Sing Out!]]|volume=38|page=104|oclc=60637751}}</ref> Since then she has released several more albums, including "Union Maid," "If I Can't Dance," "Have you Been to Jail for Justice?", ''Dump the Bosses Off Your Back''.<ref name=NPR20060904/> and, most recently "Enchanted Way" (2010). Feeney and her daughter Amy Berlin performed Feeney's song "Ain't I a Woman" at the "March for Women's Lives" in [[Washington, DC]], on April 25, 2004.<ref>{{cite news|title=Have You Been to Jail for Justice?|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-19000563_ITM|work=[[Sing Out!]]|date=March 22, 2005|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref>
Feeney's music has been recorded by [[Peter, Paul and Mary]]<ref name=Ledgin/> and played in concert as well. Political cartoonist [[Mike Konopacki]] included her recording of "[[Union Maid]]" in a flash animation in 2003. Feeney's music is frequently featured on the broadcast radio program ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' and her anthem "Have You Been to Jail for Justice?" is featured in the documentaries ''This is What Democracy Looks Like'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Arts in Brief |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BL&p_theme=bl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F6EB1246DE2AD93&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work=[[The Pantagraph]] |date=October 25, 2002 |accessdate=March 16, 2010 }}</ref> ''Isn't This a Time: A Tribute to Harold Leventhal''<ref>{{cite news|title=Folksinger Anne Feeney signed the Manifesto against conscription and the military system|url=http://bellaciao.org/en/article.php3?id_article=10640|work=Bellaciao|date=February 27, 2006|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref> and ''Get Up/Stand Up: The History of Pop and Protest''.
In 2002, she married Swedish political artist Julie Leonardsson.<ref>{{cite news|title=UNF Presents Unique Musical and Visual Experience |url=http://www.unf.edu/ia/pr/media_relations/press/2007/UNF_Presents_Unique_Musical_and_Visual_Experience.aspx |publisher=[[University of North Florida]] |date=March 2, 2007 |accessdate=March 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614035728/http://www.unf.edu/ia/pr/media_relations/press/2007/UNF_Presents_Unique_Musical_and_Visual_Experience.aspx |archivedate=June 14, 2011 }}</ref>
In August 2010, while touring in [[Sweden]], Feeney was diagnosed with small cell [[lung cancer]]. She is currently undergoing treatment for that, as well as a MAC infection in her lungs. Her friends around [[North America]] have been holding benefit events to provide her living expenses since she will be unable to work for some time. In 2013, the cancer was determined to be in complete remission. {{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
==Discography== ===Compilations=== *As part of Wild Wimmin for [[Peace]]: The Great Peace March, 1986<ref name=PostGazette19900708/> *Vote in November - [[2004 US Presidential Election|Election]] 2004 by: Anti-Theft Device, 2004 *Hail to the Thief: Songs for the [[George W. Bush|Bush]] Years *Hail to the Thieves, Volume III *Farewell to the Thief *Hold Me Up to the Light: (with Chris Chandler) *Stoking the Fires of Resistance
===Solo albums=== *Look to the Left, 1992<ref name=SingOut38/> *Heartland (Live), 1994<ref>{{cite book|title=Contemporary human behavior theory: a critical perspective for social work|last=Robbins|first=Susan P.|author2=Pranab Chatterjee|author3=Edward R. Canda|page=483|year=2006|publisher=[[Allyn & Bacon]]|isbn=978-0-205-40816-0}}</ref> *Have You Been to Jail for Justice?, 2001<ref name=Ledgin/> *Union Maid, 2003 *Original Recordings, 2004 *If I Can't Dance, 2006<ref>{{cite news|title=Anne Feeney: If I Can't Dance (It's Not My Revolution) (Self-released)|url=http://archive.fwweekly.com/content.asp?article=4521|work=[[Fort Worth Weekly]]|date=January 3, 2007|accessdate=March 16, 2010}}</ref> *Dump the Bosses Off Your Back, 2008<ref name=NPR20060904/> *Enchanted Way, 2010
===With Chris Chandler=== *Flying Poetry Circus, 2001<ref>{{cite news |title=Folk/Blues; Wayfaring Strangers take long, strange trip |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/92872822.html?dids=92872822:92872822&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+30%2C+2001&author=DANIEL+GEWERTZ&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=Folk%2FBlues%3B+Wayfaring+Strangers+take+long%2C+strange+trip&pqatl=google |work=[[Boston Herald]] |date=November 30, 2001 |accessdate=March 16, 2010 |format=fee required | first=Daniel | last=Gewertz}}</ref> *Live from the Wholly Stolen Empire, 2003<ref>{{cite news |title=Chris Chandler and Anne Feeney Live from the Wholly Stolen Empire |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-3169328/Chris-Chandler-and-Anne-Feeney.html |work=[[Sing Out!]] |date=September 22, 2003 |accessdate=March 16, 2010 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.annefeeney.com/ Official website] * [https://www.myspace.com/annefeeneyreally Anne on Myspace] * [http://fellow-travelers-advisory.blogspot.com/ Anne Feeney's blog]
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Bibliography */ Added a book by Marcus/Myers
revision.text:
{{Anthropology of art}} {{Anthropology}} '''Anthropology of art''' is a sub-field in [[social anthropology]] dedicated to the study of [[art]] in different cultural contexts. The anthropology of art focuses on historical, economic and aesthetic dimensions in non-Western art forms, including what is known as '[[tribal art]]'.
==History== [[Franz Boas]], one of the pioneers of modern [[anthropology]], conducted many field studies of the arts, helping create a foundation to the field. His book, ''Primitive Art'' (1927), summarizes his main insights into so-called 'primitive' art forms, with a detailed case study on the arts of the Northwest Pacific Coast.<ref>Franz Boas. (1927) ''Primitive art''.</ref> The famous anthropologist [[Claude Lévi-Strauss]] took Boas' analyses further in his book ''The Way of the Masks'', where he traced changes in the plastic form of Northwest Pacific masks to patterns of intercultural interaction among the indigenous peoples of the coast.<ref>Claude Lévi-Strauss. (1982) ''The Way of the Masks''.</ref>
==The Problem of Art== One of the central problems in the anthropology of art concerns the universality of 'art' as a cultural phenomenon. Several anthropologists have noted that the Western categories of 'painting', 'sculpture', or 'literature', conceived as independent artistic activities, do not exist, or exist in a significantly different form, in most non-Western contexts.<ref>Robert Layton. (1981) ''The Anthropology of Art''.</ref> Thus, there is no consensus on a single, cross-cultural definition of 'art' in anthropology.<ref>Howard Morphy & Morgan Perkins. (2006) Introduction, in ''The Anthropology of Art: A Reader''.</ref><ref>G. Angioni, ''Fare dire sentire: l'identico e il diverso nelle culture'', Nuoro, il Maestrale, 2011</ref> To surmount this difficulty, anthropologists of art have focused on formal features in objects which, without exclusively being 'artistic', have certain evident 'aesthetic' qualities. Boas' ''Primitive Art'', Claude Lévi-Strauss' ''The Way of the Masks'' (1982) or Geertz's 'Art as Cultural System' (1983) are some examples in this trend to transform the anthropology of 'art' into an anthropology of culturally-specific 'aesthetics'. More recently, in his book ''Art and Agency'', [[Alfred Gell]] proposed a new definition of 'art' as a complex system of intentionality, where artists produce art objects to effect changes in the world, including (but not restricted to) changes in the aesthetic perceptions of art audiences.<ref>Alfred Gell. (1998) ''Art and Agency''.</ref> Gell's ideas have stirred a large controversy in the anthropology of art in the 2000s.<ref>Ross Bowden. (2004) A Critique of Alfred Gell on Art and Agency. ''Oceania'', 74: 309-325</ref><ref>Robert H. Layton. (2003) Art and Agency: A reassessment. ''Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute'', 9: 447-464</ref><ref>Howard Morphy. (2009). Art as a Mode of Action: Some Problems with Gell’s Art and Agency. ''Journal of Material Culture'', 14 (1): 5-27</ref>
==Bibliography== *Boas, Franz. (1927) ''Primitive Art''. New York: Dover *Coote, Jeremy and Anthony Shelton, eds. (1992) ''Anthropology Art and Aesthetics''. Oxford: Clarendon Press {{ISBN|0-19-827945-0}} *Forge, Anthony, ed. (1973) ''Primitive Art & Society''. Oxford: Oxford University Press *Forge, Anthony. (1979) The Problem of Meaning in Art, in ''Exploring the Visual Art of Oceania''. Sidney M. Mead, ed. Honolulu: Hawaii University Press, pp. 278–286 *Geertz, Clifford. (1983). Art as a Cultural System, in ''Local Knowledge: Further Essays in Interpretive Anthropology''. New York: Basic Books *Gell, Alfred. (1998) ''Art and Agency: An Anthropological Theory of Art''. Oxford: Oxford University Press {{ISBN|0-19-828014-9}} *Hatcher, Evelyn Payne. (1985) ''Art As Culture: An Introduction to the Anthropology of Art''. Lanham: University Press of America {{ISBN|0-89789-628-9}} *Layton, Robert. (1981) ''The Anthropology of Art''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press {{ISBN|978-0-521-36894-0}} *Lévi-Strauss, Claude. (1982) ''The Way of the Masks'', translated by Sylvia Modelski. Seattle: University of Washington Press *Marcus, George and Myers, Fred "The traffic in Culture: Refiguring Art and Anthropology". University of California ,California 2008 *Morphy, Howard and Morgan Perkins, eds. (2006) ''The Anthropology of Art: A Reader''. Malden, MA: Blackwell Publishing *Munn, Nancy. (1973) ''Walpiri Iconography''. Ithaca: [[Cornell University Press]] *Price, Sally. (1989) ''Primitive Art in Civilized Places''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press
==See also==
*[[Sociology of art]] *[[Tribal art]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20060220101738/http://ssl.brookes.ac.uk/anthro-art/index.html
{{Social sciences}}

{{Multiple issues| {{one source|date=May 2017}} {{primary sources|date=May 2017}}}} {{Infobox award | name = Arab Cartoon Award
جائزة الكاريكاتير العربي | image = | alt = | description = | presenter = | country = [[Qatar]] | date = {{Start date|2012}}–present | reward = | sponsor = The Ministry of Culture, Arts and Heritage of Qatar | holder_label = | holder = | website = http://www.arabcartoonaward.com }} The '''Arab Cartoon Award''' is a [[Qatari]] Award conferred to those who made artistic excellence in drawing [[Cartoon]] ([[Caricature]]) in the [[Arab World]]. Established in 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.dc4mf.org/ar/node/2725|title=Media Expo Qatar 2012 brings media companies together|publisher=Doha Centre for Media Freedom|date=5 November 2012|accessdate=19 January 2018}} it is sponsored by Ministry of Culture Arts and Heritage of Qatar, Ooredoo communications company, and Dar Al-Sharq for Media publication.[http://www.arabcartoonaward.com/%d8%b9%d9%86-%d8%a7%d9%84%d8%ac%d8%a7%d8%a6%d8%b2%d8%a9/ about us]{{ar icon}} ==Winners== {{Empty section|date=May 2017}} ==External links== * [http://www.arabcartoonaward.com Official website ] {{ar icon}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Arts awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Qatar]] [[Category:Media awards]] [[Category:Art awards]] [[Category:Editorial cartooning]] {{cartoon-stub}}

[[File:Association of Writers of Serbia logo.png|right|thumb|220px|Association crest]] The '''Association of Writers of Serbia (UKS)''' ([[Serbian language|Serbian]]: Удружење књижевника Србије, ''Udruženje književnika Srbije'') is [[Serbia]]'s official writing association, and its current president is [[Radomir Andrić]].
==History== The association was founded on May 26, 1905 under the presidency of [[Milan Đ. Milićević]].<ref>Milovan Bogavac, Association of Serbian Writers 1905-1945, UKS history</ref>
The first management consisted of: *[[Simo Matavulj]], acting as president *[[Jovan Skerlić]], secretary * Dobrosav Ružić, treasurer * Živojin O. Dačić, librarian * Rista J. Odavić, host
=== Post-WWII === As a result of the [[Slovene Writers' Association]]'s support of the [[1989 Kosovo miners' strike]] the UKS broke off its relations with the Slovene Writers' Association.<ref name="Ramet2006">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|title=The three Yugoslavias: state-building and legitimation, 1918-2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FTw3lEqi2-oC&pg=PA364|accessdate=9 March 2012|year=2006|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=9780253346568|page=364}}</ref>
==Mission== The UKS states its main goals as: * gathering Serbian authors in the same community * to protect the professional interests of its members * to work on their interpersonal relationships * to work on relations with publishers and the general public * to make their job(s) easier * to help its members or their families who are in poverty.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.uksrbije.org.rs/en/ Official website] (in English)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Association of Writers of Serbia}} [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1905]] [[Category:Serbian writers' organizations]]

revision.text:
'''Begrepp – En Samling''' (Concepts – a Collection) was an art project realized at the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Arts|Royal Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Stockholm]] in 1992. It comprised an [[exhibition]], a [[publication]] and a [[lecture]] series that all focused on the heart and brain in various fields: [[art]], [[science]], [[religion]], the [[occult]] and [[cooking]], in order to reflect on the philosophical and practical relationship between art and science.<ref>Begrepp en Samling, 1992, ed. P. Huttner and E. Arnér with texts by Erna Möller, Rolf Luft, Lenke Rothman, Lennart Wetterberg and Lars Olson, Published by Royal Institute of Art in Stockholm.[http://libris.kb.se/bib/1845797]</ref> The project was initiated by artist [[Per Huttner]], at that time a student at the [[Royal Institute of Art in Stockholm]] and M.D. Ph.D. student [[Elias Arnér]].
In the exhibition, one could see two large metal and glass sculptures of the heart and the brain that contained the crumbled posters promoting the exhibition. Large photographs of histological samples of the two organs sat next to scientific abstracts, occult and religious images. Close to the entry of the exhibition, hearts and brains of various animals including and elephant and a lemur which had been lent by the Museum of Natural History sat next to recipes of how to cook the organs.<ref>Tjugo år : Maria Bonnier Dahlins stiftelse : 1985-2005, Ed. Anders Olofsson, translation: Gabriella Berggren, Stockholm : Maria Bonnier-Dahlins Stiftelse, 2006, {{ISBN|91-631-8973-9}}</ref> The lectures were held by Professor Lennart Wetterberg on the subject of how [[Swedenborg]] looked at the brain,<ref>http://swedenborg-philosophy.org/journal/article.php?page=1037&issue=106a</ref> Professor Erna Möller and the artist Lenke Rothman dialogued about [[creativity]] in their respective fields; Professor Rolf Luft examined social and cultural implications among [[Nobel Laureates]] in the sciences<ref>[http://theinclusion.davidrobertsartfoundation.com/ Per Hüttner interviewed on The Inclusion, [[The David Roberts Art Foundation]] in 2013.]</ref> and Lars Olson talked about how a medial scientist sees the brain. Each lecturer also contributed with a text in the publication.<ref>Begrepp en Samling, 1992, ed. P. Huttner and E. Arnér with texts by Erna Möller, Rolf Luft, Lenke Rothman, Lennart Wetterberg and Lars Olson, Published by Royal Institute of Art in Stockholm. [http://libris.kb.se/bib/1845797]</ref> In 2007, after Hüttner had developed some of the experiences from Begrepp – En Samling in projects like [[I am a Curator]]”,<ref name="Introdictionary">{{cite book |last = Hüttner |first = Per |authorlink = Per Hüttner |chapter=Introdictionary |title =[[I am a Curator]] |publisher = Föreningen Curatorial Mutiny |chapter-url=http://www.perhuttner.com/text/by/IAAC.book.intro.doc |chapter-format=[[DOC (computing)|DOC]] |year = 2005 |location=Stockholm |isbn = 91-631-5132-4 }}</ref> ''[[Democracy and Desire]]''<ref>[[Democracy and Desire]], 2007, 158 pages (A3) including 10 colour fold-out pages. Languages: English, Swedish, Spanish and Rumanian. Design by Åbäke. Published by Vacio 9 and The Rumanian Cultural Institute. {{ISBN|978-91-633-0548-1}}</ref> and formed the international research network [[Vision Forum (art organisation)|Vision Forum]],<ref>[[The Invisible Generation]], ed. Gerrie van Noord, design Marie Proyard, Published by Vision Forum, Stockholm, Sweden. {{ISBN|978-91-978934-2-8}}</ref> Huttner and Arnér decided to set up a continuation of their project, entitled [[(In)Visible Dialogues]], which was shown publicly in the same venue in 2011, almost 20 years after the first exhibition.<ref>[[(In)Visible Dialogues]], Ed. E. Arnér and P. Huttner, 240 pages, design by Åbäke. Published by [[Dent-de-Leone]]. {{ISBN|978-91-978934-3-5}} and {{ISBN|978-0-9561885-5-7}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.perhuttner.com/invisible.dialogues/1992_publ.php site to download of a facsimile of the publication.] *[http://swedenborg-philosophy.org/journal/article.php?page=1037&issue=106a Professor Lennart Wetterberg's contribution to lecture and publication (English version).] *[http://www.kkh.se/ Royal Institute of Art web site] *[http://www.konstakademien.se/ Royal Academy of Fine Arts web site (In Swedish only)] *[http://ki.se/ki/jsp/polopoly.jsp?l=en&d=130 Karolinska Institutet web site] *[http://www.perhuttner.com/ Per Huttner web site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120319005017/http://ki.se/ki/jsp/polopoly.jsp?l=en&d=30753 Elias Arnér profile at Karolinska Institutet.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Begrepp - En samling}} [[Category:Installation art works]] [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:Swedish art]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Blackfellas | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[James Ricketson]] | producer = Paul D. Barron
[[Penny Chapman]]
David Rapsey | screenplay = James Ricketson
[[Archie Weller]] | based on = '''Novel:'''
Archie Weller | starring = John Moore
[[David Ngoombujarra]]
[[Jack Charles (actor)|Jack Charles]]
[[John Hargreaves (actor)|John Hargreaves]]
[[Ernie Dingo]] | music = David Milroy | cinematography = Jeffrey Malouf | editing = Christopher Cordeaux | distributor = Ronin Films | released = [[File:Flag of Australia.svg|25px]] 1993 | runtime = 95 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Blackfellas''''' is a 1993 [[Cinema of Australia|Australian]] [[drama film]] directed by [[James Ricketson]]. It is an adaptation of [[Archie Weller]]'s 1981 novel ''The Day of the Dog''. ''Blackfellas'' stars John Moore, [[David Ngoombujarra]], [[Jack Charles (actor)|Jack Charles]], [[John Hargreaves (actor)|John Hargreaves]] and [[Ernie Dingo]]. The film won two [[Australian Film Institute Awards|AFI Awards]] and had its premier at the [[Valhalla Cinema, Melbourne|Valhalla Cinema]] in [[Melbourne]] on 26 August 1993.Kim, Ignatius (18 August 1993). [http://www.greenleft.org.au/node/5773 "A universal story"], ''[[Green Left Weekly]]''. Retrieved 5 September 2012. ==Plot== In [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]], Doug Dooligan (John Moore), a young [[Nyoongar]] man, is released from prison where he was incarcerated for assault. Outside he is picked up by his charismatic childhood friend Floyd "Pretty Boy" Davies ([[David Ngoombujarra]])—who was partially responsible for Doug's incarceration—and taken to a remote [[:Category:Aboriginal communities in Western Australia|Aboriginal community]]. He becomes attracted to local girl Polly (Jaylene Riley) and, upon learning that Floyd is still involved in criminal activities, decides to leave and visit his mother. Determined to stay out of trouble, Doug buys back his father's old property, Yetticup, which has [[Aboriginal land rights in Australia|traditional roots]]. Polly joins him at Yetticup and not soon after Doug's father reappears having escaped from prison. Doug narrowly escapes the police when his father is apprehended, who later dies in prison. Distraught, Doug meets Floyd and the two become friends again. When Doug tries to stop Floyd from committing a crime, Floyd sacrifices his own life so that Doug can escape and avoid arrest. ==Cast== * John Moore as Doug Dooligan * [[David Ngoombujarra]] as Floyd "Pretty Boy" Davies * Jaylene Riley as Polly * Lisa Kinchela as Valerie * [[John Hargreaves (actor)|John Hargreaves]] as Detective Maxwell * [[Ernie Dingo]] as Percy * Julie Hudspeth as Mrs. Dooligan * [[Jack Charles (actor)|Jack Charles]] as Carey * Michael Watson as Hughie * [[Kelton Pell]] as Willice ==Production== James Ricketson became interested in the story in the early 1980s when he was directing an episode of ''Women of the Sun''.[http://www.signis.net/malone/tiki-index.php?page=James+Ricketson&bl "Interview with James Ricketson", ''Signet'', 22 May 1995] accessed 20 November 2012 ==Reception== According to Ozmovies:
Proving once again that reviews can’t be banked, the film opened to generally positive reviews amongst mainstream newspaper reviewers but this didn't help at the box office.[http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/blackfellas 'Blackfellas'] at [http://www.ozmovies.com.au Ozmovies], accessed 26th October 2017.
==Awards== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Subject ! Result |- |rowspan=4|[[AACTA Awards]]
(1993 AFI Awards) |[[AACTA Award for Best Direction|Best Direction]] |rowspan=2|[[James Ricketson]] |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]] |{{won}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor]] |John Moore |{{nom}} |- |[[AACTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role|Best Supporting Actor]] |[[David Ngoombujarra]] |{{won}} |- |} ==See also== *[[Cinema of Australia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{imdb title|0106675|Blackfellas}} * [http://www.ozmovies.com.au/movie/blackfellas Blackfellas] at [http://www.ozmovies.com.au Ozmovies] {{Films and television series about Indigenous Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blackfellas (Film)}} [[Category:1993 films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:Australian drama films]] [[Category:Films based on Australian novels]] [[Category:Films set in Western Australia]] [[Category:Films about Aboriginal Australians]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]]

revision.text:
[[File:Parmigianino 004.jpg|thumb|''[[Madonna with the Long Neck]]'', by [[Parmigianino]]. As in other [[Mannerist]] works, the proportions of the body - here the [[neck]] - are exaggerated for artistic effect.]] While there is significant variation in anatomical proportions between people, there are many references to '''body proportions''' that are intended to be canonical, either in [[art]], [[measurement]], or [[medicine]]. In [[measurement]], body proportions are often used to relate two or more measurements based on the body. A [[cubit]], for instance, is supposed to be six [[palm (unit)|palms]]. A [[span (unit)|span]] is taken to be 9 inches and was previously considered as half a cubit. While convenient, these ratios may not reflect the physiognomic variation of the individuals using them. Similarly, in [[art]], body proportions are the study of relation of [[human body|human]] or animal body parts to each other and to the whole. These ratios are used in depictions of the figure (to varying degrees naturalistic, idealized or stylized), and may become part of an [[aesthetic canon]] within a culture. ==Basics of human proportions== [[Image:Braus 1921 1.png|thumb|upright=0.6|Human proportions marked out in an illustration from a 20th-century anatomy text-book. Hermann Braus, 1921]] [[Image:Braus 1921 3.png|300px|thumb|upright|A) [[black lemur]]
B) chimpanzee
C) gorilla
D) human]] It is important in [[figure drawing]] to draw the human figure in proportion. Though there are subtle differences between individuals, human proportions fit within a fairly standard range, though artists have historically tried to create idealised standards, which have varied considerably over different periods and regions. In modern figure drawing, the basic unit of measurement is the 'head', which is the distance from the top of the head to the chin. This unit of measurement is reasonably standard, and has long been used by artists to establish the proportions of the human figure. [[Ancient Egyptian art]] used a canon of proportion based on the "fist", measured across the knuckles, with 18 fists from the ground to the hairline on the forehead. This was already established by the [[Narmer Palette]] from about the 31st century BC, and remained in use until at least the conquest by [[Alexander the Great]] some 3,000 years later.Smith, W. Stevenson, and Simpson, William Kelly. ''The Art and Architecture of Ancient Egypt'', pp. 12-13 and note 17, 3rd edn. 1998, Yale University Press (Penguin/Yale History of Art), {{ISBN|0300077475}} The proportions used in figure drawing are:{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} * An average person is generally 7-and-a-half heads tall (including the head). * An ideal figure, used when aiming for an impression of nobility or grace, is drawn at 8 heads tall. * A [[heroic]] figure, used in the heroic for the depiction of [[gods]] and [[superheroes]], is eight-and-a-half heads tall. Most of the additional length comes from a bigger chest and longer legs. ==Western ideal== [[File:Jessica Alba Face Proportions.png|thumb|left|A [[University of Toronto]] study found that ideal facial proportions of [[Jessica Alba]] {{cite journal |year=2010 |last1=Pallett |first1=PM |last2=Link |first2=S |last3=Lee |first3=K |title=New "Golden" Ratios for Facial Beauty |journal=Vision Research |volume=50 |issue=2 |pages=149–54 |doi=10.1016/j.visres.2009.11.003 |pmid=19896961 |pmc=2814183}}{{cite journal |pmid=23441307 |year=2013 |author1=Prokopakis |first1=E. P |title=The golden ratio in facial symmetry |journal=Rhinology |volume=51 |issue=1 |pages=18–21 |last2=Vlastos |first2=I. M |last3=Picavet |first3=V. A |last4=Nolst Trenite |first4=G |last5=Thomas |first5=R |last6=Cingi |first6=C |last7=Hellings |first7=P. W |doi=10.4193/Rhino12.111 |doi-broken-date=2018-03-06 }} were close to the average of all female profiles.{{cite news |author= Fiona Macrae |title=Skin deep: Beautiful faces have Miss Average proportions |publisher= ''Daily Mail'' |quote=All were head shots of the same person with different distances from eyes to mouth or between the eyes. She was at her most attractive when the space between her pupils was just under half, or 46 per cent, of the width of her face from ear to ear. The other perfect dimension was when the distance between her eyes and mouth was just over a third, or 36 per cent, of the overall length of her face from hairline to chin. ... |date= 27 December 2009 |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1236636/Skin-deep-Beautiful-faces-Miss-Average-proportions.html |accessdate= 2011-07-31}}]] ===Leg-to-body ratio=== A study using Polish participants by Sorokowski found 5% longer legs than an individual used as a reference was considered most attractive.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2007.09.002 |title=Adaptive preferences for leg length in a potential partner |journal=Evolution and Human Behavior |volume=29 |issue=2 |pages=86–91 |year=2008 |last1=Sorokowski |first1=Piotr |last2=Pawlowski |first2=Boguslaw }} The study concluded this preference might stem from the influence of leggy runway models.{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09709274.2010.11906309 |title=Attractiveness of Legs Length in Poland and Great Britain |journal=Journal of Human Ecology |volume=31 |issue=3 |pages=145 |year=2017 |last1=Sorokowski |first1=Piotr }} The Sorokowski study was criticized for using a picture of the same person with digitally altered leg lengths which Marco Bertamini{{who|date=March 2016}} felt were unrealistic. Another study using British and American participants, found ''mid-ranging'' leg-to-body ratios to be most ideal.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bodyim.2009.09.001 |pmid=19822462 |title=The influence of leg-to-body ratio (LBR) on judgments of female physical attractiveness: Assessments of computer-generated images varying in LBR |journal=Body Image |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=51–5 |year=2010 |last1=Frederick |first1=David A |last2=Hadji-Michael |first2=Maria |last3=Furnham |first3=Adrian |last4=Swami |first4=Viren }} A study by Swami et al. of American men and women showed a preference for men with legs as long as the rest of their body and women with 40%{{clarify|date=March 2016}} longer legs than the rest of their body{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bodyim.2006.08.003 |pmid=18089235 |title=The leg-to-body ratio as a human aesthetic criterion |journal=Body Image |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=317–23 |year=2006 |last1=Swami |first1=Viren |last2=Einon |first2=Dorothy |last3=Furnham |first3=Adrian }} The researcher concluded that this preference might be influenced by American culture where long-legged women are portrayed as more attractive. The Swami et al. study was criticized for using a picture of the same person with digitally altered leg lengths which Marco Bertamini felt were unrealistic.{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/h0099320 |title=The effect of leg length on perceived attractiveness of simplified stimuli |journal=Journal of Social, Evolutionary, and Cultural Psychology |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=233–50 |year=2009 |last1=Bertamini |first1=Marco |last2=Bennett |first2=Kate M }} Bertamini also criticized the Swami study for only changing the leg length while keeping the arm length constant. Bertamini's own study which used stick figures mirrored Swami's study, however, by finding a preference for leggier women. Another common measurement of related to leg-to-body ratio is sitting-height ratio (SHR). Sitting height ratio is the ratio of the head plus spine length to total height which is highly correlated to leg-to-body ratio. SHR has been found to be very different between individuals of different ancestry. It has been reported that individuals with African ancestry have on average longer leg length, i.e. lower SHR than individuals of European ancestry.{{cite journal | last1 = Bogin | first1 = B. | last2 = Varela-Silva | first2 = MI | date = Mar 2010 | title = Leg length, body proportion, and health: a review with a note on beauty | url = | journal = Int J Environ Res Public Health | volume = 7 | issue = 3| pages = 1047–75 | doi=10.3390/ijerph7031047 | pmid=20617018 | pmc=2872302}} A study in 2015 revealed that this difference is mainly due to genetic differences and the SHR difference between African and European individuals is as large as 1 standard deviation.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ajhg.2015.02.018 |pmid=25865494 |pmc=4570286 |title=Genome-wide Analysis of Body Proportion Classifies Height-Associated Variants by Mechanism of Action and Implicates Genes Important for Skeletal Development |journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics |volume=96 |issue=5 |pages=695–708 |year=2015 |last1=Chan |first1=Yingleong |last2=Salem |first2=Rany M |last3=Hsu |first3=Yu-Han H |last4=McMahon |first4=George |last5=Pers |first5=Tune H |last6=Vedantam |first6=Sailaja |last7=Esko |first7=Tonu |last8=Guo |first8=Michael H |last9=Lim |first9=Elaine T |last10=Franke |first10=Lude |last11=Smith |first11=George Davey |last12=Strachan |first12=David P |last13=Hirschhorn |first13=Joel N }} ===Muscle men and thin women=== A 1999 study found that "the (action) figures have grown much more muscular over time, with many contemporary figures far exceeding the muscularity of even the largest human bodybuilders," reflecting an American cultural ideal of a super muscular man.{{Cite journal|last=Pope|first=Harrison|author2=Roberto Olivardia|author3=Amanda Gruber|author4=John Borowiecki|date=1998-05-26|title=Evolving Ideals of Male Body Image as Seen Through Action Toys|journal=International Journal of Eating Disorders|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc|volume=26|issue=1|doi=10.1002/(sici)1098-108x(199907)26:1<65::aid-eat8>3.3.co;2-4|pmid=10349585|pages=65–72}} Also, female dolls reflect the cultural ideal of thinness in women. [[File:Da Vinci Vitruve Luc Viatour.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Vitruvian Man]]'', by [[Leonardo da Vinci]]]] ==In art== {{further|Mathematics and art}} The ancient Greek sculptor [[Polykleitos]] (c.450–420 BC), known for his ideally proportioned bronze ''[[Doryphoros]]'', wrote an influential ''Canon'' describing the proportions to be followed in sculpture.{{cite journal |last1=Stewart |first1=Andrew |title=Polykleitos of Argos," One Hundred Greek Sculptors: Their Careers and Extant Works |journal=Journal of Hellenic Studies |date=November 1978 |volume=98 |pages=122–131 |doi=10.2307/630196|jstor=630196 }} The ''Canon'' applies the basic mathematical concepts of Greek geometry, such as the ratio, proportion, and ''symmetria'' (Greek for "harmonious proportions") creating a system capable of describing the human form through a series of continuous [[geometric series|geometric progressions]]. Polykleitos uses the [[distal phalanges|distal phalanx]] of the [[little finger]] as the basic module for determining the proportions of the human body, scaling this length up repeatedly by {{radic|2}} to obtain the ideal size of the other phalanges, the hand, forearm, and upper arm in turn.{{cite journal| author=Tobin, Richard | title=The ''Canon'' of Polykleitos | journal=American Journal of Archaeology | volume=79 | issue=4 | date=October 1975 | pages=307–321 | doi=10.2307/503064| jstor=503064 }} [[Leonardo da Vinci]] believed that the ideal human proportions were determined by the harmonious proportions that he believed governed the universe,"Universal Leonardo: Leonardo Da Vinci Online › Essays." Universal Leonardo: Leonardo Da Vinci Online › Welcome to Universal Leonardo. Web. 22 Apr. 2010. . such that the ideal man would fit cleanly into a circle as depicted in his famed drawing of ''[[Vitruvian man]]''. ==Additional images== Image:Braus 1921 2a.png|a 1½-year-old child Image:Braus 1921 2b.png|an adult man File:Human development neoteny body and head proportions pedomorphy maturation aging growth.png|Human body proportions change with age == Bibliography == * [[Gottfried Bammes]]: ''Studien zur Gestalt des Menschen.'' Verlag Otto Maier GmbH, Ravensburg 1990, {{ISBN|3-473-48341-9}}. ==See also== * The ''Kanon'' of [[Polykleitos]] * [[Body shape]] * [[Anthropometry]] * [[Female body shape]] * [[Physical attractiveness]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Body proportions}} * {{Cite journal | last1 = Deriabin | first1 = V. E. | title = Age-related changes in human body proportions studied by the method of principal components | journal = Nauchnye doklady vysshei shkoly. Biologicheskie nauki | issue = 1 | pages = 50–55 | year = 1987 | pmid = 3828410 }} * {{Cite journal | pmid = 20617018 | pmc = 2872302 | year = 2010 | author1 = Bogin | first1 = B | title = Leg length, body proportion, and health: A review with a note on beauty | journal = International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health | volume = 7 | issue = 3 | pages = 1047–75 | last2 = Varela-Silva | first2 = M. I. | doi = 10.3390/ijerph7031047 }} * {{Cite journal | pmid = 25865494 | year = 2015 | author1 = Chan | first1 = Y | title = Genome-wide Analysis of Body Proportion Classifies Height-Associated Variants by Mechanism of Action and Implicates Genes Important for Skeletal Development | journal = The American Journal of Human Genetics | last2 = Salem | first2 = R. M. | last3 = Hsu | first3 = Y. H. | last4 = McMahon | first4 = G | last5 = Pers | first5 = T. H. | last6 = Vedantam | first6 = S | last7 = Esko | first7 = T | last8 = Guo | first8 = M. H. | last9 = Lim | first9 = E. T. | last10 = Giant | first10 = Consortium | last11 = Franke | first11 = L | last12 = Smith | first12 = G. D. | last13 = Strachan | first13 = D. P. | last14 = Hirschhorn | first14 = J. N. | doi = 10.1016/j.ajhg.2015.02.018 | volume=96 | issue = 5 | pages=695–708 | pmc=4570286 }} * {{cite journal|last=Alley|first=Thomas R. |title=Growth-Produced Changes in Body Shape and Size as Determinants of Perceived Age and Adult Caregiving|journal=Child Development|volume=54|issue=1|date=Feb 1983|pages=241–248|doi=10.2307/1129882|jstor=1129882}} * {{cite journal|pmid=2385485|doi=10.3758/BF03207078|title=Body proportions as information for age and cuteness: Animals in illustrated children's books|year=1990|last1=Pittenger|first1=John B.|journal=Perception & Psychophysics|volume=48|issue=2|pages=124–30}} * [http://www.spirxpert.com/collegeUK/e.htm Changing body proportions during growth] {{Mathematical art}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Body Proportions}} [[Category:Anatomy]] [[Category:Artistic techniques]] [[Category:Human body|Prop]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of Peru |image = Escudo nacional del Perú.svg |image_width = 250 |middle = Escudo de armas del Perú.svg |middle_width = 250 |middle_caption = The Coat of arms (''{{lang|es|Escudo de armas}}'') as used in the centered on the white band of the National flag. |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |armiger = [[Republic of Peru]] |year_adopted = 25 February 1825 |crest = [[Holm oak]] [[civic crown]] |torse = |shield = Per fess, the first per pale azure and argent in dexter a vicuña counter-statant proper and in sinister a cinchona tree also proper, the second gules, a cornucopia spilling potatoes Or |supporters = Two [[Flag of Peru|National Flags of]] [[Peru]] and two standards on each side. |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = When used on the National Flag, the Coat of arms (''{{lang|es|Escudo de armas}}'') is surrounded by a wreath of [[palm branch]] one on the left and a [[Bay Laurel|laurel]] one on the right tied by a red and white ribbon. |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''Coat of arms of Peru''' is the national symbolic emblem of [[Peru]]. Four variants are used: the Coat of arms ''per se'' (''{{lang|es|Escudo de Armas}}''); the National Coat of arms, or National Shield (''{{lang|es|Escudo Nacional}}''); the Great Seal of the State (''{{lang|es|Gran Sello del Estado}}''); and the Naval Coat of arms (''{{lang|es|Escudo de la Marina de Guerra}}''). ==Description== All four share the same [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] or shield, consisting of three elements: the top left section shows the [[vicuña]], the national animal, on a light-blue [[field (heraldry)|field]], representing the [[fauna]] of Peru; the tree in the top right section is the [[cinchona]] tree (the source of [[quinine]], a powerful anti-malarial drug and the key flavorant in [[tonic water]]), on a white background, representing the national [[flora]]; and the bottom [[cornucopia]] with coins spilling from it, on a red field, represents the mineral resources of the country ==Variants== ===The Coat of arms=== The [[coat of arms]] (''{{lang|es|Escudo de Armas}}'') has a [[palm branch]] on its left and an [[Bay Laurel|laurel]] one on its right, tied by a red and white ribbon, as well as a [[Holm oak]] [[civic crown]] above it. These represent victory and glory. This variant is used on the [[Flag of Peru#National ensign (state flag)|national ensign]] (''{{lang|es|Pabellón Nacional}}'') or state flag. Its use on its own is infrequent, except on [[Peruvian nuevo sol|currency]], both on coins and bills, and stamps. ===The National Coat of arms=== The National Coat of arms, or National Shield (''{{lang|es|Escudo Nacional}}''), consists of the shield plus a [[Flag of Peru|Peruvian flag]] and a standard on each side, and a Civic Crown as [[crest (heraldry)|crest]]. It is used on the [[flag of Peru#War flag|war flag]] (''{{lang|es|Bandera de Guerra}}''). Its use on its own is mandated for all public buildings, with the name of the entity under it. ===The Great Seal of the State=== The Great Seal of the State (''{{lang|es|Gran Sello del Estado}}''), consisting of the National Shield and the semicircular inscription "{{lang|es|República del Perú}}" ("Republic of Peru") above it, is used on official documents. ===The Naval Coat of arms=== The Naval Coat of Arms (''{{lang|es|Escudo de la Marina de Guerra}}''), consists of the National Shield and the semicircular inscription "{{lang|es|Marina de Guerra del Peru}}", along with anchors instead of the traditional flags it is embedded upon, as well as having an image of the sun as the crest. It is used for various naval purposes. ==History== === First version === [[File:Escudo del Perú-1821.tif|thumb|First version.]] The first version of the Coat of Arms of Peru was designed by General [[José de San Martín]] and officially declared on 21 October 1820. It consisted of a landscape of [[Inti]] the sun rising from the [[Andes]], seen from the sea, and escorted by laurel branches tied with a golden ribbon. In the shield, on a blue sky background, the sun's yellow rays can be seen behind the dark brown mountains rising above the blue and green ocean. The flags of the South American nations and a banana tree can be seen behind the shield. A [[condor]] on the left and a [[llama]] on the right act as supporters. This was on top of a [[baroque]] base, with a scroll under it with the [[motto]] "''Renació el sol del Perú''" ("Peru's sun is reborn") in capital letters. Some flowers, branches and ammunition were on the base. ===Second version=== [[File:Escudo peruano.jpg|thumb|Coat of Arms in 1825]] [[File:Escudo de la República Peruana (1825-1950).svg|thumb|Third Coat of Arms since 1825 until 1950.]] On 25 February 1825, [[Simón Bolívar]] and the Constituent Congress proclaimed a law defining the new national symbols. establishing the new Coat of Arms, similar to the one used today. This was designed by [[Congress of Peru|Congressmen]] José Gregorio Paredes and Francisco Javier Cortés. The official description was the following: :"Las armas de la Nación Peruana constarán de un escudo dividido en tres campos (forma polaca), uno azul celeste, a la derecha, que llevará una vicuña mirando al interior; otro blanco, a la izquierda, donde se colocará el árbol de la quina; y otro rojo inferior y más pequeño en que se verá una cornucopia derramando monedas, significándose con estos símbolos, las preciosidades del Perú en los tres reinos naturales. El escudo tendrá por timbre una corona cívica vista de plano; e irá acompañada en cada lado de una bandera y un estandarte de los colores nacionales, señalado más adelante." :"The arms of the Peruvian Nation shall consist of a shield divided into three fields (Polish shape), one light-blue, to the left, which will carry a vicuña looking inwards; another white, on the right, where a cinchona tree will be located; and another red below and smaller in which a cornucopia will be seen spilling coins, signifying with these symbols, the richnesses of Peru in the three natural kingdoms. The shield shall have as crest a Civic Crown seen flat; and shall be escorted on each side by a flag and standard of the same national colors, described later." ====1950 modification==== This is the coat of arms used today and is a modification of the second version. Until 1950, the coat of arms was a symbol of both the nation and the state, and presented some difficulties in its design. These generated that, months after its creation, that the seals of ministries modified the law, cutting the width of the shield to design the cornucopia comfortably, and getting rid of the escorting flags. The last modification was in March 1950, during General [[Manuel A. Odría]]’s administration. In this way, the coat of arms was split in halves, and the lower section became the largest, rather than the smallest. The national coat of arms was created simultaneously as a heraldic symbol of the State. File:Escudo nacional del Perú.svg|National Coat of Arms
''Escudo Nacional'' File:Escudo de armas del Perú.svg|The National Coat of Arms
''Escudo de Armas'' File:Gran Sello de la República del Perú.svg|Great Seal of the State
''Gran Sello del Estado'' File:Emblem of the Peruvian Army.svg|Coat of arms
''[[Peruvian Army|Escudo de la Ejército del Perú]]'' File:Emblem of the Peruvian Navy.svg|Naval Coat of arms
''[[Peruvian Navy|Escudo de la Marina de Guerra del Perú]]'' File:Emblem of the Peruvian Air Force.svg|Coat of arms
''[[Peruvian Air Force|Escudo de la Fuerza Aérea del Perú]]'' File:Escudo de la Policía Nacional del Perú.png|Policial Coat of arms
''[[National Police of Peru|Escudo de la Policía Nacional del Perú]]'' ==See also== * [[Flag of Peru]] {{Peru symbols}} {{Coats of arms of South America}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coat Of Arms Of Peru}} [[Category:National coats of arms|Peru]] [[Category:Peruvian coats of arms|Peru]] [[Category:Coats of arms with animals|Peru]] [[Category:Coats of arms with cornucopia|Peru]] [[Category:Coats of arms with trees|Peru]] [[Category:Coats of arms with flags|Peru]] [[Category:Coats of arms with palm branches|Peru]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Santa Maria del Popolo Capella Chigi Kuppel.JPG | painting_alignment = | image_size = 200px | title = Creation of the World | other_language_1 = Dio Padre creatore del firmamento e simboli del sole e dei sette pianeti | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Raphael]] | year = 1516 | type = Mosaics | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = | imperial_unit = | city = Rome | museum = [[Chigi Chapel]] }} '''''Creation of the World''''' is a [[mosaic]] composition in the dome of the [[Chigi Chapel]] in [[Santa Maria del Popolo]], [[Rome]], designed by [[Raphael]]. The chapel itself was designed by Raphael for his friend and patron, banker [[Agostino Chigi]] as a private chapel and family burial place. The dome was decorated with mosaics, a somewhat unusual and old-fashioned technique in the 16th century. Raphael's cartoons were executed by a Venetian craftsman, Luigi da Pace in 1516. The original cartoons were lost but some preparatory drawings, that confirm the originality of the work, survived in the [[Ashmolean Museum]], [[Oxford]]. There are two studies for the figure of God and one for the angel above Jupiter. Another drawing in the [[Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille|Palais des Beaux-Arts]] in [[Lille]] shows the planet Mars with an angel. This is probably a creative drawing by a pupil suggested by its inferior quality.Paul Joannides: ''The Drawings of Raphael: With a Complete Catalogue'', University of California Press, Berkeley, 1983, p.231 Luigi da Pace signed and dated the work at the corner of the panel of Venus:Nicole Riegel: Die Chigi-Kapelle in Santa Maria del Popolo. Eine kritische Revision, Marburger Jahrbuch für Kunstwissenschaft, 30. Bd. (2003), p. 97
"LV[dovicus] D[e] P[ace] V[enetus] F[ecit] 1516"
==Description== [[File:Raphaels ashmolean angel.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Preparatory drawing by Raphael.]] The central roundel represents God, the Father, surrounded by putti, effectively foreshortened in an impetuous gesture, harking back to [[Michelangelo]], which seems to give rise to the entire motion of the universe below. Eight mosaic panels show the Sun, the Moon, the starry sky and the six known planets as pagan deities depicted in half-length, each accompanied by an angel with colourful feathered wings. The figures are accompanied by the signs of the zodiac. The sequence of the panels is as follows: the sky; [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]], the god holding the [[caduceus]] (with [[Virgo (astrology)|Virgo]] and [[Gemini (astrology)|Gemini]]); [[Luna (goddess)|Luna]], the crescent moon jewelled goddess holding a bow (with [[Cancer (astrology)|Cancer]]); [[Saturn (mythology)|Saturn]], the bearded god holding the scythe (with [[Aquarius (astrology)|Aquarius]] and [[Capricorn (astrology)|Capricorn]]); [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], the king of the gods with his eagle holding a thunderbolt (with [[Sagittarius (astrology)|Sagittarius]] and [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]]); [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]], the god of war holding a sword and a shield (with [[Scorpio (astrology)|Scorpio]] and [[Aries (astrology)|Aries]]); [[Sol (mythology)|Sol]], the sun-jewelled god holding a bow (with [[Leo (astrology)|Leo]]); [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]], the goddess of love with [[Cupid]] holding a torch as the Evening Star (with [[Taurus (astrology)|Taurus]] and [[Libra (astrology)|Libra]]). A French engraver, [[Nicolas Dorigny]] created a series of plates depicting the mosaics in 1695 for [[Louis, Duke of Burgundy]]. The mosaic panels are surrounded by richly gilded stucco decoration. The blue background creates an optical illusion giving the impression of an architectural framework opening to the sky above the chapel. The panels look like illusionistic skylights between the gilt stucco ribs while God is standing on the edge of the central oculus.John Shearman: The Chigi Chapel in S. Maria del Popolo, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes, Vol. 24, No. 3/4 (Jul. - Dec., 1961) The traditional interpretation of the dome is that the composition shows the ''Creation of the World''. Another (disputed) interpretation claims that it represents the cosmos as described by [[Plato]] in a Christianized [[Neoplatonism|Neoplatonist]] form. This idea had a widespread popularity in the Renaissance. In this case the dome is a depiction of the Realm of the Soul after Death with God, the Father receiving the soul (of Agostino Chigi) in his new home. The presence of the signs of the zodiac corroborates this interpretation because the signs were symbols of the passage of time in eternity, and they appeared in antique funeral art around the image of the departed. Nicole Riegel emphasized the role of the angels in the composition: "In view of the important, anything but accessory position of the angels in the panels, there is an unmistakable effort for a reconciliation or interfusion of the Pagan and Christian life view."Op. cit. p. 113 ==Gallery== {|style="background:darkgray; border:1px solid dimgray;color:white" border="0" height="230" align="center" valign="bottom" cellpadding=10px cellspacing=0px |+style="background:white; color:black"|'''''Raphaelis Sanctii Urbinatis Planetarium (Nicolas Dorigny)''''' |-align="center" |[[Image:Astronomy; an angel astride the cosmos, looking heavenward. Wellcome V0024870.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny God Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Mercurius Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Astronomy; Diana, as Moon goddess, an angel above looking he Wellcome V0024874.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Saturn Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Jupiter Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Mars Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Sol Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |[[Image:Dorigny Venus Planetarium.jpg|border|500x130px|none]] |-align="center" valign="top" |width="100"|'''''Title page''''' |width="100"|''' God, the Father''' |width="100"|'''''Mercury''''' |width="100"|'''''Luna''''' |width="100"|'''''Saturn''''' |width="100"|'''''Jupiter''''' |width="100"|'''''Mars''''' |width="100"|'''''Sol''''' |width="100"|'''''Venus''''' |} ==Notes== {{Raphael}} [[Category:Paintings by Raphael]] [[Category:Italian mosaic]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Paintings of Cupid]] [[Category:Paintings of Mars (mythology)]] [[Category:Paintings of Venus]] [[Category:Paintings of Jupiter (mythology)]] [[Category:Artworks in Santa Maria del Popolo]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{for|the medieval allegory|Danse Macabre}} {|align=right |{{Listen |filename=Saint-Saens, Camille - Danse macabre Opus 40 - Computer generated, transcribed by MacLeod.ogg |title=''Danse macabre'' |description=Computer generated recording (transcribed by [[Kevin MacLeod (composer)|Kevin MacLeod]]). }} |}
'''''Danse macabre''''', [[opus number|Op.]] 40, is a [[tone poem]] for orchestra, written in 1874 by the French composer [[Camille Saint-Saëns]]. It is in the key of [[G minor]]. It started out in 1872 as an [[art song]] for voice and piano with a French text by the poet [[Henri Cazalis]], which is based on an [[Danse Macabre|old French superstition]].<ref>Boyd, Malcolm. [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/07153 "Dance of death]", Grove Music Online, Oxford University Press, retrieved 6 October 2015. {{subscription}}</ref> In 1874, the composer expanded and reworked the piece into a tone poem, replacing the vocal line with a solo violin part.
==Analysis== According to legend, "[[Death (personification)|Death]]" appears at midnight every year on [[Halloween]]. Death calls forth the dead from their [[grave (burial)|graves]] to dance for him while he plays his [[violin|fiddle]] (here represented by a solo violin). His skeletons dance for him until the rooster crows at dawn, when they must return to their graves until the next year.
The piece opens with a harp playing a single note, D, twelve times (the twelve strokes of midnight) which is accompanied by soft chords from the string section. The solo violin enters playing the [[tritone]], which was known as the ''[[Tritone#Historical uses|diabolus in musica]]'' ("the Devil in music") during the Medieval and [[Baroque music|Baroque]] eras, consisting of an A and an E{{music|flat}}—in an example of [[scordatura]] tuning, the violinist's E string has actually been tuned down to an E{{music|flat}} to create the dissonant tritone.
The first theme is heard on a solo flute,<ref>[IMSLP full score, page 3]</ref> followed by the second theme, a descending scale on the solo violin which is accompanied by soft chords from the string section.<ref>[full score, page 4, 4th bar]</ref> The first and second themes, or fragments of them, are then heard throughout the various sections of the orchestra. The piece becomes more energetic and at its midpoint, right after a [[contrapuntal]] section based on the second theme,<ref>[full score, page 13, rehearsal letter C]</ref> there is a direct quote<ref>[full score, page 16, rehearsal letter D]</ref> played by the woodwinds of ''[[Dies irae]]'', a [[Gregorian chant]] from the [[Requiem]] that is melodically related to the work's second theme. The ''Dies irae'' is presented unusually in a major key. After this section the piece returns to the first and second themes and climaxes with the full orchestra playing very strong dynamics. Then there is an abrupt break in the texture<ref>[full score, page 50, 6th bar]</ref> and the [[coda (music)|coda]] represents the dawn breaking (a [[cockerel]]'s crow, played by the [[oboe]]) and the skeletons returning to their graves.
The piece makes particular use of the [[xylophone]] to imitate the sounds of rattling bones. Saint-Saëns uses a similar [[motif (music)|motif]] in the ''Fossils'' movement of ''[[The Carnival of the Animals]]''.
==Instrumentation== ''Danse macabre'' is scored for an [[obbligato]] violin and an orchestra consisting of one [[piccolo]], two [[flute]]s, two [[oboe]]s, two [[clarinet]]s in B{{music|flat}}, two [[bassoon]]s; four [[French horn|horns]] in G and D, two [[trumpet]]s in D, three [[trombone]]s, one [[tuba]]; a percussion section that includes [[timpani]], [[xylophone]], [[bass drum]], [[cymbals]] and [[Triangle (musical instrument)|triangle]]; one [[harp]] and [[string section|strings]].
==Reception== When ''Danse macabre'' was first performed it was not well received.<ref name=nichols>Nichols, Roger (2012), Notes to Chandos CD CHSA 5104, OCLC 794163802</ref> The piece caused widespread consternation: the commentator Roger Nichols mentions adverse reaction to "the deformed ''Dies irae'' plainsong", the "horrible screeching from solo violin", the use of a xylophone and "the hypnotic repetitions", in which Nichols hears a pre-echo of [[Maurice Ravel|Ravel]]'s ''[[Boléro]].<ref name=nichols/>
Today, it's considered one of Saint-Saëns masterpieces, widely regarded and reproduced in erudite and popular culture.
==Usage== Shortly after the premiere, the piece was transcribed into a piano arrangement by [[Franz Liszt]] (S.555),<ref>{{cite book |title=Franz Liszt: A Guide to Research |last=Salle |first=Michael |year=2004 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=0-415-94011-7 |page=460 }}</ref> a good friend of Saint-Saëns. The best-known piano transcription (for four hands) is by [[Ernest Guiraud]]. The composition was again later transcribed for piano by [[Vladimir Horowitz]]. There is an organ transcription by [[Edwin Lemare]].
The piece was later used in dance performances, including those of [[Anna Pavlova]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Legacies of Twentieth-century Dance |last=Garafola |first=Lynn |year=2005 |publisher=Wesleyan University Press |location=New York |isbn=978-0-8195-6674-4 |pages=155–156 }}</ref>
The piece is played offstage during the first act of Henrik Ibsen's 1896 play ''[[John Gabriel Borkman]].''
The piece is used as a recurring ironic motif in Jean Renoir's 1939 film ''[[The Rules of the Game]]'' (La Règle du Jeu),
An adaptation of the piece is used as the theme music for ''[[Jonathan Creek]]'', a mystery crime series on British television.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.com/composers/saint-saens/guides/saint-saens-facts/jonathan-creek-13/|title=A Danse Macabre|website=Classicfm.com|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
The piece is used in the animated television series ''[[Modern Toss (TV series)|Modern Toss]]'' as the theme tune for the character, Mr. Tourette - Master Signwriter.
The piece is used in the Dutch theme park ''[[Efteling]]'' in the attraction [[Haunted Castle (Efteling)|Haunted Castle]].
It can be heard in [[Alone in the Dark (1992 video game)|''Alone in the Dark'']] after setting the record on the Gramophone in the Dance Hall.
A portion of the piece can be heard in the 1993 [[western film]] ''[[Tombstone (film)|Tombstone]]'' during the performance of the stage version of ''[[Faust]]''.
A synthesized version of the piece is used in the soundtrack for the anime television series [[Dimension W]].
In Neil Gaiman's novel ''[[The Graveyard Book]]'' the characters dance the "Macabray". In the audiobook, the Danse Macabre is played between chapters.
Korean figure skater [[Yuna Kim]] used the piece as her short program music in 2008-2009 season.
The piece is used in several instances during the 2011 ''[[Grimm (TV series)|Grimm]]'' episode ''[[Danse Macabre (Grimm episode)|Danse Macabre]]'', for which it is named.
The piece can be heard during the New Year's Eve festivities in the 2014 [[Gothic horror|gothic horror film]], ''[[Stonehearst Asylum]].''
The piece is played in the ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' episode "[[Hush (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Hush]]"; rather than serving merely as soundtrack, the character [[Rupert Giles]] plays the song in-universe while describing the episode's villains, the Gentlemen.
The piece's title is used for a [[Hitman (2016 video game)|''Hitman'']] mission set in Italy, in which [[Agent 47]] is required to crush three victims with falling objects while dressed as a plague doctor.
The piece is arranged in multiple levels of [[The End Is Nigh (video game)|''The End is Nigh'']], such as "The End" and "Mortaman".
The piece is used in the opening of Season 2 Episode 8 of the [[USA Network|USA]] original, ''[[Mr. Robot]]''.
The piece was used in a [[Jameson Irish Whiskey]] commercial <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqYOv3-nqUo|title=Jameson Irish Whiskey - Giant Bird|first=|last=macturtle|date=26 November 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== ===Sheet music=== * {{IMSLP2|work=Danse_Macabre%2C_Op.40_%28Saint-Sa%C3%ABns%2C_Camille%29|cname=''Danse macabre''}}
===Audio=== * {{YouTube|YyknBTm_YyM|''Danse macabre''}}
