revision.text:
[[File:Ho-Mg-ZnQuasicrystal.jpg|thumb|A Ho–Mg–Zn quasicrystal in the shape of a [[dodecahedron]].]]
A '''holmium–magnesium–zinc (Ho–Mg–Zn) quasicrystal''' is a [[quasicrystal]] made of an alloy of those three metals that has the shape of a regular [[dodecahedron]], a [[Platonic solid]] with 12 five-sided faces. Unlike the similar [[pyritohedron]] shape of some cubic-system crystals such as [[pyrite]], this quasicrystal has faces that are true regular pentagons.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Holmium-magnesium-zinc quasicrystal}} [[Category:Crystallography]] [[Category:Condensed matter physics]] [[Category:Tessellation]] [[Category:Intermetallics]]

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|url trimming]] of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{good article}} [[File:Falconry Book of Frederick II 1240s detail falconers.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Detail of two [[falconry|falconers]] from the Medieval ''[[De arte venandi cum avibus]]'', c. 1240]] '''Human uses of birds''' have included both economic uses such as food and symbolic uses such as art, music and religion, for thousands of years.
In terms of economic uses, birds have been hunted for food since [[Palaeolithic]] times. They have been captured and bred as [[poultry]] to provide meat and eggs since at least the time of ancient Egypt. Some species have been used, too, to help locate or to catch food, as with [[cormorant fishing]] and the use of [[greater honeyguide|honeyguides]]. Feathers have long been used for bedding, as well as for [[quill pen]]s and for [[Fletching|fletching arrows]]. Today, many species face [[habitat loss]] and other threats caused by humans; [[bird conservation]] groups work to protect birds and to influence governments to do so.
Birds have appeared in the mythologies and religions of many cultures since ancient [[Sumer]]. For example, the dove was the symbol of the ancient [[Mesopotamian goddess]] [[Inanna]], the [[Canaan]]ite mother goddess [[Asherah]], and the Greek goddess [[Aphrodite]]. [[Athena]], the Greek goddess of wisdom, had a [[little owl]] as her symbol, and, in ancient India, the [[peacock]] represented [[Mother Nature|Mother Earth]]. Birds have often been seen as symbols, whether bringing bad luck and death, being sacred, or being used in [[heraldry]]. In terms of entertainment, [[Bird of prey|raptors]] have been used in [[falconry]], while [[aviculture|cagebirds]] have been kept for their [[bird vocalization|song]]. Other birds have been raised for the traditional sports of [[cockfight]]ing and [[pigeon racing]]. [[Birdwatching]], too, has grown to become a major leisure activity. Birds feature in a wide variety of art forms, including in [[painting]], [[sculpture]], [[poetry]] and [[prose]], [[film]] and [[fashion]]. [[Birds in music|Birds also appear in music]] as well as traditional [[dance]] and [[ballet]]. In certain cases, such as the [[bird-and-flower painting]] of China, birds are central to an artistic genre.
==Context==
[[Culture]] consists of the [[social behaviour]] and [[Norm (social)|norms]] found in [[human]] [[society|societies]] and transmitted through social [[learning]]. [[Cultural universals]] in all human societies include expressive forms like [[art]], [[music]], [[dance]], [[ritual]], [[religion]], and [[technology|technologies]] like [[tool|tool usage]], [[cooking]], [[shelter (building)|shelter]], and [[clothing]]. The concept of [[material culture]] covers physical expressions such as technology, architecture and art, whereas immaterial culture includes principles of [[social organization]], [[mythology]], [[philosophy]], [[literature]], and [[science]].<ref name=MacionisGerber2011>{{cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |title=Sociology |last=Macionis |first=John J. |last2=Gerber |first2=Linda Marie |date=2011 |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |isbn=978-0137001613 |page=53 |accessdate=29 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045455/https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |archivedate=18 August 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref> This article describes the roles played by birds in human culture, so defined.
==Economic uses==
Birds are important economically, providing substantial amounts of food, especially protein, largely but not exclusively from the domestic chicken;<ref name=Adler/><ref name=CIWF/> feathers and down are used for bedding, insulation, and other purposes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sheikh |first1=Farhan |title=Poultry feathers-how many ways they can be used for? |url=http://thepoultryguide.com/uses-of-chicken-feathers/ |website=The Poultry Guide |date=22 June 2013}}</ref>
===As food=== {{main|Poultry farming}} [[File:Egyptian - Vase in the Shape of a Duck - Walters 48421 - Profile.jpg|thumb|left|Ducks were common in [[Ancient Egypt]], as depicted in this 3rd century BC [[faience]] vase.]]
[[Birds]] were among the wild animals hunted for food before the [[Neolithic revolution]] and the development of agriculture. For example, in the [[Epipaleolithic]] of the [[Levant]], between c. 14,500 and 11,500 BP, both [[waterfowl]] and [[bird migration|migratory birds]] were eaten.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cummings |first1=Vicki |last2=Jordan |first2=Peter |last3=Zvelebil |first3=Marek|title=The Oxford Handbook of the Archaeology and Anthropology of Hunter-Gatherers |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nl2yAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT239 |year=2014 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-102526-6 |page=239}}</ref> Archaeologists have studied the return in terms of energy from captured food compared to the energy expended to capture it; birds provide a smaller return than larger game such as deer, but better than many plant materials. For example, waterfowl captured in a drive can yield a return of around 2,000 kcal/hour, whereas an antelope can yield as much as 31,000 kcal/hour, and wild rye around 1,000 kcal/hour.<ref>{{cite book |author=Kelly, Robert L. |title=The Lifeways of Hunter-Gatherers: The Foraging Spectrum |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CDAWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA53 |year=2013 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-1-107-02487-8 |pages=53–56}}</ref>
[[File:Battery hens -Bastos, Sao Paulo, Brazil-31March2007.jpg|thumb|upright|Battery hens: [[poultry]] is a major source of food, the [[chicken]] alone providing 20% of the world's animal protein.<ref name=Poultry/>]]
Birds have been [[domestication|domesticated]] and bred as [[poultry]] for use as food for at least four thousand years. The most important species is the [[chicken]]. It appears to have been domesticated by 5000 BC in northeastern China, likely for cockfighting, and only later used for food.<ref name=Adler>{{cite news |title=How the Chicken Conquered the World |author1=Adler, Jerry |author2=Lawler, Andrew |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/how-the-chicken-conquered-the-world-87583657/ |newspaper=Smithsonian Magazine |date=June 1, 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref> In [[ancient Egypt]], poultry including ducks, geese, and pigeons were captured in nets and then bred in captivity.<ref>{{cite book |year=1998 |author=Manuelian, Peter der |title=Egypt: The World of the Pharaohs |location=Cologne, Germany|publisher=Könemann |isbn=3-89508-913-3 |page=381}}</ref>
Chicken now provides some 20% of the animal protein eaten by the world's human population in the form of meat and [[egg]]s. [[Poultry farming|Chickens are often raised intensively]] in [[battery farm]]s; this facilitates production but has been criticised on animal welfare grounds.<ref name=CIWF>{{cite web |url=https://www.ciwf.org.uk/farm-animals/chickens/egg-laying-hens/ |title=About egg laying hens |publisher=Compassion in World Farming |accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref> Other species including [[ducks]], [[geese]], [[pheasants]], [[guineafowl]] and [[turkeys]] are significant economically around the world.<ref name=Poultry>{{cite web |title=History of Poultry |url=http://www.poultryclub.org/poultry/history-of-poultry/ |publisher=The Poultry Club of Great Britain |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> Less commonly raised species such as the [[ostrich]] are starting to be farmed for their meat, which is low in [[cholesterol]]; they have also been kept for their feathers, and for leather from their skin.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shanawany |first1=M. M. |title=Recent developments in ostrich farming |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/v6200t/v6200T02.htm |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref>
Birds are hunted in many countries around the world. In the developed world, ducks such as [[mallard]], [[wigeon]], [[shoveler]] and [[teal]] have for centuries been captured by [[waterfowl hunting|wildfowlers]], while pheasants, [[partridges]], [[driven grouse shooting|grouse]], and [[snipe]] are among the terrestrial birds that are [[hunting|hunted]] for sport, generally with guns.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Marchington |first1=John |title=History of Wildfowling |date=1980 |publisher=A & C Black |isbn=978-0-713-62053-5}}</ref> In other parts of the world, traditional subsistence hunting still continues, as in rural Northern Papua, where [[cassowaries]], [[crowned pigeon]]s, [[hornbill]]s and [[megapode]]s are captured for food.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pangau-Adam |first1=Margaretha |last2=Noske |first2=Richard |editor1-last=Tideman |editor1-first=Sonia |editor2-last=Gosler |editor2-first=Andrew |title=Wildlife Hunting and Bird Trade in Northern Papua (Irian Jaya), Indonesia |work=Aboriginal stories: The riches and colour of Australian birds |date=2010 |publisher=Earthscan|pages=74–85 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Tim_Whiteside/publication/236596667_Aboriginal_stories_The_riches_and_colour_of_Australian_birds/links/0046352d335d8135ea000000/Aboriginal-stories-The-riches-and-colour-of-Australian-birds.pdf}}</ref> [[Seabird]]s such as [[Muttonbirding|muttonbirds]], [[penguin]]s and [[auks]] have been hunted for food, formerly with sufficient intensity to threaten many populations and to make some, such as the [[great auk]], extinct.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Simeone, A. |author2=Navarro, X. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2002 |title=Human exploitation of seabirds in coastal southern Chile during the mid-Holocene |journal=Rev. Chil. Hist. Nat |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=423–431|url=http://www.scielo.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0716-078X2002000200012&lng=es&nrm=iso&tlng=en|doi=10.4067/S0716-078X2002000200012}}</ref><ref name="Anderson">{{cite journal |author=Anderson, A. |year=1996 |title=Origins of Procellariidae Hunting in the Southwest Pacific |journal=International Journal of Osteoarcheology |volume=6 |pages= 403–410 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1212(199609)6:4<403::AID-OA296>3.0.CO;2-0 |issue=4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Burnham, W. |author2=Burnham, K. K. |author3=Cade, T. J. |year=2005 |title=Past and present assessments of bird life in Uummannaq District, West Greenland |journal=Dansk Orn. Foren. Tidsskr. |volume=99 |pages=196–208 |url=http://www.birdlife.org/news/news/2006/01/birdlife_in_uummannaq.pdf}}</ref> Seabird hunting continues at more moderate levels today, for instance with the traditional Māori harvest of [[sooty shearwater]] chicks.<ref name=McGonigal>{{cite book |last=McGonigal |first=David |authorlink=David McGonigal |title=Antarctica: Secrets of the Southern Continent |year=2008 |publisher=Firefly Books |isbn=978-1-55407-398-6 |page=220}}</ref>
===Assisting hunters and gatherers=== [[File:Greater Honeyguide, Gambia.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Some peoples in Africa are guided to the nests of wild bees by the [[greater honeyguide]].]]
The archaeological and historical records suggest interdependence between humans and [[vulture]]s for millions of years. Like other animal species, early [[hominin]]s probably used these birds as beacons signalling the location of meat, in the form of [[Cadaver|carcasses]], in the landscape.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Morelli |first=F. |last2=Kubicka |first2=A. | last3=Tryjanowski |first3=P. | last4=Nelson |first4=N. |year=2015 |title=The vulture in the sky and the hominin on the land: three million years of human-vulture interaction |journal=Anthrozoos |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=449–468 |doi=10.1080/08927936.2015.1052279}}</ref>
[[Cormorant fishing]] is a traditional fishing method in which trained [[cormorant]]s are used to catch fish in rivers. Historically, cormorant fishing has taken place in [[Japan]] and [[China]] since about 960 AD.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Jackson | first1 = C. E. | title = Fishing with cormorants | doi = 10.3366/anh.1997.24.2.189 | journal = Archives of Natural History | volume = 24 | issue = 2 | pages = 189–211 | year = 1997}}</ref>
The [[greater honeyguide]] guides people in some parts of Africa to the nests of wild bees.<ref name="IsackReyer1989">{{cite journal |author1=Isack, H. A. |author2=Reyer, H.-U. | title=Honeyguides and honey gatherers: interspecific communication in a symbiotic relationship | journal=Science | volume=243 | year=1989 | pages=1343–1346 | doi=10.1126/science.243.4896.1343 | pmid=17808267 | issue=4896 }}</ref> A guiding bird attracts a person's attention with a chattering call, and flies in short bounds towards a bees' nest. When the human honey-hunter has taken their honey, the honeyguide eats what is left.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Short, Lester |author2=Horne, Jennifer | year=2002 | title=[[Handbook of the Birds of the World]]: Jacamars to Woodpeckers, Vol. 7 | chapter=Family Indicatoridae (Honeyguides) | chapter-url=http://www.hbw.com/hbw/volume7/family7.html |editor1=Josep Del Hoyo |editor2=Andrew Elliott |editor3=Jordi Sargatal | publisher=Lynx | isbn=84-87334-37-7}}</ref><ref name="ShortHorneDiamond2003">{{cite book |author1=Short, Lester |author2=Horne, Jennifer |author3=Diamond, A. W. | year=2003 | title=Firefly Encyclopedia of Birds | chapter =honeyguides | editor=[[Christopher Perrins]] | pages=396–397 | publisher=Firefly Books | isbn=1-55297-777-3}}</ref> The [[Borana Oromo|Boran people]] of East Africa use a specific whistle, which doubles the encounter rate with honeyguides; they find that using a honeyguide reduces the time to find honey by two-thirds.<ref name="IsackReyer1989" /> The [[Bushmen]] of the [[Kalahari]] thank the honeyguide with a gift of honey.<ref name="ShortHorneDiamond2003" />
{{anchor|In fashion}}
===Materials=== [[File:Dunhreinsun2.jpg|thumb|upright|A farmer in [[Iceland]] separating [[down feather|eiderdown]] gathered from nests of [[eider duck]]s from mixed-in hay]]
Feathers are used to make warm and soft [[bedding]], including [[quilt|eiderdowns]] from the [[down feather|belly down]] of the [[eider duck]], and winter clothing as they have high "loft", trapping a large amount of air for their weight.<ref>{{Cite journal |journal=Journal of Materials Science Letters |title=The structural mechanical properties of down feathers and biomimicking natural insulation materials |volume=18 |issue=21 |pages=1769–1770 |year=1999 |author1=Bonser, R.H.C. |author2=Dawson, C. |lastauthoramp=yes |doi=10.1023/A:1006631328233}}</ref> Feathers were used also for [[quill]] pens,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Quill Pen|url=https://www.history.org/Foundation/journal/Winter07/lettersSide.cfm |publisher=Colonial Williamsburg Foundation|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> for [[fletching]] [[arrow (weapon)|arrow]]s,<ref>{{cite book |author=Massey, Jim |date=1992 |title=Self Arrows |work=The Traditional Bowyer's Bible Volume One |editor=Hamm, Jim |publisher=Lyons Press |isbn=1-58574-085-3}}</ref> and to decorate [[fishing lure]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wakeford |first=Jacqueline |title=Fly Tying Tools and Materials |year=1992 |publisher=Lyons & Burford |pages=Preface |isbn=1-55821-183-7 }}</ref>
Bird bones were used by [[stone age]] peoples to make [[Bradawl|awls]] and other tools.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bone Tools |url=http://archaeology.uiowa.edu/bone-tools-0 |publisher=[[University of Iowa]] Office of the State Archaeologist |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> [[Guano]], the droppings of seabirds, rich in [[nitrogen]], [[phosphorus]], and [[potassium]], was once important as an agricultural [[fertiliser]] and is still used in [[organic farming]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Cushman |first=Gregory T. |title=Guano and the Opening of the Pacific World: A Global Ecological History |year=2013 |publisher=Cambridge Univ. Press |location=Cambridge and New York |isbn=9781107004139 }}</ref> The [[War of the Pacific]] in 1865 was in part about which country had control of the territory containing valuable guano sources.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zum.de/whkmla/military/19cen/guanowar.html |title=The Guano War of 1865–1866 |publisher=World History at KMLA |accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> Today, birds such as the chicken and the [[Japanese quail]] are used as [[model organism]]s in [[ornithology|ornithological]] and more generally in [[biology|biological]] research, for instance in [[toxicology]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Burt |first1=D. W. |title=Emergence of the Chicken as a Model Organism: Implications for Agriculture and Biology |journal=Poultry Science |date=2007 |volume=86 |issue=7 |pages=1460–1471 |doi=10.1093/ps/86.7.1460 |pmid=17575197 |url=http://ps.oxfordjournals.org/content/86/7/1460.full}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jaspers |first1=Veerle L. B. |title=Selecting the right bird model in experimental studies on endocrine disrupting chemicals |journal=Frontiers in Environmental Science |date=2015 |volume=3 |issue=35 |doi=10.3389/fenvs.2015.00035 |url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fenvs.2015.00035/full}}</ref>
===Clothing and fashion=== [[File:Índios da etnia Bororo-Boe.jpg|thumb|left|[[Bororo (Brazil)|Bororo]] men wearing brightly-coloured feathered headdresses]]
Feathers have been important and colourful items of clothing and fashion from before the birth of civilisation. Elaborate, brightly coloured headdresses containing [[feather]]s are worn by [[indigenous peoples of the Americas]] such as the [[Bororo (Brazil)|Bororo]] of the [[Mato Grosso]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Bororo Headdress |url=http://www.indian-cultures.com/cultures/bororo-indians/ |website=Indian-cultures.com |accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> In Polynesia, ''sega ula'' [[lory]] bird feathers were major trade items, used to decorate high quality mats in Samoa and Tonga.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Barnes |first1=Shawn S. |last2=Hunt |first2=Terry L. |title=Sāmoa's Pre-Contact Connections In West Polynesia And Beyond |journal=The Journal of the Polynesian Society |date=September 2005 |volume=114 |issue=3 |pages=227–266 |jstor=20707289}}</ref>
<!--[[File:Sophie Arnould by Greuze (copy) - Gallica.jpg|thumb|upright|Painting of the actress [[Sophie Arnould]] wearing a feathered hat by [[Jean-Baptiste Greuze]], c. 1770]] --> In Western culture, feathers are used in [[Feather boa|boas]] and decorating elaborate hats and other items of ladies' clothing. Feathers in fashion were a status symbol well into the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. The [[Belle Époque|Belle Epoque]] draped its clothing in feathers as ornaments.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.disegnodaily.com/article/birds-of-paradise-plumes-and-feathers-in-fashion |title=Birds of Paradise. Plumes and Feathers in Fashion |access-date=}}</ref> [[Ostrich]] plumes were a luxury commodity in Europe for centuries, leading to serious harm to wild ostrich populations, and subsequent establishment of ostrich farms.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bourn |first1=Aomar |last2=Bonine |first2=Michael |title=The elegant plume: ostrich feathers, African commercial networks, and European capitalism |journal=Journal of North African Studies |date=2015 |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=5–26 |doi=10.1080/13629387.2014.983733}}</ref> Classical 1930s Hollywood films used feathers in abundance, arguably as a metaphor for female sexuality. For example, in the 1935 musical ''[[Top Hat]]'', [[Ginger Rogers]] danced "Cheek to Cheek" covered in white plumes that emphasised her movements.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dirix |first1=Emmanuelle |title=Birds of paradise: Feathers, fetishism and costume in classical Hollywood |journal=Film, Fashion, and Consumption |date=1 March 2014 |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=15–29 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/intellect/ffc/2014/00000003/00000001/art00002 |doi=10.1386/ffc.3.1.15_1}}</ref> Late twentieth century designers such as [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]] and [[Alexander McQueen]] used feathers to make fashion statements.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stratford |first1=Oli |title=Birds of Paradise. Plumes and Feathers in Fashion |url=https://www.disegnodaily.com/article/birds-of-paradise-plumes-and-feathers-in-fashion#slide-2 |publisher=Disegno |date=20 March 2014}}</ref>
===Sports and hobbies=== [[File:Ara macao -on a small bicycle-8.jpg|left|thumb|[[Scarlet macaw]] riding a tricycle at a show in Spain]]
[[Bird of prey|Raptors]] from eagles to small [[falcon]]s have for centuries been used in [[falconry]], often to catch other birds, whether for pleasure or for food.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Falconry|url=http://www.thefalconrycentre.co.uk/bird-info/conservation/nocturnal-raptors/history-falconry/|publisher=The Falconry Centre|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref>
[[Cockfight]]ing is an ancient spectator sport. It formed part of the culture of the ancient Indians, Chinese, Greeks, and Romans. It continues to be practised in South America and across South and Southeast Asia, often combined with betting on the result.<ref name=Crews>{{cite web |last=Crews |first=Ed |title=Once Popular and Socially Acceptable: Cockfighting |url=https://www.history.org/Foundation/journal/Autumn08/rooster.cfm |publisher=Colonial Williamsburg Foundation |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lawler |first1=Andrew |title=Birdmen. Cockfighters spread the chicken across the globe |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2014/12/cockfighting_and_chicken_history_the_world_slasher_cup_in_the_philippines.html |publisher=Slate |accessdate=22 April 2016 |date=2 December 2014}}</ref> It is practised in religious ceremonies in Hindu temples in [[Bali]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Cook |first=William |title=Cockfighting: the last, hidden link to Bali's warlike past |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2015/01/cockfighting-the-last-hidden-link-to-balis-warlike-past/ |publisher=[[The Spectator]] |accessdate=22 April 2016 |date=3 January 2015}}</ref> but is now banned in many countries on grounds of cruelty.<ref name=Crews/>
[[Pigeon racing]] involves releasing specially trained [[racing pigeon]]s to return to their homes over a measured distance of between {{convert|100|km|mi}} and {{convert|1000|km|mi}}. The sport was popularised in Belgium in the 19th century, and is now competitive worldwide.<ref>{{cite book |last=Levi |first=Wendell |title=The Pigeon |year=1977 |publisher=Levi Publishing |pages=4, 40 | isbn=0-85390-013-2}}</ref> Also in Belgium and [[Flanders]] is ''[[vinkensport]]'', in which participants have male chaffinches compete to make the most [[bird call]]s in an hour.<ref>{{cite news |first=Bilefsky |last=Dan |title=One-Ounce Belgian Idols Vie for Most Tweets per Hour |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=21 May 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/21/world/europe/21finch.html }}</ref>
[[Birdwatching]] has since the nineteenth century become a major leisure activity.<ref name="dunne">{{cite book |last=Dunne |first=Pete |title=Pete Dunne on Bird Watching |year=2003 |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |isbn=0-395-90686-5}}</ref><ref name="oddie">{{cite book |last=Oddie |first=Bill |title=Bill Oddie's Little Black Bird Book |year=1980 |publisher=Butler & Tanner |isbn=0-413-47820-3}}</ref> Millions of people around the world, amounting to nearly half of all households in some developed countries, put out [[birdfeeder]]s to attract birds to their gardens or windowsills, at a cost of billions of dollars each year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.audubon.org/bird/at_home/bird_feeding/index.html |title=Bird Feeding Basics |publisher=Audubon |date=2004 |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rspb.org.uk/advice/helpingbirds/feeding/index.asp |title=Feeding birds |publisher=[[The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] |date=3 November 2009 |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tryjanowski |first1=Piotr et al|title=Urban and rural habitats differ in number and type of bird feeders and in bird species consuming supplementary food |journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research International |date=2015 |volume=22 |issue=19 |pages=15097–15103 |doi=10.1007/s11356-015-4723-0 |pmid=4592493|pmc=4592493}}</ref>
===As pets=== [[File:LA2-NSRW-3-0536 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Charles Darwin]] noted that [[Pigeon fancying|pigeon fanciers]] had created many kinds of pigeon, such as [[Tumbler pigeon|Tumblers]] (1, 12), [[Fantail pigeon|Fantails]] (13), and [[Pouter pigeon|Pouters]] (14) by [[selective breeding]].<ref name=Secord/>]]
[[Aviculture|Cagebirds]] such as [[domestic canary|canaries]], [[budgerigars]], [[cockatoo]]s, [[lovebird]]s, [[quail]]s, [[finch]]es, and [[parrot]]s are popular [[pet]]s, whether for their song, their behaviour, their colourful plumage, or their [[talking bird|ability to mimic speech]]. Among reasons for their popularity is that they can be kept in homes too small or otherwise unsuitable for dogs or cats.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Avicultural Society|url=http://www.avisoc.co.uk/|publisher=The Avicultural Society |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Lane |first=Megan |title=How can birds teach each other to talk? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-14930062 |publisher=BBC News |date=16 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Popular pet Birds |url=http://www.birdchannel.com/bird-species/|publisher=The Bird Channel |accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kalhagen |first1=Alyson |title=Top Reasons Why a Bird Could Be the Best Choice for Your Family |url=http://birds.about.com/od/adoptingabird/tp/birdsgoodpets.htm |date=25 November 2014}}</ref> The cagebird trade in some parts of the world threatens certain species with extinction, when birds are illegally captured in the wild. For example, in Indonesia, at least 13 species are close to extinction including the Indonesian national bird, the [[Javan hawk-eagle]], while five subspecies including the [[scarlet-breasted lorikeet]] may have become extinct in the wild.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Platt |first1=John R. |title=Illegal Pet Trade Threatens 13 Indonesian Birds with Extinction |url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/extinction-countdown/13-indonesian-birds/ |publisher=Scientific American |date=25 May 2016}}</ref>
Pet birds are kept in their millions, as are domestic fowls, [[Bantam (poultry)|bantam]]s, and [[pigeon]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pet Population 2015 |publisher=Pet Food Manufacturers' Association |accessdate=25 April 2016 |url=http://www.pfma.org.uk/pet-population-2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Levi |first=Wendell |title=The Pigeon |year=1977 |publisher= Levi Publishing |isbn=0-85390-013-2 |pages=Chapter 1}}</ref> These last had an important effect on evolutionary biology, as [[Charles Darwin]] took an especial interest in [[pigeon fancying]], adopted the hobby himself, and made use of the wide variation between breeds as an argument for the power of [[selective breeding|selection]] in his 1859 ''[[Origin of Species]]''.<ref name=Secord>{{cite journal |last1=Secord |first1=James A. |title=Nature's Fancy: Charles Darwin and the Breeding of Pigeons |journal=Isis |date=June 1981 |volume=72 |issue=2 |pages=162–186 |jstor=230968 |doi=10.1086/352717}}</ref>
==Symbolic uses==
===Inspiration=== [[File:Chicken Mask Bali.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Wooden [[mask]] in form of a chicken. [[Bali]], late 20th century]]
The nature writers Mark Cocker and [[Richard Mabey]], reviewing people's love of birds, observe that people are touched by feelings for birds in a variety of ways, such as enjoying the [[northern lapwing|lapwing's]] "joyous display",<ref name=CockerMabey2005>{{cite book |last1=Cocker |first1=Mark |last2=Mabey |first2=Richard |author2link=Richard Mabey |title=Birds Britannica |titlelink=Birds Britannica |date=2005 |publisher=Chatto & Windus |isbn=0-7011-6907-9 |pages=ix–x, 436–437 and passim}}</ref> or the "beauty and mystery" of the [[tawny owl]]'s call on a cold winter's night.<ref name=CockerMabey2005/> They argue that people feel the simple companionship of birds, are inspired by them to create art, let them mark the seasons and provide a sense of place, and use them "as symbols of joy and love".<ref name=CockerMabey2005/> A former statesman, [[Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon]], was able to express his feeling for birds in his 1927 book ''The Charm of Birds''.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Grey, Edward |authorlink1=Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon |title=The Charm of Birds |date=1927 |publisher=Hodder and Stoughton}}</ref> Such feelings, in turn, have stimulated the intention to conserve birds and their habitats.<ref name=CockerMabey2005/> Around the same time as Grey was writing, the first conservation organisations were coming into being, starting in Britain, triggered by the rapid disappearance of familiar species as they were captured for their feathers or for food.<ref name=CockerMabey2005/> A substantial folklore rich in symbolism has accrued around birds; it was documented early in the 20th century as something that was already fading from memory. For example, the [[house sparrow]] has been associated with "sex and lechery"<ref name=CockerMabey2005/> since ancient Egypt, where libidinousness was written with the sparrow hieroglyph. In the same vein, in the classical era the sparrow was sacred to the goddess of love, [[Aphrodite]] or [[Venus (goddess)|Venus]]; the sparrow features in an erotic poem by Catullus for the same reason. [[Chaucer]] describes the summoner in his ''[[Canterbury Tales]]'' as being as "lecherous as a sparwe".<ref name=CockerMabey2005/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Ingersoll |first1=Ernest |title=Birds in Legend, Fable, and Folklore |date=1923 |publisher=Longmans Green}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Armstrong |first1=Edward A. |title=The Folklore of Birds|date=1958 |publisher=Collins ([[New Naturalist]] series)}}</ref>
Studies have shown how important birds are to individual societies, touching on all aspects of life. In Andean societies such as the [[Moche culture|Moche]] (1–800 AD), [[Nazca people|Nazca]] (100–700 AD) and [[Chimu]] (1150–1450 AD), bright parrot and macaw feathers were traded from the Amazon rainforest to the mountains and the Pacific coast, while guano was collected as a fertiliser, and artists and craftsmen were inspired to create textiles, metal jewellery, and ceramics depicting condors, cormorants, ducks, hummingbirds, owls, vultures, and waders. Their religions, too, endowed birds with symbolic meaning.<ref>{{cite web |title=Birds of the Andes |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/bird/hd_bird.htm |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art |accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Sign for the Spread Eagle - geograph.org.uk - 517603.jpg|thumb|upright|The Spread Eagle pub sign: [[Pub names|the pub is named]] after a [[Spreadeagle (heraldry)|heraldic symbol]].]]
The [[Audubon society]], reviewing the importance of birds in 2013, obtained statements from many people with differing perspectives. Among them, the society's science director, Gary Langham, noted that what is good for birds is also good for humans. The writer [[David Allen Sibley]] observed that birds bring a little wildness into parks and gardens.<ref name=Audubon/> The writer [[Barbara Kingsolver]] noted that birds are part of life on earth. The actress [[Jane Alexander]] wrote "Birds remind us that there are angels."<ref name=Audubon/> The forensic ornithologist Carla Dove noted that birds are biological indicators of habitat health, climate change, and the coming of spring.<ref name=Audubon>{{cite web|title=Why Do Birds Matter?|url=http://www.audubon.org/magazine/march-april-2013/why-do-birds-matter|publisher=Audubon|date=April 2013}}</ref>
===Symbolism and heraldry=== [[File:Coat of arms of São Tomé and Príncipe.svg|thumb|left|A [[Red-footed falcon]] and a [[Grey parrot]] are used as [[supporters]] in the [[Coat of arms of São Tomé and Príncipe]], providing an example of birds in heraldry.]] Birds have been seen as symbols, and used as such, though perceptions of bird species vary widely across cultures: some birds have a positive image in some regions, a negative image in others. [[Owl]]s are associated with bad luck, [[witchcraft]], and death in parts of Africa,<ref>Enriquez, P.L.; Mikkola, H. (1997). "Comparative study of general public owl knowledge in Costa Rica, Central America and Malawi, Africa". pp. 160–66 In: J.R. Duncan, D.H. Johnson, T.H. Nicholls, (Eds). ''Biology and conservation of owls of the Northern Hemisphere. General Technical Report NC-190'', USDA Forest Service, St. Paul, Minnesota. 635 pp.</ref> but are regarded as wise across much of Europe.<ref>Lewis DP (2005). [http://www.owlpages.com/articles.php?section=Owl+Mythology&title=Myth+and+Culture Owlpages.com], Owls in Mythology and Culture. Retrieved on 15 September 2007</ref> [[Hoopoe]]s were considered sacred in [[Ancient Egypt]] and symbols of virtue in [[Persia]], but were thought of as thieves across much of Europe, and harbingers of war in [[Scandinavia]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1=Dupree | first1=N. | year=1974 | title=An Interpretation of the Role of the Hoopoe in Afghan Folklore and Magic | journal=Folklore | volume=85 | issue=3| pages=173–93 | jstor=1260073 | doi=10.1080/0015587X.1974.9716553 }}</ref>
In [[heraldry]], birds, especially [[Eagle (heraldry)|eagles]], often appear in [[coats of arms]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Fox-Davies, A. C. |title=A Complete Guide to Heraldry |publisher=Bloomsbury |date=1985}}</ref> In Britain, over 3000 [[pub]]s have birds in [[pub names|their names]], sometimes commemorating a local family with a bird from their coat of arms, sometimes for other reasons. There are dozens of pubs named "[[Crow's nest|Crow's Nest]]" (nautical), "[[Dog and Duck, Soho|Dog & Duck]]" (wildfowling), "[[Eagle & Child]]" (heraldic), and "Falcon" (heraldic, or falconry), while over 600 pubs are named for [[swan]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cocker |first1=Mark |last2=Mabey |first2=Richard |author2link=Richard Mabey |title=Birds Britannica |titlelink=Birds Britannica |date=2005 |publisher=Chatto & Windus |isbn=0-7011-6907-9 |pages=473–476}}</ref>
Birds, too, may symbolise human attributes such as stupidity or talkativeness. People have been called "birdbrain[ed]" or "cuckoo", among many other [[animal epithet]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Birdbrain |url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/birdbrain |publisher=Merriam-Webster |accessdate=16 June 2017}}</ref> Birds feature prominently in often derogatory [[simile]]s like "noisy as a goose" and [[metaphor]]s including "to parrot".<ref name=Sakalauskaite>{{cite book |last1=Sakalauskaite |first1=Aida |title=Zoometaphors in English, German, and Lithuanian: A Corpus Study |date=2010 |publisher=University of California, Berkeley (PhD Thesis) |url=http://digitalassets.lib.berkeley.edu/etd/ucb/text/Sakalauskaite_berkeley_0028E_10322.pdf}}</ref>
===Mythology and religion=== [[File:Thoout, Thoth Deux fois Grand, le Second Hermés, N372.2A.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Thoth]], the [[Ibis]]-headed scribe of the gods.]]
Birds have appeared in mythology and religion in a variety of guises.
Birds have featured as gods from the time of [[ancient Egypt]], where the [[sacred ibis]] was venerated as a symbol of the god [[Thoth]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wheye |first1=Darryl |last2=Kennedy |first2=Donald |title=Humans, Nature, and Birds: Science Art from Cave Walls to Computer Screens |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TnDg03_Hb7sC&pg=PA36-IA2 |year=2008 |publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=978-0-300-12388-3 |page=36}}</ref> In India, the [[common peacock|peacock]] is perceived as Mother Earth among [[Dravidian people]]s,<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Thankappan Nair | first1=P. | title=The Peacock Cult in Asia | journal=Asian Folklore Studies | volume=33 | issue=2 | pages=93–170 | year=1974 |doi=10.2307/1177550 | jstor=1177550}}</ref> while the [[Mughal era|Mughal]] and [[History of Iran|Persian]] emperors displayed their godlike authority by sitting in a [[Peacock Throne]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Clarke | first1=CP | year=1908 | title=A Pedestal of the Platform of the Peacock Throne | journal=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin | volume=3 | issue=10| pages=182–83 | doi=10.2307/3252550 | jstor=3252550}}</ref> In the [[Yazidis|Yazidi]] religion, [[Melek Taus]] the "Peacock Angel" is the central figure of their faith.<ref>{{cite web |title=What is the Peacock Angel? |url=http://www.yeziditruth.org/the_peacock_angel |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> In the cult of [[Makemake (mythology)|Makemake]], the [[Tangata manu]] birds of [[Easter Island]] served as chiefs.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1=Routledge | first1=S. | last2=Routledge | first2=K. | year=1917 | title=The Bird Cult of Easter Island | journal=Folklore | volume=28 | issue=4| pages=337–55 | doi=10.1080/0015587X.1917.9719006 }}</ref>
[[File:Butterfly-shaped ivory vessel with the pattern of two birds facing the sun(Neolithic) in Zhejiang Museum.JPG|thumb|Butterfly-shaped ivory vessel with the pattern of two birds facing the sun, which demonstrates the sacred primitive belief of Hemudu people. [[Hemudu culture]], c. 5500-3300 BC]]
Birds have been seen as spirit messengers of the gods. In [[Norse mythology]], [[Hugin and Munin]] were [[common raven|ravens]] who whispered news into the ears of the god [[Odin]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Lukas | first1=S.E. | last2=Benedikt | first2=R. | last3=Mendelson | first3=J.H. | last4=Kouri | first4=E. | last5=Sholar | first5=M. | last6=Amass | first6=L. | title=Marihuana attenuates the rise in plasma ethanol levels in human subjects | journal=Neuropsychopharmacology | volume=7 | issue=1 | pages=77–81 | year=1992 | pmid=1326277}}</ref> In the [[Etruscan mythology|Etruscan]] and [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] [[Religion in Ancient Rome|religion]]s of [[History of Italy|ancient Italy]], priests were involved in [[augur]]y, interpreting the words of birds while the "auspex" watched their activities to foretell events.<ref>Ingersoll, Ernest (1923). [https://archive.org/details/birdsinlegendfab00inge Archive.org], ''Birds in legend, fable and folklore''. Longmans, Green, page 214</ref> In the [[Inca]] and [[Tiwanaku]] empires of South America, birds are depicted transgressing the boundaries between the earthly and underground spiritual realms.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Smith, S. |year=2011 |title=Generative landscapes: the step mountain motif in Tiwanaku iconography. |journal=Ancient America |volume=12 |pages=1–69 |url=http://www.precolumbia.com/bearc/CAAS/AA12.pdf}}</ref> Indigenous peoples of the central Andes maintain legends of birds passing to and from metaphysical worlds.<ref name="Smith2011Tiwanaku">{{cite journal |author=Smith, S. |year=2011 |title=Generative landscapes: the step mountain motif in Tiwanaku iconography. |journal=Ancient America |volume=12 |pages=1–69 |url=http://www.precolumbia.com/bearc/CAAS/AA12.pdf |format=Automatic PDF download}}</ref> The mythical chullumpi bird is said to mark the existence of a portal between such worlds, and to transform itself into a llama.<ref name="Smith2011Tiwanaku"/><ref name="Dransart2002Earth">{{cite book |author=Dransart, P. |year=2002 |title=Earth, Water, Fleece and Fabric: An Ethnography and Archaeology of Andean Camelid Herding |publisher=Routledge |pages=64, 79 }}</ref> Among the [[Parsee]]s of India and Iran, and among practitioners of [[Vajrayana Buddhism]] who believe in the [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|transmigration of souls]] in [[Sikkim]], [[Mongolia]], [[Bhutan]] and [[Nepal]], [[sky burial]] has been practised for centuries. In this ritual, corpses are left exposed for [[griffon vulture]]s to pick clean.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=van Dooren |first1=Thom |title=Vultures and their People in India: Equity and Entanglement in a Time of Extinctions |journal=Australian Humanities Review |date=May 2011 |issue=50 |url=http://www.australianhumanitiesreview.org/archive/Issue-May-2011/vandooren.html |access-date=24 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011145001/http://www.australianhumanitiesreview.org/archive/Issue-May-2011/vandooren.html |archive-date=11 October 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The practice is declining, not least because of the [[Indian vulture crisis|loss of most of the vulture population across South Asia]] to accidental poisoning by the [[anti-inflammatory]] veterinary drug [[diclofenac]].<ref>{{cite news |work=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/30/world/asia/cultivating-vultures-to-restore-a-mumbai-ritual.html |title=Giving New Life to Vultures to Restore a Human Ritual of Death |date=29 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=npr |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/09/05/160401322/vanishing-vultures-a-grave-matter-for-indias-parsis |title=Vanishing Vultures A Grave Matter For India's Parsis |date=5 September 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Nadir Madrasah Phoenix.JPG|thumb|[[Simurgh]] in tilework on Nadir Divan-Beghi Madrasah, [[Bukhara]], Uzbekistan]]
Birds have sometimes served as religious symbols. In ancient [[Mesopotamia]], doves were prominent animal symbols of [[Inanna]] (later known as Ishtar), the goddess of love, sexuality, and war,<ref name="Botterweck">{{cite book|last1=Botterweck|first1=G. Johannes|last2=Ringgren|first2=Helmer|date=1990|title=Theological Dictionary of the Old Testament|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MCOd-uAEQy0C&pg=PA35&q=Ishtar%20doves|volume=VI|location=Grand Rapids, Michigan|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co.|isbn=0-8028-2330-0|pages=35–36|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Lewis">{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Sian|last2=Llewellyn-Jones|first2=Lloyd|date=2018|title=The Culture of Animals in Antiquity: A Sourcebook with Commentaries|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GvJFDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT335&q=Ishtar%20doves|location=New York City, New York and London, England|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-315-20160-3|page=335|ref=harv}}</ref> and, in the [[History of the ancient Levant|ancient Levant]], doves were used as symbols for the [[Ancient Canaanite religion|Canaanite]] mother goddess [[Asherah]].<ref name="Botterweck"/><ref name="Lewis"/><ref name="BAR">[http://www.bib-arch.org/e-features/enduring-doves.asp The Enduring Symbolism of Doves, From Ancient Icon to Biblical Mainstay by Dorothy D. Resig BAR Magazine] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131120659/http://www.bib-arch.org/e-features/enduring-doves.asp |date=31 January 2013 }}. Bib-arch.org (9 February 2013). Retrieved on 5 March 2013.</ref> In [[ancient Greece]], [[Athena]], the goddess of wisdom and patron deity of the city of [[Athens]], had a [[little owl]] as [[Owl of Athena|her symbol]].<ref name="Deacy, Susan 2001">{{cite book |last1=Deacy |first1=Susan |authorlink=Susan Deacy |last2=Villing |first2=Alexandra|date=2001|title=Athena in the Classical World |publisher=Koninklijke Brill NV|location=Leiden, The Netherlands |isbn=978-9004121423 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Deacy2008">{{cite book |last=Deacy |first=Susan |date=2008 |title=Athena |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-30066-5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kIiCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA163 |pages=34–37, 74–75|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Nilsson1950">{{cite book |last=Nilsson|first=Martin Persson |authorlink=Martin P. Nilsson |title=The Minoan-Mycenaean Religion and Its Survival in Greek Religion |publisher=Biblo & Tannen |year=1950 |isbn=0-8196-0273-6 |edition=second |pages=491–496 |ref=harv}}</ref> In Greek iconography, Athena is often shown accompanied by an owl<ref name="Nilsson1950"/> and the owl was used as a symbol of Athens on [[Athenian coinage]].<ref name="Deacy2008"/> In classical antiquity, doves were sacred to the Greek goddess [[Aphrodite]],<ref name="Cyrino2010">{{cite book |last=Cyrino |first=Monica S. |date=2010 |title=Aphrodite |series=Gods and Heroes of the Ancient World |url=https://books.google.com/?id=7gyVn5GjXPkC |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0-415-77523-6 |pages=120–123 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Tinkle|first=Theresa|date=1996|title=Medieval Venuses and Cupids: Sexuality, Hermeneutics, and English Poetry |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gjhLACGml2cC&pg=PA80 |publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0804725156|page=81|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Botterweck"/><ref name="Lewis"/> who absorbed this association with doves from Inanna-Ishtar.<ref name="Lewis"/> Aphrodite frequently appears with doves in [[Pottery of ancient Greece|ancient Greek pottery]]<ref name="Cyrino2010"/> and, during Aphrodite's main festival, the [[Aphrodisia]], her altars would be purified with the blood of a [[Animal sacrifice|sacrificed dove]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Simon |first=Erika |date=1983 |title=Festivals of Attica: An Archaeological Companion|url=https://books.google.com/?id=IHFYM-IGCO8C&pg=PA48&q=Aphrodisia%20festival |publisher=University of Wisconsin Press |isbn=0-299-09184-8 |ref=harv}}</ref>
In Medieval Christian iconography, the [[cormorant]]'s "wing-drying" pose represents the Christian cross, and hence is a figure of Christ. In [[John Milton]]'s ''[[Paradise Lost]]'', on the other hand, the bird's cross-like pose is a travesty of Christ: "Then up he flew, and... Sat like a cormorant; yet not true life Thereby regained, but sat devising death To them who lived".<ref name="Fowler2014">{{cite book |last=Fowler |first=Alastair |title=Milton: Paradise Lost |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PFcSBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA228 |year=2014 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-86573-5 |pages=227–228}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Murphy-Hiscock, Arin |title=Birds – A Spiritual Field Guide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zYLYIJtWr-MC&pg=PA48 |date=2012 |publisher=Adams Media |isbn=1-4405-2688-5 |pages=48–49}}</ref>
In mythology, birds were sometimes monsters, like the [[Roc (mythology)|Roc]] and the [[Māori people|Māori]]'s ''[[Poukai|Pouākai]]'', a giant bird capable of snatching humans.<ref>Tennyson, A.; Martinson, P. (2006). ''Extinct Birds of New Zealand'', Te Papa Press, Wellington {{ISBN|978-0-909010-21-8}}</ref> In Persian mythology, the [[simurgh]] was a gigantic bird, the first to come into existence, and it nested on the tree of plant life that grew in the great ocean beside the tree of immortality. Its task was to shake the seeds of all the plants out of the tree.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Warner |first1=Arthur George |last2=Warner |first2=Edmond |title=The Shahnama of Firdausi |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-eH7AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA235 |year=2013 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-136-39505-5 |page=235}}</ref>
===In the arts=== {{further|List of fictional birds}}
Birds have been depicted throughout the arts from the earliest times to the present,<ref name=Meighan/> including in painting and sculpture, in literature, in music, in theatre, in traditional dance and ballet, and in film.<ref name=CockerMabey2005/>
[[File:Bamboo and Shrike.jpg|thumb|''Bamboo and Shrike''. Chinese [[bird-and-flower painting]], 12th century. Album leaf, ink and colours on silk.]]
====Painting and sculpture====
Birds have been depicted in paintings, sculptures and other art objects from the earliest times, including in [[cave painting]]s.<ref name=Meighan>{{cite journal | last1=Meighan | first1=C. W. | title=Prehistoric Rock Paintings in Baja California | journal=American Antiquity | volume=31 | issue=3 | pages=372–92 | year=1966 |doi=10.2307/2694739 | jstor=2694739}}</ref>
In [[Chinese painting|Chinese art]], [[bird-and-flower painting]] forms one of the three major subjects (the others being landscapes and figures), from the time of the [[Five Dynasties]] in the 10th century. [[Huang Quan (painter)|Huang Quan]] created the naturalistic ''xiesheng'' style for bird paintings.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bird Painting |url=http://www.chinaonlinemuseum.com/painting-birds.php |website=China Online Museum |accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> Birds have long been celebrated in the [[Japanese art|arts of Japan]], including in painting, woodblock printing, cloisonné, ceramics and indeed poetry from the 18th and 19th centuries. Print artists like [[Utamaro]] and [[Hokusai]] made use of Western and Chinese influences to give a sophisticated effect, while [[Hiroshige]] reworked the traditional bird-and-flower genre.<ref>{{cite web |title=Birds in Japanese Art and Poetry |url=http://www.worcesterart.org/exhibitions/past/birds_in_japanese.html |publisher=Worcester Art Museum |accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref>
In [[modern art]], some of the paintings of [[Joan Miró]] include "A tangle of lines and small, colored ideograms suggesting birds, allegorical characters, stars, and animals".<ref>{{cite web|title=Woman Encircled by the Flight of a Bird, 1941 by Joan Miro|url=http://www.joan-miro.net/woman-encircled-by-the-flight-of-a-bird.jsp|website=Joan Miro Paintings, Biography, and Quotes|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Joan Miró Women and Bird in the Moonlight 1949|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/miro-women-and-bird-in-the-moonlight-n06007|publisher=[[Tate Gallery]]|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> In modern sculpture, [[Pablo Picasso]]'s 1932 bronze ''Coq'' (Cockerel) is an assemblage of "spiky, elongated forms."<ref>{{cite web |title=Pablo Picasso Cock 1932, cast 1952 |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/picasso-cock-n06023 |publisher=[[Tate Gallery]] |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref>
In public [[statue|statuary]], the [[Magyars]]'s mythical [[Turul]] symbolises national power and nobility, and is represented by many statues in [[Hungary]], including the largest bird statue in the world, on a mountain near [[Tatabánya]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Developing The Knowledge Economy: How Cities Help National Programs In Three Eu Accession And An Eca Country |url=http://info.worldbank.org/etools/docs/library/19619/Documents%20and%20Settings/wb230542/Desktop/KECITIES/Course_Modules/4713.htm#_Toc16495747 |publisher=The Economic Development Organization of the County Town Tatabánya |accessdate=22 April 2016 |date=June 2002}}</ref><ref>Warhol, Tom. [https://books.google.com/books?id=YkepQQWk-TQC&pg=PA158 Birdwatcher's Daily Companion: 365 Days of Advice, Insight, and Information for Enthusiastic Birders], Marcus Schneck, Quarry Books, 2010, p. 158</ref><ref>István Dienes, [https://books.google.com/books?id=IDQ9AAAAIAAJ The Hungarians cross the Carpathians], Corvina Press, 1972, p. 71</ref>
[[File:Mantiq al-Tayr, The Language of the Birds, Farid al-Din Attar (detail of cover).jpg|thumb|upright|''[[The Conference of the Birds]]'' by [[Farid al-Din Attar]]. Cover detail, Iran, c. 1610]]
====Poetry====
Birds have been celebrated in [[poetry]] since ancient times, when for example the Roman poet [[Catullus]] wrote in one of his most famous works about a girl and her pet [[sparrow]] in ''[[Catullus 2|Passer, deliciae meae puellae]]'', "Sparrow, delight of my girl".<ref>{{cite journal |author=Phillimore, J.S. |title=Passer: Catull. Carm. ii |journal=Classical Philology |volume=5 |issue=2 |date=April 1910 |pages=217–219 |jstor=262194 |doi=10.1086/359388}}</ref>
Birds featured in medieval poetry, for example forming the characters of the 1177 Persian poem ''[[The Conference of the Birds]]'', where the birds of the world assemble under the wisest bird, the [[hoopoe]], to decide who is to be their king.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Conference of the Birds |author=Attar, Farid al-Din |authorlink=Farid al-Din Attar |editor1=Darbandi, Afkham |editor2=Davis, Dick |publisher=Penguin Classics |date=1984 |isbn=978-0-14-044434-6}}</ref>
In English romantic poetry, [[John Keats]]'s 1819 "[[Ode to a Nightingale]]" and [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]]'s 1820 "[[To a Skylark]]" are popular classics.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brooks |first=Cleanth |last2=Warren |first2=Robert Penn |title=The ''Ode to a Nightingale'' |work=Keats's Odes |editor-first=Jack |editor-last=Stillinger |pages=44–47 |publisher=Prentice-Hall |year=1968}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia | last=Sandy | first=Mark | title=To a Skylark | encyclopedia=The Literary Encyclopedia | date=2002 | url=http://www.litencyc.com/php/sworks.php?rec=true&UID=7305 | accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> Bird poems by [[Gerard Manley Hopkins]] include "Sea and Skylark" and "[[The Windhover]]" (on the kestrel).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hopkins |first1=Gerard Manley |title=Poems and Prose |date=1985 |publisher=Penguin Books |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=afjmf6TpHagC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227|isbn=9780140420159 }}</ref> More recently, [[Ted Hughes]]'s 1970 collection of poems about a bird character, "[[Crow (poetry)|Crow]]", is considered one of his most important works.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetedhughessociety.org/crow.htm |title=Crow – The Ted Hughes Society Journal |publisher=The Ted Hughes Society |date=2012 |accessdate=22 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702124543/http://www.thetedhughessociety.org/crow.htm |archivedate=2 July 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Collins |first1=Billy |title=Bright Wings|date=2010|publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |isbn=978-0-231-15084-2}}</ref>
====Prose==== [[File:Heron woodcut Bewick's British Birds 1847.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Wood engraving]] of a [[heron]] in [[Thomas Bewick]]'s 1797–1804 ''[[A History of British Birds]]'']]
Birds have similarly appeared in literature from ancient times.<ref name=Lutwack>{{cite book |last1=Lutwack |first1=Leonard |title=Birds in Literature |date=1994 |publisher=University Press of Florida |isbn=978-0-8130-1254-4}}</ref> Among [[Aesop's Fables]] are [[The Wolf and the Crane]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Aesop for Children (1919) 48. The Wolf and the Crane |url=http://mythfolklore.net/aesopica/milowinter/14.htm |website=Aesopica |accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> and [[The Fox and the Stork]]; these [[fable]]s, which have analogues in eastern traditions such as the Buddhist ''Javasakuna [[Jataka]]'',<ref>{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/jatakatales00fran#page/222/mode/2upv |title=JatakaTales |author=Francis, H. T.; Thomas, E. J. |publisher=Cambridge University Press |date=1916 |pages=223–224}}</ref> use birds to imply moral conclusions about human behaviour.<ref>{{cite web |title=Aesop for Children (1919) 48. The Fox and the Stork |url=http://mythfolklore.net/aesopica/milowinter/48.htm |website=Aesopica |accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref>
[[File:66 Ivory-billed Woodpecker (Duke of Portland Audubon edition).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ivory-billed woodpecker]] from [[John James Audubon|Audubon]]'s 1827–1838 ''[[Birds of America (book)|Birds of America]]'']]
More recently, birds have appeared in books illustrated by some exceptional artists, producing images that were accurate and beautiful, and that made use of the latest available printing techniques. The [[wood engraver]] [[Thomas Bewick]]'s 1797–1804 ''[[A History of British Birds]]'' brought affordable illustrations to the public for the first time, and the book formed in effect the first [[field guide]] to birds,<ref name=Uglow>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2006/oct/14/art.biography | agency=[[The Guardian]] | title=Small wonders | date=14 October 2006 | accessdate=12 January 2013 | author=Uglow, Jenny |authorlink=Jenny Uglow}}</ref><ref name="Newcastle">{{cite web|title=1st December – The Partridge|url=https://blogs.ncl.ac.uk/speccoll/tag/thomas-bewick/|publisher=Newcastle University|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> while [[John James Audubon]]'s enormous<ref>The first [[Book size|double elephant folio]] edition was 39.5 inches high by 28.5 inches wide. {{cite web |url=http://minniesland.com/prints/audubon_folio_birds_havell.htm |title=Prints: Audubon's Folio Birds Havell Edition (1827-1838) |publisher=minniesland.com |accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref> and impressive images of birds in his 1827–1838 ''[[Birds of America (book)|Birds of America]]'' are among the most admired by art critics<ref>{{cite news |last1=Smart |first1=Alastair |title=The best birds in art |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-features/10816680/The-best-birds-in-art.html |accessdate=22 April 2016 |agency=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=23 May 2014}}</ref> and by collectors: early editions fetch among the highest prices paid for any printed books.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2010/12/books | work=The Economist | title=Book value | date=8 December 2010}}</ref> The ornithologist [[John Gould]]'s bird illustrations, in books such as ''A Century of Birds hitherto unfigured from the Himalaya Mountains'' (1830–1833) with 80 plates, and his 7-volume ''The Birds of Australia'' (1840–1848) with 600 plates, related directly to his research, were both beautiful and scientifically useful.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Karen S.|title=John Gould: Bird Illustration in the Age of Darwin|url=https://exhibits.lib.ku.edu/exhibits/show/gould/about/kucollections|publisher=University of Kansas Gould Collections|date=September 2013}}</ref>
Birds are popular characters in children's books, which are often handsomely illustrated. [[Beatrix Potter]]'s 1908 ''[[The Tale of Jemima Puddle-duck]]'' created an enduringly popular bird heroine.<ref>{{cite book |author=Taylor, Judy |year=1996 |origyear=1986 |title=Beatrix Potter: Artist, Storyteller and Countrywoman |publisher=Frederick Warne |isbn=0-7232-4175-9 |page=136}}</ref> Other authors followed with many bird characters in books for children of different ages.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lewis |first1=Gill |title=Gill Lewis's top 10 birds in books |url=https://www.theguardian.com/childrens-books-site/2014/jul/31/top-ten-birds-childrens-books-gill-lewis |work=The Guardian |date=31 July 2014}}</ref>
In books for adults, birds may have symbolic or psychological significance. For instance, [[Paul Gallico]]'s 1940 ''[[The Snow Goose: A Story of Dunkirk]]'' was a parable about the regenerative power of friendship in wartime; the goose symbolises both the hero, Rhayader, a wounded artist, and the world wounded by war.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/dec/19/winter-reads-snow-goose-paul-gallico |author=Allardice, Lisa |title=Winter reads: The Snow Goose by Paul Gallico |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 December 2011}}</ref> [[T. H. White]]'s 1951 ''The Goshawk'' describes the author's "monstrous and often cruel battles" to train his bird of prey, while [[Helen Macdonald (writer)|Helen Macdonald]]'s 2014 ''[[H is for Hawk]]'', which references White's book, tells how her obsession with the same species as a falconer helped her through the loss of her father.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cooke |first1=Rachel |title=H is for Hawk review – Helen Macdonald's taming of a goshawk called Mabel reads like a thriller |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/aug/04/h-is-for-hawk-review-helen-macdonald-taming-goshawk-mabel |work=The Guardian |date=4 August 2014}}</ref>
====Music==== {{main|Birds in music}} [[File:Léon Bakst 001.jpg|thumb|upright|Ballerina in ''[[The Firebird]]'' by [[Léon Bakst]], 1910]]
[[Birds in music|In music]], [[birdsong]] has influenced composers and musicians in several ways: they can be inspired by birdsong; they can intentionally imitate bird song in a composition, as [[Antonio Vivaldi|Vivaldi]] and [[Beethoven]] did, along with many later composers; they can incorporate recordings of birds into their works, first seen in the work of [[Ottorino Respighi]]; or as [[Beatrice Harrison]] did in 1924 with a [[nightingale]], and [[David Rothenberg]] did in 2000 with a [[laughingthrush]], they can duet with birds.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Head, Matthew |title=Birdsong and the Origins of Music |journal=Journal of the Royal Musical Association |volume=122 |issue=1 |year=1997 |pages=1–23 |doi=10.1093/jrma/122.1.1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Clark, Suzannah |year=2001 |title=Music Theory and Natural Order from the Renaissance to the Early Twentieth Century |journal=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-521-77191-9}}</ref><ref name=ledger>{{cite news |last=Reich |first=Ronni |title=NJIT professor finds nothing cuckoo in serenading our feathered friends |url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2010/10/njit_professor_finds_nothing_c.html |accessdate=19 June 2011 |newspaper=Star Ledger |date=15 October 2010}}</ref>
At least two groups of scientists, namely Luis Felipe Baptista and Robin A. Keister in 2005, and Adam Tierney and colleagues in 2011, have argued that [[birdsong]] has a similar structure to music. Baptista and Keister argue that the way birds use variations of [[rhythm]], relationships of [[musical pitch]], and combinations of [[musical note|note]]s is somewhat musical, perhaps because some birds exploit variation in song to avoid monotony, or [[mimicry|mimic]] other species.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Baptista |first1=Luis Felipe |last2=Keister |first2=Robin A. |title=Why Birdsong is Sometimes Like Music |journal=Perspectives in Biology and Medicine |date=2005 |volume=48 |issue=3 |pages=426–443 |doi=10.1353/pbm.2005.0066 |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/185549}}</ref> Tierney argues that the similar motor constraints on human and avian song drive these to have similar song structures, including "arch-shaped and descending melodic contours in musical phrases", long notes at the ends of phrases, and typically small differences in pitch between adjacent notes.<ref name=Tierney>{{cite journal |last1=Tierney |first1=Adam T. |last2=Russo |first2=Frank A. |last3=Patel |first3=Aniruddh D. |title=The motor origins of human and avian song structure |journal=PNAS |date=2011 |volume=108 |issue=37 |pages=15510–15515 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1103882108 |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/37/15510.full.pdf |pmid=21876156 |pmc=3174665}}</ref>
====Dance==== [[File:17 Years of Sekar Jepun 2014-11-01 42 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|A dancer of the [[Bali]]nese Sekar Jepun troupe performing the [[Cendrawasih (dance)|cendrawasih]] ([[bird-of-paradise]]) dance]]
Birds feature as central characters in [[dance]] traditions around the world. For example, [[Goldie's bird of paradise]] is celebrated in Papua New Guinea in a "beautiful"<ref name=LeCroy>{{cite journal |last1=LeCroy |first1=Mary |last2=Kulupi |first2=Alfred |last3=Peckover |first3=W. S. |title=Goldie's Bird of Paradise: Display, Natural History and Traditional Relationships of People to the Bird |journal=The Wilson Bulletin|date=September 1980 |volume=92 |issue=3 |pages=289–301 |url=https://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/wilson/v092n03/p0289-p0301.pdf}}</ref> dance by two men who dress in grass skirts with the bird's plumes on the rump; they carry [[cassowary]] feathers in their hands and on their armbands, and imitate the bird's calls while they dance. It is performed on important occasions, carrying "special magic",<ref name=LeCroy/> and the performers are obliged to prepare for a week, avoiding certain foods, and undergoing a prolonged submergence in a cold stream to prepare their minds. The dance is preceded by a "magic chant" to the bird of paradise.<ref name=LeCroy/> In [[Balinese dance]], the [[Cendrawasih (dance)|cendrawasih]] dance illustrates the [[bird-of-paradise]]'s mating rituals.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Tari Cendrawasih Keelokan Gerak dan Busana |trans-title=Cendrawasih Dance: The Beauty of Costume and Movement |language=Indonesian |work=Pikiran Rakyat |url=http://www.pikiran-rakyat.com/node/269737 |date=12 February 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TtXit61n?url=http://www.pikiran-rakyat.com/node/269737 |archivedate=7 November 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
In Africa, the [[Ewe people]] of Ghana, who were said to have been guided from Dahomey to Ghana by a bird, incorporate the flapping of the bird's wings in dances such as ''Agbadza'', ''Atsiagbekor'', and ''Gakpa''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Welsh-Asante |first=Kariamu |title=African Dance: An Artistic, Historical, and Philosophical Inquiry |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nnsWhJGkXo8C&pg=PA14 |year=1996 |publisher=Africa World Press |isbn=978-0-86543-197-3 |page=14}}</ref>
In [[ballet]], [[Tchaikovsky]]'s classical 1895 ''[[Swan Lake]]'' and [[Igor Stravinsky]]'s 1910 ''[[The Firebird]]'' have central bird characters.<ref>Wiley, Roland John. ''Tchaikovsky's Ballets: Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, Nutcracker''. Oxford University Press 1985.</ref>
====The dramatic arts==== [[File:Alabastron (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ancient Greek]] bird: an [[alabastron]], 600 BC]]
In [[theatre]], [[Aristophanes]]'s 414 BC [[Greek comedy|comedy]] ''[[The Birds (play)|The Birds]]'' ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: {{lang|grc|Ὄρνιθες}} ''Ornithes'') is an acclaimed fantasy with effective mimicry of birds. The play's chorus consists of characters playing many identifiable species, including the [[kingfisher]], [[Streptopelia|turtledove]], and [[Eurasian sparrowhawk|sparrowhawk]]; birds feature as messengers and dancers, and several Athenians are compared to specific birds.<ref>''Aristophanes: The Birds and Other Plays''. Barrett, D.; Sommerstein, A. Penguin Classics, 1978, page 149</ref><ref>''Greek Drama''. [[Peter Levi|Levi, Peter]] in 'The Oxford History of the Classical World'. Boardman, J.; Griffin, J.; Murray, O. (eds), Oxford University Press, 1986, page 178</ref>
In [[film]], birds can feature as the major driving force in a story, as in [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s acclaimed 1963 ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]''. Loosely based on [[Daphne du Maurier]]'s [[The Birds (story)|story of the same name]], it tells the tale of sudden attacks on people by violent flocks of birds.<ref>{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=David |authorlink=David Thomson (film critic) |title='Have You Seen…?' A Personal introduction to 1,000 Films |year=2008 |publisher=Knopf |isbn=978-0-375-71134-3 |page=97}}</ref> A bird plays the role of an outlet for a person's feelings in [[Ken Loach]]'s much admired<ref name=BFI/> 1969 ''[[Kes (film)|Kes]]''. The film is based on [[Barry Hines]]'s 1968 novel ''[[A Kestrel for a Knave]]'', and tells the story of a young boy who [[Bildungsroman|comes of age]] by training a [[kestrel]] that he has taken from the nest.<ref name=BFI>{{cite web |title=Kes (1969) |url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b6adf17e2 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref>
Birds feature also in the mass media with iconic [[animated cartoon]] characters such as [[Walt Disney]]'s [[Donald Duck]],<ref>{{cite book | last=Blitz | first=Marcia | title=Donald Duck | year=1979 | publisher=[[Harmony Books]] | isbn=0-517-52961-0}}</ref> [[Warner Bros.]]'s [[Tweety Pie]],<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hartl |first1=John |title=Warner Bros. cartoons get respect, with Museum of History & Industry show |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/movies/warner-bros-cartoons-get-respect-with-museum-of-history-industry-show/ |work=The Seattle Times |date=21 February 2009}}</ref> and [[Walter Lantz]]'s [[Woody Woodpecker]]. The species involved are not always discernible, though Woody has been claimed to be based on the [[acorn woodpecker|acorn]] or [[pileated woodpecker]]s.<ref>{{cite web |last=Zickefoose |first=Julie |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=101665227 |title=Woody The Acorn (Not Pileated) Woodpecker |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=10 March 2009}}</ref>
==Conservation== {{main|Bird conservation}} {{see|Late Quaternary prehistoric birds|List of extinct birds|Raptor conservation}} [[File:California-Condor3-Szmurlo edit.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The [[California condor]] once numbered only 22 birds, but conservation measures have raised that to over 300 today.]]
Though human activities have allowed the expansion of a few species, such as the [[barn swallow]] and [[European starling]], they have caused population decreases or [[extinction]] in many other species. Over a hundred bird species have gone extinct in historical times, including the [[dodo]] and the [[great auk]],<ref>{{cite book |author=Fuller, Errol |authorlink=Errol Fuller |date=2000 |title=Extinct Birds |edition=2nd |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=0-19-850837-9}}</ref> although the most dramatic human-caused avian extinctions, eradicating an estimated 750–1800 species, occurred during the human colonisation of [[Melanesia]]n, [[Polynesia]]n, and [[Micronesia]]n islands.<ref>{{cite book |author=Steadman, D. |date=2006 |title=Extinction and Biogeography in Tropical Pacific Birds |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-77142-7}}</ref> Many bird populations are declining worldwide, with 1,227 species listed as [[threatened species|threatened]] by [[BirdLife International]] and the [[IUCN]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=BirdLife International announces more Critically Endangered birds than ever before |publisher=[[BirdLife International]] |date=14 May 2009 |url=http://www.birdlife.org/news/pr/2009/05/red_list.html |accessdate=15 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8045971.stm |first=Mark |last=Kinver |title=Birds at risk reach record high |publisher=BBC News Online |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009}}</ref>
The most commonly cited human threat to birds is [[Habitat destruction|habitat loss]].<ref>{{cite book |editor1=Norris, K.|editor2=Pain, D. |date=2002 |title=Conserving Bird Biodiversity: General Principles and their Application |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-78949-3}}</ref> Other threats include overhunting; accidental mortality due to collisions with [[bird-skyscraper collisions|buildings]] and [[bird strike|vehicles]]; [[long-line fishing]] [[bycatch]];<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1016/0006-3207(91)90031-4 | last1=Brothers | first1=N. P. | year=1991 | title=Albatross mortality and associated bait loss in the Japanese longline fishery in the southern ocean | journal=Biological Conservation | volume=55 | issue=3 | pages=255–268 }}</ref> pollution (including [[oil spill]]s and pesticide use),<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Wurster | first1=D. | last2=Wurster | first2=C. | last3=Strickland | first3=W. | date=July 1965 | title=Bird Mortality Following DDT Spray for Dutch Elm Disease | journal=Ecology | volume=46 | issue=4| pages=488–499 | doi =10.2307/1934880 }}; {{cite journal | doi=10.1126/science.148.3666.90 | title=Bird Mortality after Spraying for Dutch Elm Disease with DDT | year=1965 | last1=Wurster | first1=C. F. | last2=Wurster | first2=D. H. | last3=Strickland | first3=W. N. | journal=Science | volume=148 | issue=3666 | pages=90–91 | pmid=14258730 }}</ref> competition; predation; [[bird hybrid|hybridisation]] from nonnative introduced or [[invasive species]];<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Blackburn | first1=T. | last2=Cassey | first2=P. | last3=Duncan | first3=R. | last4=Evans | first4=K. | last5=Gaston | first5=K. | date=24 September 2004 | title=Avian Extinction and Mammalian Introductions on Oceanic Islands | journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume=305 | issue=5692| pages=1955–58 | doi=10.1126/science.1101617 | pmid=15448269}}</ref> and climate change.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Moller |first1=Anders P. |last2=Fiedler |first2=W. |last3=Berthold |first3=P. |title=Effects of Climate Change on Birds |date=2010 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-199-56975-5}}</ref> The collection of specimens for [[taxidermy]] and [[egg collection|eggs]] from the wild has at times had a serious effect on some species. It is now forbidden in many countries, such as by the British [[Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Wild birds and the law: Egg Collecting|url=https://www.rspb.org.uk/our-work/our-positions-and-campaigns/positions/wildbirdslaw/wildbirdcrime/egg_collection.aspx|publisher=RSPB|date=26 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=BirdLife Partnership|title=REVIEW OF THE ILLEGAL KILLING AND TRAPPING OF BIRDS IN EUROPE|url=https://wcd.coe.int/com.instranet.InstraServlet?command=com.instranet.CmdBlobGet&InstranetImage=1959997&SecMode=1&DocId=1762044&Usage=2|publisher=Council of Europe|accessdate=28 June 2017|ref=T-PVS/Inf (2011) 13|date=July 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Demoiselle cranes flying past wind turbines, Gujarat.jpg|thumb|[[Demoiselle crane]]s flying past [[wind turbine]]s, [[Gujarat]]]]
Effects are not all negative; for example, [[wind farm]]s produce [[renewable energy]], helping to mitigate the single greatest threat to birds, climate change. But, especially if wind farms are poorly sited, they may affect bird populations through disturbance, direct or indirect habitat loss, and collisions. Well sited wind farms benefit birds; poorly sited ones can [[Bird migration perils|kill many birds]] in collisions.<ref name=RSPBwindfarms/> For example, at the [[Altamont Pass Wind Farm|Altamont Pass]] in California, the [[golden eagle]] has been reduced by 80%, and nesting has ceased in the area.<ref>{{cite news |title=DRIESSEN: Big Wind tax credit exterminates endangered species |author=Paul Driessen |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/dec/22/big-wind-tax-credit-exterminates-endangered-specie/ |newspaper=[[Washington Times]] |date=22 December 2012 |quote=In an 86-square-mile area blanketed by the Altamont wind facility, no eagles have nested for more than 20 years even though the area is prime habitat, Mr. Wiegand says. Overall, there has been an 80 percent population decline for the golden eagle in Southern California, he notes. }}</ref> Thus, there is a [[trade-off]] in the siting of any wind farm.<ref name=RSPBwindfarms>{{cite web |title=Wind Farms |url=https://www.rspb.org.uk/our-work/our-positions-and-campaigns/positions/windfarms/ |publisher=[[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] |accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
Governments and [[conservation biology|conservation]] groups work to protect birds, either by passing laws that [[In-situ conservation|preserve]] and [[ecological restoration|restore]] bird habitat, or by establishing [[Ex-situ conservation|captive populations]] for reintroductions. Such projects have produced some successes; one study estimated that conservation efforts saved 16 species of bird that would otherwise have gone extinct between 1994 and 2004, including the [[California condor]] and [[Norfolk parakeet]].<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1017/S0030605306000950 | last1=Butchart | first1=S. | last2=Stattersfield | first2=A. | last3=Collar | first3=N. | year=2006 | title=How many bird extinctions have we prevented? | url=http://www.birdlife.org/news/news/2006/08/butchart_et_al_2006.pdf | journal=Oryx | volume=40 | issue=3| pages=266–279 }}</ref> The British [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]], founded as the Plumage League in 1889 to protect birds such as the [[egret]] from hunting for their plumes, used in fashion, has grown to have over a million members; it has been followed by similar societies in other countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rspb.org.uk/about/history/index.asp |title=History of the RSPB |publisher=[[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] |accessdate=19 February 2007}}</ref> A more specialised organisation, the [[Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust]] founded in 1946, works to conserve waterfowl and their [[wetland]] habitats, with projects around the world.<ref>{{cite web |title=Our projects |url=https://www.wwt.org.uk/conservation/wwt-projects/ |publisher=[[Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust]] |accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
==References==
