{{redirect|Tsū||TSU (disambiguation)}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} '''''Iki''''' (いき, English: roughly "chic, stylish") is a concept in aesthetics, the basis of which is thought to have formed among urbane commoners ([[chōnin]]) in [[Edo]] in the [[Edo period|Tokugawa period]].<ref name="nussbaum379">Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "''Iki''{{-"}} in {{Google books|p2QnPijAEmEC|''Japan Encyclopedia'', p. 379|page=379}}; n.b., Louis-Frédéric is pseudonym of Louis-Frédéric Nussbaum, ''see'' [http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 Deutsche Nationalbibliothek Authority File] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120524174828/http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 |date=2012-05-24 }}.</ref> ''Iki'' is sometimes misunderstood as simply "[[Cool Japan|anything Japanese]]" overseas, but it is actually a specific aesthetic ideal, distinct from more ethereal notions of transcendence or poverty. As such, [[samurai]], for example, would typically, as a class, be considered devoid of ''iki'' (see ''[[yabo]]''). At the same time, individual warriors are often depicted in contemporary popular imagination as embodying the ''iki'' ideals of a clear, stylish manner and blunt, unwavering directness. The term became widespread in modern intellectual circles through the book ''[[The Structure of Iki]]'' (1930) by [[Kuki Shūzō]].
==Interpretation== ''Iki'', having emerged from the worldly [[Japanese merchant class]], may appear in some ways a more contemporary expression of Japanese aesthetics than concepts such as ''[[wabi-sabi]]''. The term is commonly used in conversation and writing, but is not necessarily exclusive of other categories of beauty.
''Iki'' is an expression of simplicity, sophistication, spontaneity, and originality. It is ephemeral, romantic, straightforward, measured, audacious, smart, and lacking in detrimental self-consciousness.
''Iki'' is not overly refined, pretentious, complicated, showy, slick, coquettish, or, generally, [[Kawaii|cute]]. At the same time, ''iki'' may exhibit any of those traits in a smart, direct, and unabashed manner.
''Iki'' may signify a personal trait, or artificial phenomena exhibiting human will or consciousness. ''Iki'' is not used to describe natural phenomena, but may be expressed in human appreciation of natural beauty, or in the nature of human beings. [[Murakami Haruki]] (b. 1949), who writes in a clear, unflinching style—at turns sentimental, fantastic, and surreal—is described as embodying ''iki''. In contrast, [[Kawabata Yasunari]] (1899-1972) writes in a more poetic vein, with a closer focus on the interior "complex" of his characters, while situations and surroundings exhibit a kind of ''[[wabi-sabi]]''. That said, stylistic differences may tend to distract from a similar emotional subjectivity. Indeed, ''iki'' is strongly tied to stylistic tendencies.
==''Tsū''== The indefinite ideal of '''tsū''' (通) can be said to reference a highly cultivated but not necessarily solemn sensibility. The ''iki''/''tsu'' sensibility resists being construed within the context of overly specific rules about what could be considered as vulgar or uncouth.<ref>Gallaher, John. ''Geisha: A Unique World of Tradition, Elegance, and Art.'' p. 8.</ref>
''Iki'' and ''tsu'' are considered synonymous in some situations, but ''tsu'' exclusively refers to persons, while ''iki'' can also refer to situations/objects. In both ideals, the property of refinement is not academic in nature. ''Tsu'' sometimes involves excessive obsession and cultural (but not academic) pedantry, and in this case, it differs from ''iki'', which will not be obsessive. ''Tsu'' is used, for example, for knowing how to properly appreciate (eat) Japanese cuisines ([[sushi]], [[tempura]], [[soba]] etc.). ''Tsu'' (and some ''iki''-style) can be transferred from person to person in form of "tips." As ''tsu'' is more focused in knowledge, it may be considered superficial from ''iki'' point of view, since ''iki'' cannot be easily attained by learning.
==''Yabo''== {{main|Yabo}}
''[[Yabo]]'' (野暮) is the antonym of ''iki''. ''Busui'' (無粋), literally "non-''iki''," is synonymous to ''yabo''.
==''Sui''== In the [[Kamigata]] or [[Kansai]] area, the ideal of ''sui'' is prevalent. ''Sui'' is also represented by the [[kanji]] "粋". The sense of ''sui'' is similar to ''iki'' but not identical, reflecting various regional differences.<ref name="nussbaum379"/> The contexts of their usages are also different.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Gallagher, John. (2003). ''Geisha: A Unique World of Tradition, Elegance, and Art''. New York: [[Sterling Publishing]]. {{ISBN|1-85648-697-4}} * [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger, Martin]]. (1982). "A Dialogue on Language: between a Japanese and an Inquirer." ''On The Way to Language''. San Francisco: [[Harper & Row]]. {{ISBN|0-06-063859-1}} (paper) * Nara, Hiroshi. (2004). ''The Structure of Detachment: the Aesthetic Vision of Kuki Shūzō with a translation of "Iki no kōzō."'' Honolulu: [[University of Hawaii Press]]. {{ISBN|9780824827359}}; {{ISBN|9780824828059}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/structure-of-detachment-the-aesthetic-vision-of-kuki-shuuzoo-with-a-translation-of-iki-no-kozo/oclc/644791079&referer=brief_results OCLC 644791079] * Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&client=firefox-a ''Japan encyclopedia.''] Cambridge: [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-674-01753-5}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/58053128?referer=di&ht=edition OCLC 58053128] * Pincus, Leslie. (1996). ''Authenticating Culture in Imperial Japan: [[Kuki Shūzō]] and the Rise of National Aesthetics.'' Berkeley: [[University of California Press]]. {{ISBN|0-520-20134-5}} (paper) * Seigle, Cecila Segawa. (1993). ''Yoshiwara: The Glittering World of the Japanese Courtesan.'' Honolulu: University of Hawai'i Press. {{ISBN|0-8248-1488-6}} (paper) * Botz-Bornstein, Thorsten. (1997) 'Iki, Style, Trace: Shuzo Kuki and the Spirit of Hermeneutics' in ''Philosophy East and West'' Vol. 47, Nr. 4, October 1997, p. 554-580.
==External links== * {{en icon}} {{ja icon}} [http://cosmoshouse.com/works/papers/index-e.htm "An Aesthetics of Everyday Life: Modernism and a Japanese popular aesthetic ideal, Iki"] -(A modern approach towards ''iki'') * {{ja icon}} [http://www.aozora.gr.jp/cards/000065/files/393_1765.html 九鬼周造『「いき」の構造』] -(A classic theory of ''iki'')

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2600:6C51:747F:BC35:0:76A3:EE7C:F9A2|2600:6C51:747F:BC35:0:76A3:EE7C:F9A2]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = International Thespian Society | image = InternationalThespianSociety.png | image_border = | size = | caption = | map = | msize = | mcaption = | abbreviation = ITS | formation = 1929 | extinction = | type = NGO | status = | purpose = Dramatic Arts | headquarters = [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]] | location = | region_served = International | membership = | language = [[American English]] | leader_title = | leader_name = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[Educational Theatre Association]] | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|schooltheatre.org/society}} | remarks = | motto = "Act well your part; there all the honor lies." }} The '''International Thespian Society''' (ITS) is an honor society for [[high school]] and [[middle school]] theatre students. It is a division of the [[Educational Theatre Association]]. Thespian troupes serve students in grades 9-12; Junior Thespian troupes serve students in grades 6 through 8. A few famous ITS alumni include [[Tom Hanks]], [[Val Kilmer]], [[James Marsters]], [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]], and [[Stephen Schwartz (composer)|Stephen Schwartz]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooltheatre.org/membership/distinguishedthespians|title=Distinguished Thespians - EdTA - Educational Theatre Association|website=www.schooltheatre.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}} Festivals are held annually at the district, state and national levels. Each June the [[International Thespian Festival]] is held at the [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|University of Nebraska-Lincoln]]. Membership currently stands at approximately 100,000 student members across 4,700 schools. The one millionth Thespian was inducted in 1976 and the two millionth Thespian was inducted in 2009. As of 2017, there have been over 2.3 million Thespians inducted. == History == The International Thespian Society was founded in 1929 in [[Fairmont, West Virginia]]. Originally named National Thespians, the society was founded by Dr. Paul Opp, Earnest Bavely and Harry Leaper. National Thespians was an honorary organization for high school theater students who earned membership through participation in their schools' theatre programs. The organization consisted of troupes, each linked to a school. The first troupe was formed by Dr. Earl Blank at Natrona County High School in Casper, Wyoming. At the end of the 1928-1929 school year there were 71 troupes across 26 states. In October, 1929, the first issue of The High School Thespian, "official organ of National Thespians" was published. The National Thespian headquarters was moved to Cincinnati during the year 1935. That same year, the society was renamed The National Thespian Dramatic Honor Society. The society held its first National High School Drama Conference and Play Production Festival in 1941 at Indiana University, which later became a bi-annual event. The ''High School Thespian'' became ''Dramatics'' in 1944. In October 1945, The National Thespian Dramatic Honor Society was again renamed the National Thespian Society. As the Thespian Society reached its 25th anniversary in 1954, 1,432 Thespian troupes existed across forty-eight states and the then-territories of Alaska, Hawaii, and the Canal Zone, as well as Canada and Japan. In 1969 the organization's name was changed to the title it still holds today: The International Thespian Society. June 1982 marked a name change for the National High School Drama Conference and Play Production Festival, turning it into the Thespian Festival, as it is still called today. The Thespian Festival also began an annual schedule for the first time. The Society offered its first set of summertime retreats for high school theatre directors in 1986, an activity that would eventually grow into a professional association called the Theatre Education Association. In 1989 the ITS board established the Educational Theatre Association (EdTA), meant to oversee both the Thespian Society and the Theatre Education Association, and launched ''Teaching Theatre,'' a quarterly journal for theatre educators. The Theatre Education Association was eventually absorbed completely into the EdTA and thus its title is no longer used. 1990 marks the birth of the Junior Thespians branch of ITS, extending the reach of the society to middle school theatre students. The EdTA helped to write the theatre section of the National Standards for Arts Education, the first set of guidelines for the arts education field, in 1994. By 2012, International Thespian Society had formed a strong bond with the charity organization [[Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS]] and raised more than $1 million for their benefit. 2015 marked the EdTA's launch of [https://www.schooltheatre.org/programs/jumpstarttheatre JumpStart Theatre], which brings sustainable musical theatre programs to underserved middle schools where there currently are none, and the creation of an ITS branch in China.{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooltheatre.org/about/history|title=History - EdTA - Educational Theatre Association|website=www.schooltheatre.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}} == Thespian Chapters == Chapters are created in order to support the mission of the International Thespian Society. They are led by a chapter director who is supported and assisted by a chapter board. As of 2017, there are active chapters in the following states, regions, and countries:{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooltheatre.org/membership/chapters|title=Chapters - EdTA - Educational Theatre Association|website=www.schooltheatre.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}} Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, Ohio, North Carolina, South Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Florida, Louisiana, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Nevada, California, Hawaii, the Western Pacific Islands, and China. == Thespian Induction and Promotion == The International Thespian Society allows for the induction of high school and middle school students attending ITS affiliated schools, based on the quality and quantity of work in all realms of theatre. Points can be earned from participation in productions (either on stage or backstage), Thespian Festivals, seeing other theatre's productions, and holding an officer position in a Thespian troupe.{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooltheatre.org/internationalthespiansociety/troupedirectors/thespianpointsystem|title=Official Thespian point system - International Thespian Society|website=www.schooltheatre.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}} Induction ceremonies vary from troupe to troupe, but most are run by the troupe's officers and director. They include, at the very least, a brief summation of the Society's history, followed by a listing of the names and achievements of each new inductee, and then a reciting of the Society's pledge by all new and existing members. The pledge is as follows:
"''I promise to uphold the aims and ideals of the International Thespian Society. I am a student of theatre and excellence is my ideal. I promise to perform my part as well as I can; to accept praise and criticism with grace; to cooperate with my fellow thespians and work for the good of the troupe; and to share my love of theatre."''{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooltheatre.org/internationalthespiansociety/troupedirectors/troupehandbook#5c|title=Thespian troupe handbook - International Thespian Society|website=www.schooltheatre.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}}
After induction, members can continue to earn points in order to move up through the International Thespian Society ranking system. ==Student Leadership== At the high school level there are various offices possible, including, but not limited to, President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and Historian. There are also state and international student leaders elected annually by their respective student bodies. The International Thespian Officers are student members elected to represent the student membership. They suggest policy and service changes to the Educational Theatre Association Board, and take an active role in training, chapter conferences, and the annual International Thespian Festival. There are also State Thespian Officers, elected to manage such events as State Thespian Festivals and local Junior Thespian Festivals. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://broadwaycares.org/ Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS] * [http://www.edta.org EdTA/ITS official website] * [https://www.schooltheatre.org/programs/jumpstarttheatre JumpStart Theatre] * [https://www.schooltheatre.org/internationalthespiansociety/jrtroupedirectors Junior International Thespian Society] * [https://cv.schooltheatre.org/cgi-bin/utilities.dll/openpage?wrp=troupeSearch_public.htm&wmt=main_template_login.htm Troupes List] [[Category:High school honor societies]] [[Category:Student theatre]] [[Category:Theatrical organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Theatrical organizations in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{redirect|Matejko|people with surname Matejko|Matejko (surname)}} {{good article}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Jan Matejko | image = Jan Matejko.JPG | imagesize = | caption = Jan Matejko, before 1883 | birth_name = Jan Mateyko | birth_date = 24 June 1838 | birth_place = [[Free City of Kraków]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1893|11|1|1838|6|24}} | death_place = [[Kraków]], [[Austria–Hungary]] | nationality = [[Poland|Polish]] | field = [[Painting]], [[drawing]] | training = [[Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts|School of Fine Arts, Kraków]] | movement = [[History painting]] | works = ''[[Battle of Grunwald (Matejko)|Battle of Grunwald]]''
''[[Stańczyk (painting)|Stańczyk]]''
''[[Prussian Homage (painting)|The Prussian Homage]]'' | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Jan Alojzy Matejko''' ({{IPA-pol|jan aˈlɔjzɨ maˈtɛjko|-|Pl-Jan Matejko.ogg}}; also known as '''Jan Mateyko'''; 24 June 1838{{refn|group=nb|While the date of 24 June is most commonly given, some recent biographers of Matejko note that there are reliable documents for two other dates: 28 and 30 July.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|pages=7–8}}}} – 1 November 1893) was a [[Poles|Polish]] [[painting|painter]] known for paintings of notable historical Polish political and military events. His works include large [[oil on canvas]] paintings like ''[[Rejtan (painting)|Rejtan]]'' (1866), ''[[Unia lubelska (painting)|Union of Lublin]]'' (1869) or ''[[Battle of Grunwald (painting)|Battle of Grunwald]]'' (1878), numerous portraits, a gallery of [[List of Polish monarchs|Polish kings]], and [[mural]]s in [[St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków]]. He is referred to as the most famous [[Polish painters|Polish painter]] or even the "national painter" of Poland.{{cite book|author=William Fiddian Reddaway|title=The Cambridge History of Poland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=As43AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA547|year=1971|publisher=CUP Archive|page=547|id=GGKEY:2G7C1LPZ3RN}} Matejko spent most of his life in [[Kraków]]. His teachers at the [[Kraków Academy of Fine Arts]] included [[Wojciech Korneli Stattler]] and [[Władysław Łuszczkiewicz]]. Later, he became a director at this institution, which eventually was renamed the Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts. A number of his students became prominent painters themselves, including [[Maurycy Gottlieb]], [[Jacek Malczewski]], [[Józef Mehoffer]] and [[Stanisław Wyspiański]].{{CN|date=October 2017}} ==Biography== ===Youth=== Matejko was born on 24 June 1838, in the [[Free City of Kraków]]. His father, [[Franciszek Ksawery Matejko]] ({{lang-cs|František Xaver Matějka}}) (born 1789 or 13 January 1793, died 26 October 1860), a Czech from the village of [[Roudnice]], was a graduate of the [[Hradec Králové]] school who later became a tutor and [[music teacher]]. He first worked for the Wodzicki family in Kościelniki, Poland, then moved to [[Kraków]], where he married the half-German, half-Polish Joanna Karolina Rossberg (Rozberg). Jan was the ninth child of eleven children.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=12}} He grew up in a [[kamienica (architecture)|kamienica]] building on [[Floriańska Street]].{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=11}} After the death of his mother in 1845, Jan and his siblings were cared for by his maternal aunt, Anna Zamojska. [[File:Rodzeństwo Matejki.jpeg|thumb|upright|left|Portrait of Matejko's father, Franciszek, and three of his children. An early work of Matejko from 1853]] At a young age he witnessed the [[Kraków Uprising|Kraków revolution]] of 1846 and the 1848 [[siege of Kraków]] by the Austrians, the two events which ended the existence of the [[Free City of Kraków]]. His two older brothers served in these battles, under General [[Józef Bem]]; one died and the other was forced into exile. Matejko attended [[Bartłomiej Nowodworski High School|St. Ann's High School]], but he dropped out in 1851 because of poor grades. From his earliest days Matejko showed artistic talent, but had great difficulty with other academic areas.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|pages=18, 22–23}} He never mastered a foreign language.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=18}} Despite that, and because of his exceptional skill, he studied at the [[School of Fine Arts in Kraków]] from 1852 to 1858. His teachers included [[Wojciech Korneli Stattler]] and [[Władysław Łuszczkiewicz]].{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=25}} He selected [[historical painting]] as his specialization, and finished his first major work, ''Tsars Shuyski before Zygmunt III'' (''Carowie Szujscy przed Zygmuntem III''), in 1853 (he would return to this topic in a year before his death, in 1892{{cite book|author1=Jan Matejko|author2=Jerzy Malinowski|author3=Krystyna Sroczyńska|author4=Jurij Birjułow|title=Matejko: Album|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O8suAQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Arkady|language=Polish|quote=Matejko malował nadto dwukrotnie sceny hołdu carów Szujskich przed Zygmuntem III w 1853 i 1892 roku."}} [Google Books does not display page number for this book]). During this time, he began exhibiting historical paintings at the [[Kraków Society of Friends of Fine Arts]] (starting with 1855).Bochnak (1975), p. 185 His seminal project for his graduation in 1858 was ''[[Sigismund I the Old]] ennobles the professors of the [[Jagiellonian University]]'' (''Zygmunt I nadaje szlachectwo profesorom Uniwersytetu Jagiellońskiego'').{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=39}} After graduation, Matejko received a scholarship in 1859 to study with [[Hermann Anschütz]] at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Munich]]. The following year he received a scholarship to study at the [[Academy of Fine Arts Vienna]] as well, but after a few days and a major quarrel with [[Christian Ruben]], Matejko returned to Kraków. and opened a studio at his family home in Floriańska Street. It would however be years before he would gain commercial success; for a time he was the proverbial "starving artist", who celebrated when he sold a canvas (the ''Tsars Shuyski...'') for five [[Austro-Hungarian gulden|gulden]]. In 1860 Matejko published an illustrated album, ''[[Clothing in Poland (Matejko)|Clothing in Poland]]'' (''Ubiory w Polsce''), a project reflecting his intense interest in historical records of all kinds and his desire to promote such interest among Polish people, to intensify their patriotism. His financial situation improved when he sold two paintings, ''Death of Wapowski during the crowning of Henry Valois'' (''Zabicie Wapowskiego w czasie koronacji Henryka Walezego'', 1861) and ''Jan Kochanowski mourning his daughter Urszulka'' (''Jan Kochanowski nad zwłokami Urszulki'', 1862), which settled his debts.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=78}} In 1862 he finished a painting, ''[[Stańczyk (painting)|Stańczyk]]''. Initially received without much applause, in time this would become known as one of Matejko's most famous masterpieces.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=85}} It marks a visible transition in Matejko's art style, from simply illustrating history to creating a philosophical and moral commentary of it. [[File:Matejko-Dzieci.jpg|thumbnail|Portrait of the artist's four children. A late work of Matejko from 1879]] During the [[January Uprising]] of 1863, in which he did not participate because of poor health, Matejko gave financial support, donating most of his savings to the cause, and personally [[Gunrunning|transported arms]] to the insurgents' camp.Bochnak (1975), p. 186 His ''[[Skarga's Sermon]]'' (''Kazanie Skargi''), finished in May 1864, was displayed in the gallery of the Kraków Society of Friends of Fine Arts, which gained him much publicity. On 5 November that year, in recognition for his contributions to recreating historical themes, he became a member of the [[Kraków Scientific Society]] (''Towarzystwo Naukowe Krakowskie'').{{cite book|author=Henryk Marek Słoczyński|title=Matejko|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vUVMAAAAMAAJ|year=2000|publisher=Wydawn. Dolnośląskie|isbn=978-83-7023-820-9|page=81|language=Polish}} Soon afterward, on 21 November, he married [[Teodora Matejko|Teodora Giebultowska]], with whom he would have five children: Beata, [[Helena Unierzyska|Helena]], Tadeusz, Jerzy and Regina. Helena, his daughter, also an artist, helped victims in [[World War I]] and was awarded the [[Cross of Independence]] by [[president]] [[Stanisław Wojciechowski]]. ===Rise to fame=== [[File:Matejko_Self-portrait.jpg|thumbnail|Jan Matejko, ''Self-portrait'', 1892]] [[Image:Akademia Sztuk Pięknych przy Placu Matejki.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Kraków Academy of Fine Arts]] named after Matejko in 1979, where he served as president of many years]] At that time Matejko started to gain international recognition. In 1865, Matejko's painting ''Skarga's Sermon'' was awarded a gold medal at the yearly Paris salon; soon afterwards Count {{ILL|Maurycy Potocki|pl}} bought it for 10,000 guldens. In 1867, his painting ''[[Rejtan (painting)|Rejtan]]'' was awarded a gold medal at the [[International Exposition (1867)|World Exhibition]] in Paris and acquired by Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]] for 50,000 franks.{{cite book|title=Projekt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RDAtAQAAIAAJ|year=1992|publisher=Prasa-Książka-Ruch|page=cxliii}}{{cite book|author=Jan Matejko|title=Matejko: obrazy olejne : katalog|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WMsuAQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=Arkady|isbn=978-83-213-3652-7|page=1963}} His next major painting was the ''[[Union of Lublin (painting)|Union of Lublin]]'' (''Unia Lubelska''), created in the years 1867-1869. Once again applauded in Paris, it won Matejko a Cross of the French [[Légion d'honneur]].Bochnak (1975), p. 187 and was purchased by the [[Sejm of Galicia]]. ''Union...'' was followed by ''[[Stefan Batory at Pskov]]'' (''Stefan Batory pod Pskowem''), finished in 1871. In 1872 he visited [[Istanbul]] in the [[Ottoman Empire]], and upon his return to Kraków finished ''[[Astronomer Copernicus, or Conversations with God]]'' (''Astronom Kopernik, czyli rozmowa z Bogiem''), which was acquired by the [[Jagiellonian University]]. From the 1870s he was aided in many tasks by a secretary, [[Marian Gorzkowski]], who would become his "right hand", his closest friend, a model for a number of paintings, and an author of memoirs about Matejko.{{cite book|author1=Stanisław Wyspiański|author2=Maria Rydlowa|title=Listy Stanisława Wyspiańskiego do Józefa Mehoffera, Henryka Opieńskiego i Tadeusza Stryjeńskiego|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jVphAAAAMAAJ|year=1994|publisher=Wydawnictwo Literackie|isbn=978-83-08-02562-8|page=75|language=Polish}} In 1872 during an exhibition in [[Prague]] he was offered a directorship of the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Prague]], and soon afterwards, a similar position at Kraków's School of Fine Arts. He accepted the Kraków offer, and was for many years the principal ([[Rector (academia)|rector]]) of the Academy of Fine Arts. In 1874 he finished ''[[Zawieszenie dzwonu Zygmunta]]'' (''The Hanging of the Sigismund bell''). In 1878 he finished another masterpiece, ''[[Battle of Grunwald (painting)|Battle of Grunwald]]''.Bochnak (1975), p. 188 That year he received an "honorary grand gold" medal in Paris, and the city council of Kraków presented him with a ceremonial [[scepter]], a symbol of his "royal status in fine arts". In 1879 he finished ''[[Rok 1863 - Polonia]]'' (Year 1863 - Polonia), his take on the [[January Uprising]] of that time. Begun in 1864, a year after the Uprising he himself had lived through and where he lost a number of friends and family members, this canvas languished unfinished until prince [[Władysław Czartoryski]] became interested in acquiring it; it is still considered unfinished.{{cite book|author=Stowarzyszenie Historyków Sztuki|title=Sztuka XIX wieku w Polsce|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ExXAAAAIAAJ|year=1979|publisher=Państwowe Wydawn. Naukowe|pages=31–32|language=Polish}}{{cite book|author=Mieczysław Treter|title=Matejko: osobowosc artysty, tworczosc, forma i styl|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q3RHAQAAIAAJ|year=1939|publisher=Książnica-Atlas|page=611|language=Polish}} Years 1880-1882 marked his work on another large painting, ''[[Prussian Homage (painting)|Prussian Tribute]]'' (''Hołd Pruski''). Matejko gifted this painting to "the Polish nation", and it earned him [[honorary citizenship]] of Kraków; one of the squares in the city was also named [[Matejko Square]]. In 1883 he finished ''[[Sobieski at Vienna]]'' (''Jan Sobieski pod Wiedniem''). ''Sobieski...'' was gifted to [[Pope Leo XIII]] as a "gift of the Polish nation" and Matejko, who was one of the members of the group delivering it, received a Knight Commander with Star [[Order of Pius IX]].Bochnak (1975), p. 189 The painting is exhibited in the Sobieski Room of the [[Vatican Museums]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vaticanstate.va/content/vaticanstate/en/monumenti/musei-vaticani/sala-sobieski-e-dell-immacolata.paginate.1.html|title=The Immaculate Conception and Sobieski Rooms|author=|date=|website=www.vaticanstate.va|accessdate=2 April 2018}}At that time he also became a vocal spokesman in a number of political issues, publishing letters on issues such as [[Polish-Russian relations]]. Another arena he was very engaged in were efforts to protect and reconstruct various historical monuments in the city of Kraków. In 1886, he finished a painting about French rather than about Polish history: ''[[Virgin of Orléans]]'', portraying [[Joan of Arc]].{{cite book|author1=Roxana Radvan|author2=John F. Asmus|author3=Marta Castillejo|author4=Paraskevi Pouli |author5=Austin Nevin|title=Lasers in the Conservation of Artworks VIII|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ev29OVkHLtgC&pg=PA173|date=1 December 2010|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-415-58073-1|page=173}} Next year Matejko received a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] degree, [[honoris causa]], from the [[Jagiellonian University]], and the Austrian ''[[Litteris et Artibus (Austria)|Litteris et Artibus]]''. In 1888 he finished ''[[Bitwa pod Racławicami (painting)|Battle of Racławice]]'' (''Bitwa pod Racławicami''). In 1888-1899, to justify his new academic title, he published a cycle of twelve sketches with an accompanying commentary, ''[[History of civilization in Poland]]'' (''Dzieje Cywilizacji w Polsce''). From 1890 to 1892 he published another cycle of sketches, this time of [[Polish kings]] (''[[Poczet królów i książąt polskich]]'' - ''Fellowship of the kings and princes of Poland''), which over the years became so popular that its portraits are seen as the canon portrayals of their subjects.{{cite book|author=Barbara Ciciora-Czwórnóg|title=Jan Matejko|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jZMmAQAAIAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Bosz|isbn=978-83-89747-16-7|page=14|language=Polish}} 1891 saw him finishing ''[[Constitution of the 3 May (painting)|Constitution of the 3 May]]'' (''Konstytucja 3 Maja''). He then began composing another large painting, ''[[Oaths of Jan Kazimierz]]'' (''Śluby Jana Kazimierza''), but it remained unfinished due to his death. In 1892, a year before his death, he finished a ''[[Self-portrait (Matejko)|Self-portrait]]'' (''Autoportret''). Matejko suffered from a [[peptic ulcer]], and died in Kraków on 1 November that year of internal bleeding. His funeral on 5 November drew large crowds, and his death was mentioned in at least thirty two European newspapers.{{cite book|author=Maria Szypowska|title=Jan Matejko wszystkim znany|year=2016|publisher=Fundacja Artibus-Wurlitzer oraz Wydawn. Domu Słowa Polskiego|isbn=9788377858448|language=Polish|page=428}} He was buried in the Kraków's [[Rakowicki Cemetery]].Bochnak (1975), p. 190 ==Significance, style and themes== [[File:GrobowiecJanaMatejki-CmentarzRakowicki-POL, Kraków.jpg|thumb|Matejko's tomb]]He is counted among the most famous [[Polish painters]], described as "Poland's greatest historical painter" and "a cult figure to the nation at large... [already] by the time of his death.". His style was praised for being "colourful, detailed and imaginative". He succeeded in propagating Polish history, and reminding the world about Poland, while his country remained partitioned and without any independent political representation. His works, disseminated in thousands of reproductions, have become almost standard illustrations of many key events in [[Polish history]]. His 1860 illustrated album ''Ubiory w Polsce'' (Clothing in Poland) is seen as a valuable historical reference.{{cite web|url=http://www.muzeum.krakow.pl/Wystawa.1106.0.html?&cHash=1c6a6d9bec42ba80c47995258e045fb5&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=1105&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=5274 |title=WYSTAWA: Wielka rekwizytornia artysty. Stroje i kostiumy z kolekcji Jana Matejki |trans-title=EXHIBITION: Great artistic repository. Clothes and costumes in the collection of Jan Matejko. |publisher=Muzeum Narodowe w Krakowie |date=2012 |accessdate=15 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309041508/http://www.muzeum.krakow.pl/Wystawa.1106.0.html?&cHash=1c6a6d9bec42ba80c47995258e045fb5&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=1105&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=5274 |archivedate= 9 March 2014 |df= }} Critics of his work have pointed to his use of traditional painting style ("antiquarian realism", "theatrical effects").{{cite book|author=Jerzy Jan Lerski|title=Historical Dictionary of Poland, 966-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QTUTqE2difgC&pg=PA343|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-26007-0|page=343}} At exhibitions abroad, the nuanced historical context of his works often was lost on foreign audiences. Occasionally his paintings would cause controversy; for example, ''Rejtan'' offended a number of prominent members of Polish nobility, who saw the painting as an indictment of their entire social class. His paintings were subject to censorship in the [[Russian Empire]]; and [[Nazi Germany]] planned to destroy ''Battle of Grunwald'' and ''Prussian Homage'', which Nazi authorities considered offensive to the German view of history (those paintings were among many that the Germans planned to destroy in their [[culture in Poland during World War II|war on Polish culture]], but the [[Polish resistance in World War II|Polish resistance]] successfully hid both).{{cite journal|last=Batorska|first=Danuta|title=The Political Censorship of Jan Matejko|journal=Art Journal|volume=51|issue=1|page=57|doi=10.2307/777255}} Many of his works are dedicated to famous events in Polish history. Matejko was focusing on major themes in Polish history and using historical sources to paint events in minute historical detail.{{cite book|author=Ian Chilvers|title=The Oxford Dictionary of Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WYaRX58a0_IC&pg=PA452|date=10 June 2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-860476-1|page=452}} His earliest paintings are simple historical paintings with no hidden messages. The later ones, starting with the painting ''[[Stańczyk]]'' (1862), are intended to inspire the viewers with a patriotic message.{{cite book|author=Geraldine Norman|title=Nineteenth-century Painters and Painting: A Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_AIX2wVuj0C&pg=PA181|date=1 January 1977|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-03328-3|page=181}} ''Stańczyk'' focuses on the court jester, portrayed as a symbol of country's conscience, sitting in a chair in the background of a party - a sole figure reflecting on the war, ignored by the joyful crowd.Wanda Małaszewska. "Matejko, Jan." Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press, accessed 28 May 2014, http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T055919 In addition to history paintings Matejko made also numerous portraits. Among others: portraits of Jagiellonian University rectors [[Józef Szujski]] and [[Stanisław Tarnowski]], and numerous portraits of family and friends, including ''Wife in the wedding dress'' ("Żona w sukni ślubnej") (1865, destroyed by his wife during a quarrel and recreated in 1879) and a self-portrait (1892). Altogether Matejko authored 320 [[oil paintings]] and several thousands [[drawings]] and [[watercolors]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} He also designed the [[polychrome]] in [[St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków]] (1889–1891).{{cite book|author=Stanisława Serafińska|title=Jan Matejko: wspomnienia rodzinne|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HUhsYBacEW8C|year=1958|publisher=Wydawn. Literackie|page=575|language=Polish}} His paintings are on display in numerous Polish museums; including the [[National Museum in Warsaw]], [[National Museum in Kraków]], [[National Museum in Poznań]] and [[National Museum in Wrocław]]. National Museum in Kraków has a branch dedicated to Matejko - [[House of Jan Matejko]] (''Dom Jana Matejki'') located in his former studio and family house at Floriańska Street, opened in 1898.{{cite web|url=http://www.muzeum.krakow.pl/O-oddziale.67.0.html |title=O oddziale |publisher=Muzeum.krakow.pl |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524004222/http://www.muzeum.krakow.pl/O-oddziale.67.0.html |archivedate=24 May 2014 |df= }} Another museum dedicated to Matejko, [[Dworek Jana Matejki w Krzesławicach|Dworek Jana Matejki]], opened in [[Krzesławice, Lesser Poland Voivodeship|Krzesławice]] (where Matejo acquired a [[dworek (house)|manor]]) in 1865.Bochnak (1975), p. 191 Over 80 painters have been Matejko's students at some point, many influenced during his tenure as the director of the Kraków School of Fine Arts, and are referred to as members of "Matejko School".{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/event/artists-from-the-school-of-jan-matejko |title="Artists from the School of Jan Matejko" | Event |publisher=Culture.pl |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529052601/http://culture.pl/en/event/artists-from-the-school-of-jan-matejko |archivedate=29 May 2014 |df= }} Prominent among them are [[Maurycy Gottlieb]], [[E.M. Lilien|Ephraim Moses Lilien]],{{cite book|author=Glenda Abramson|title=Encyclopedia of Modern Jewish Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L_FhfTvzjygC&pg=PA523|date=1 March 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-42865-6|page=523}} [[Jacek Malczewski]], [[Józef Mehoffer]], [[Antoni Piotrowski]], [[Witold Pruszkowski]], [[Leon Wyczółkowski]], and [[Stanisław Wyspiański]]. Image:Samuel Zborowski śmierć.jpg|center|Samuel Zborowski on his way to his execution. revision.comment: recategorize
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Jerry Saltz | birth_name = | image = Pulitzer2018-jerry-saltz-20180530-wp.jpg | caption = Saltz at the 2018 Pulitzer Prizes | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|2|19|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Oak Park, Illinois]], USA | occupation = Journalist, Author, [[Art critic]] | language = <!-- English --> | nationality = United States | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = 1990s–present | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Seeing Out Loud: The Village Voice Art Columns, 1998–2003'', ''Seeing Out Louder'' }} '''Jerry Saltz''' (born February 19, 1951) is an American [[art critic]]. Since 2006, he has been senior art critic and columnist for ''[[New York magazine|New York]]'' magazine. Formerly the senior art critic for ''[[The Village Voice]]'', he received the [[Pulitzer Prize for Criticism]] in 2018 and was nominated for the award in 2001 and 2006. He has also contributed to ''[[Art in America]], [[Flash Art|Flash Art International]], [[Frieze (magazine)|Frieze]], and [[Modern Painters (magazine)|Modern Painters]]'', among other art publications.<ref>Parmiggiani, Sandro (February 2011). "[http://www.ilgiornaledellarte.com/articoli/2011/2/106529.html Il 90% dell’arte è pessima, il 9% buona, l’1% favolosa (e forse resterà)]" (review of Italian edition of ''Seeing Out Loud''; in Italian). ''Il Giornale dell'arte''. No. 306. ilgiornaledellarte.com. Retrieved 2018-07-20.</ref> Saltz served as a visiting critic at [[The School of Visual Arts]], [[Columbia University]], [[Yale University]], and [[The School of the Art Institute of Chicago]] and the New York Studio Residency Program, and was the sole advisor for the 1995 [[Whitney Museum|Whitney Biennial]].
==Early life== Saltz was born in Chicago and attended art school for a few years before dropping out. Before moving to New York at 26, he founded an artist-run gallery in Chicago.<ref name=br>{{cite web |url=http://brooklynrail.org/2008/09/art/jerry-saltz-in-conversation-with-irving-sandler |title=Jerry Saltz with Irving Sandler |last=Sandler |first=Irving |date=12 September 2012 |website=brooklynrail.org |publisher=Brooklyn Rail|access-date=12 September 2016}}</ref>
==Art criticism== In an article in ''[[Artnet]]'' magazine, Saltz codified his outlook: "All great contemporary artists, schooled or not, are essentially self-taught and are de-skilling like crazy. I don't look for skill in art...Skill has nothing to do with technical proficiency... I'm interested in people who rethink skill, who redefine or reimagine it: an engineer, say, who builds rockets from rocks."<ref>Saltz, Jerry, [http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/saltz/saltz12-20-05.asp "Seeing Out Loud"], ''www.artnet.com'', December 20, 2005. Retrieved 2015-10-01.</ref> In 2008 Saltz said, "I'm looking for what the artist is trying to say and what he or she is actually saying, what the work reveals about society and the timeless conditions of being alive".<ref>Thornton, Sarah. Seven Days in the Art World. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. 2008. (174–75)</ref>
[[File:VOLVO.jpg|thumbnail|left|150px|Saltz was a long distance truck driver before becoming an art critic.<ref>Parsi, Novid. [http://chicago.timeout.com/articles/tv/85918/jerry-saltz-interview "Jerry Saltz: Interview"]. Time Out: Chicago. May 27, 2010.</ref>]]In ''Seeing Out Loud'', his collection of ''Village Voice'' columns published in 2003, he said he considers himself the kind of critic that [[Peter Plagens]] calls a "goalie," someone who says "It's going to have to be pretty good to get by me."<ref>Saltz, Jerry. Seeing Out Loud: the Village Voice Art Columns Fall 1998 – Winter 2003. The Figures. 2003 (20–21).</ref> Saltz has cited Manny Farber's "termite art" and [[Joan Didion]]'s "Babylon" as well as other wide-ranging systemic metaphors for the [[art world]]. Although he's defended the art market, he's also called out faddy market behavior and the fetish for youth, saying "the art world eats its young."<ref>Saltz, Jerry. [http://www.artnet.com/Magazine/features/saltz/saltz9-13-00.asp "Babylon Calling"]. ''Artnet Magazine''. September 13, 2000</ref>
On a [[College Art Association]] panel in February 2007, Saltz commented, "We live in a Wikipedia art world. Twenty years ago, there were only four to five encyclopedias—and I tried to get into them. Now, all writing is in the Wikipedia. Some entries are bogus, some are the best. We live in an open [[art world]]."
His humor, irreverence, [[self-deprecation]] and volubility have led some to call him the [[Rodney Dangerfield]] of the art world.<ref name=HAH/> He has expressed doubt about art critics' influence as purveyors of taste, saying they have little effect on the success of an artist's career. Nonetheless, [[ArtReview]] called him the 73rd most powerful person in the art world in their 2009 Power 100 list.<ref name=HAH>Harrison, Helen A. [http://sagharboronline.com/artists-dont-get-no-respect/ "Artists Don't Get No Respect"]. Sag Harbor Express. August 7, 2010. Retrieved 2015-10-01.</ref>
In 2007, he received the [[Frank Jewett Mather]] Award for art criticism from the [[College Art Association]].<ref name="caa">{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeart.org/awards/matherpast|title=Awards|publisher=The College Art Association|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}</ref>
===Dialogue with readers through Facebook=== Saltz uses Facebook more actively than many other art critics, posting daily questions and diatribes to his audience of friends, which numbered 89,155 in September 2018. He has stated that he wants to demystify the art critic to artists and a general art audience. His posts are less polished and restrained than his writing for ''New York Magazine'' and ''[[vulture.com]]'', and he has shared personal matters including family tragedies, career bumps and his diet. He told the ''[[New York Observer]]'', "It's exciting to be in this room with 5,000 people. It's like the Cedar Bar for me, or [[Max's Kansas City]]."<ref>Neyfakh, Leon. [http://www.observer.com/2010/media/many-friends-jerry-saltz "The Many Friends of Jerry Saltz"]. New York Observer. February 16, 2010.</ref>
He has used his page to defend the use of [[irony]] in art, arguing against adherents of "the New Seriousness", whom he calls the "Purity Police".<ref>Butler, Sharon L. [http://www.brooklynrail.org/2009/03/artseen/the-art-world-on-facebook-a-primer "The Art World on Facebook:A Primer"]. Brooklyn Rail. March 2009.</ref>
<gallery caption="Some Facebook-related Jerry Saltz activity" widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:saltz jerry.jpg|Saltz and [[Bill Clinton]] pose at an art gallery exhibit opening—side view of the scene long used as the user-avatar on {{Official website|https://www.facebook.com/jerry.saltz|name=Saltz's official Facebook page}}<!-- File:Wiki_roberta_smith_left_jerry_saltz_center_terry_ward_right_nyc_chelsea_2012.jpg|At the public opening reception of an art exhibit at a gallery in New York City, Saltz (center) is flanked by wife [[Roberta Smith]] and artist and Facebook friend Terry Ward. <!-- more Facebook-related Jerry Saltz copyright-free photos needed --> </gallery>
In 2010, artist [[Jennifer Dalton]] exhibited an artwork called "What Are We Not Shutting Up About?" at the FLAG Foundation in New York that statistically analyzed five months of Facebook conversations between Saltz and his online friends.<ref>Johnson, Ken. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/13/arts/design/13galleries-002.html "Art in Review: Jennifer Dalton – Making Sense"]. ''New York Times''. August 13, 2010.</ref> In an interview with [[Artinfo]], Dalton said of the work, “I became interested in Jerry Saltz's Facebook page as an amazing site of written dialogue and as a place where culture is being created on the spot. I think my piece, and Jerry Saltz's Facebook page itself, tells us that a lot of people in the art world crave dialogue and community, and when a space is welcoming enough people really flock to it.”<ref>[http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2010/07/07/jennifer-dalton-makes-art-from-jerry-saltzs-facebook/ "Jennifer Dalton Makes Art From Jerry Saltz's Facebook Page"]. Artinfo. July 7, 2010.</ref>
In 2010, Saltz asked his Facebook friends about art studio (or office) door signs—and then later sought someone to compile the replies. The result was a book featuring Saltz and dozens of his page's followers' quotes: ''JERRY SALTZ ART CRITIC's Fans, Friends, & The Tribes Suggested ART STUDIO DOOR SIGNS of Real Life or Fantasy'' ({{ISBN|978-0-9798261-0-8}}).<ref>[http://www.blurb.com/books/1445427 "Art studio door signs book online preview portal"]</ref>
In 2015, Saltz was briefly suspended from Facebook after the site received complaints from users about provocative posts.<ref name=nyt.fb>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=4 March 2015 |title=Jerry Saltz, New York Magazine Art Critic, Suspended From Facebook |url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/03/04/jerry-saltz-new-york-magazine-art-critic-suspended-from-facebook/ |newspaper=New York Times |location=New York, NY |access-date=5 February 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.artspace.com/magazine/interviews_features/qa/jerry-saltz-on-facebook-and-medieval-porn-52674|title=Jerry Saltz on His (Brief) Exile From Facebook, and the Virtues of Medieval Torture Porn|website=Artspace|language=en|access-date=2018-09-18}}</ref>
===Art critic as television personality=== Saltz served as a judge in the [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo]] television series ''[[Work of Art: The Next Great Artist]]'' which premiered on June 9, 2010.
==Personal life== Saltz lives in New York City with his wife [[Roberta Smith]], co-chief art critic for the ''[[New York Times]]''. They were married in 1992.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/opinion/kenny-schachter-jerry-saltz-777836|title=Jerry Saltz and the Future of the Critic-Artist {{!}} artnet News|date=2016-12-09|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}}</ref> He is critical of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].<ref>[https://mobile.twitter.com/jerrysaltz/status/1047919526657085441]</ref>
===Books written by Saltz===
* Saltz, Jerry. ''Seeing Out Loud: The Village Voice Art Columns'', 1998–2003. Gt Barrington: The Figures, 2003; reprinted 2007; 410 pp. (paperback), {{ISBN|978-1-930589-17-9}}. * Saltz, Jerry. ''Seeing Out Louder''. Hudson Hills Press LLC, 2009; 420 pp. (hardcover), {{ISBN|978-1-55595-318-8}}.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.geoffreyyoung.com/thefigures/seeingoutloud.html Seeing Out Loud] is available direct from the publisher. * [http://www.artnet.com/magazine/features/saltz.asp Jerry Saltz Article Archives] on Artnet.com * [http://nymag.com/nymag/jerry-saltz/ Jerry Saltz Archive] at New York Magazine * [http://www.brooklynrail.org/2008/09/art/jerry-saltz-in-conversation-with-irving-sandler ''Jerry Saltz with Irving Sandler'': an interview by [[Irving Sandler]]] published in [[The Brooklyn Rail]] {{Art blogs}}
{{PulitzerPrize Criticism}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''Kuryokhin Center''', or more extended the '''Sergey Kuryokhin Center for Modern Art''', is a [[non-profit]] [[cultural centre]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]].<ref>http://thisislike.com/kurehin-international-contemporary-art-centre-area/about</ref> The centre was founded in 2004 and named after the Russian avant garde composer [[Sergey Kuryokhin]]. The main space of the centre has a capacity of 2000 people. The venue is located in an old cinema building.
==About Kuryokhin Center== The Kuryokhin Center organises visual art exhibitions, art events and festivals. The Modern Art Center is an old cinema space. It hosts [[experimental music]], film and art festivals ([[Sergey Kuryokhin International Festival|SKIF]], [[Electro-mechanika Festival]], [[Videoforma festival]]<ref>http://www.satellietgroep.nl/badgast_air_sea/1</ref> and [[Ethno-mechanica Festival]]<ref>http://www.waytorussia.net/events/saint-petersburg/sergey-kuryokhin-modern-art-center/ethno-mechanica-festival.html</ref>) and a few other random events several times per year.
The centre is also the residency of the [[Sergey Kuryokhin Foundation]] that collects documentation about the composer.
==SKIF and Electro-Mechanica== [[Sergey Kuryokhin International Festival|SKIF]], Sergey Kuryokhin International Festival, is a yearly international festival of modern arts taking place since 1998.<ref>http://204.73.168.185/events/saint-petersburg/sergey-kuryokhin-modern-art-center/skif-15-international-festival-of-modern-arts-festival.html</ref> Kuryokhin′s long-time partner cellist [[Boris Raiskin]] conceived the festival in New York City. SKIF-1 and SKIF-2 took place in New York in 1997 and 1998. In October 1998 SKIF-3 moved to Saint Petersburg, the city where Kuryokhin lived and worked.<ref>http://www.last.fm/festival/1734121+SKIF-15+-+Sergey+Kuryokhin+International+Festival</ref> From 2005 SKIF takes place in the Kuryokhin Modern Art Center in St.Petersburg, the current residence of the festival and Sergey Kuryokhin Foundation.
[[Electro-Mechanica]] is an annual festival since 2007 representing electronic audio-visual arts including music, animation, videos, films, installations and performances<ref>http://thisislike.com/electro-mechanica-festival/about</ref> Acts such as [[Tok Tek]], [[Camera]], [[Michael Rother]] (of [[Neu]]), [[Psychic TV]], [[The Ex (band)|The Ex]], [[Pierre Bastien]] and [[Yuri landman|Yuri Landman]] have performed at SKIF or Electro-Mechanica.
Sister festival [[Ethnomechanic]]a is an international contemporary [[world music]] festival in St.Petersburg, Russia. “Ethnomechanica” is a project of Sergey Kuryokhin Foundation and takes place in Sergey Kuryokhin modern art center annually since 2008. Carrying on the SKIF festival traditions, “Ethnomechanica” introduce to Russian audience diversity of world music, welcoming experiment and synthesis. Ethnomechanica focused in 2013 on Switzerland and The Netherlands. 2013 is the Netherlands-Russia year, a year in which the Netherlands and Russia emphasize their long bilateral relations. With a support of NLRF2013 Ethnomechanica invited Dutch artists [[Skip & Die]], [[De Kift]], [[The Ex (band)|The Ex]] and [[Rebel Up! Soundclash]]. Switzerland has a focus on Russia in 2013-2015, and Pro Helvetia Swiss Arts Council supports the projects in Russia as a part of the Swiss Made in Russia programme. In frames of this program we invited [[The Dead Brothers]].
Artists who performed in 2008-2012: [[Mulatu Astatke]] (Ethiopia), [[Tony Allen (musician)|Tony Allen]] (Nigeria), [[Mari Boine]] (Norway), [[Alexander Balanescu]] & [[Evelina Petrova]] (UK/Russia), [[Orange Blossom]] (France), [[Alamaailman Vasarat]] (Finland), [[Zdob Si Zdub]] (Moldova), [[La Caution]] (France), [[Filastine]] (USA), [[Jimi Tenor]] & [[Kabu Kabu]] (Finland/Germany/Ghana/Cuba), [[Poirier]] (Canada), [[Munchi]] (Dominican Republic/The Netherlands), [[Schlachthofbronx]] (Germany), [[Awesome Tapes]] from Afrika (USA), [[Socalled]] (Canada), [[Shazalakazoo]] (Serbia), [[Las Balkanieras]] (Germany/Bosnia/Croatia/Russia), [[DakhaBrakha]] (Ukraine), [[DJ Penny Metal]] (UK), [[DJ Kosta Kostov]] (Germany/Bulgaria), [[Jouhiorkesteri]] (Finland), Debruit (France), [[General Levy]] (UK) & [[Jacky Murda]] (USA), Tibetan Buddhist monks from [[Phiyang Monastery]] (India), Altay Kai (Altai),Fellow & VJ Ken Wolff (The Netherlands), [[Daniel Haaksman]] (Germany), Troitsa (Belarus), Leha Chicanos (Belarus), Gurzuf (Belarus), Baimurat aka Jimmy (Tajikistan), [[Asfaltal Da Kosmasas]] (Finland/Russia), Tamara Soundsystem (Ukraine), and many Russia artists like Sainkho, Vera Sazhina&Sergey Letov, Kira Lao, Osipova Luka, Pontell, Signor Mako, Kamennoe More, Namgar, Psoy Korolenko, Garik Osipov, La Minor, Skazy Lesa, Nervenklinik, Volga, Swing Couture, Belorybitsa, Ptitsa Tyloburdo, Iva Nova, atlantida, Vereya, DJ Dr.Ethno aka Nazim Nadirov, Inna Zhelannaya, Obmorok Imama, Cheinesh and Marina Stepanova, Velena, Testo, Otava Yo, Hidden Tribe, Bugotak, Peterburgska Roma, DJ DenisRubin, VJ Anima, Trojan Soundsystem, Karl Hlamkin and OgneOpasnoOrchestra, Theodor Bastard, Chance-On Manouche, Reelroad, Naekhovichi, Chumaho Dryu, Ankalym, Dj Сhak and others. Besides musical program, the festival presents world cinema, workshops, dances, VJ-ing.
==Sources and References== {{reflist}} * [http://issuu.com/ergens_library/docs/kuryokhin_center_catalogue_award_2010 Kuryokhin Center Catalogue]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140222041834/http://www.kuryokhin.net/ru/award/about www.kuryokhin.net]

{{Infobox company | name = LexInnova Technologies | logo = LexInnova Logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = Private | industry = [[Intellectual property|Intellectual Property]], [[Legal]], [[Technology]] | founded = 2009 | founder = Abhi Verma | hq_location = Houston, USA | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Abhi Verma, Founder and Managing Director | products = | brands = | services = Patent Litigation Consulting; [[Intellectual property|IP]] Strategy; [[Ediscovery|eDiscovery]] and Litigation Support; [[Patent licensing|Patent Licensing]]; [[Software asset management|Software Asset Management]]; Technology Experts; M&A Due Diligence; [[Contract management|Contract Management]]; Research and Compliance | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = 100+ | website = {{url|http://www.lex-innova.com}} }}
'''LexInnova Technologies, LLC''', is a legal services and technology consulting company headquartered in [[Houston]], [[Texas]]. It specializes in providing [[patent litigation]] consulting, [[patent]] [[analytics]], [[Ediscovery|eDiscovery]], legal [[due diligence]], [[License Management|license management]], [[intellectual property]] advisory, and technology consulting services to [[law firm]]s and [[corporation]]s. The company also has offices at [[Cupertino, California]]; [[Houston, Texas]] and [[Gurgaon, India]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/lexinnova|title=LexInnova|website=Crunchbase|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.economylead.com/blog/derek-handova/start-me-up-part-1-indian-startup-scene-in-silicon-valley-78468|title=Start Me Up! (Part 1): Indian Startup Scene in Silicon Valley - EconomyLead|first=|last=EconomyLead|website=Economylead.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wireservice.co/2014/02/lexinnova-expands-presence-with-new-u-s-operations-director-and-houston-office/|title=Account Suspended|website=Wireservice.co|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== LexInnova Technologies was founded in May 2009, by Abhi Verma, an alumnus of [[IIT-Varanasi|IIT Varanasi]] and [[Harvard Law]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lex-innova.com/member-detail.php?page=27|title=Lexinnova Leadership Details - LexInnova|website=Lex-innova.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> to provide legal and intellectual property solutions to in-house and outside [[counsel]]. They also provide consulting to technology companies to help them focus their R&D efforts and identify gaps in their [[IP portfolio]].<ref name="auto"/> The company employs [[engineers]], [[technocrats]], [[lawyer]]s, [[scientist]]s and [[Legal project management|legal project managers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/varanasi/7-startups-visit-IIT-BHU-campus/articleshow/45401153.cms|title=7 startups visit IIT-BHU campus|website=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> In July, 2015, LexInnova was cited in [[Forbes]] magazine for its patent portfolio analytics report on Internet of Things.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Internet Of Things: IoT Tech Landscape And Rankings - New Report|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisabrownlee/2015/07/30/internet-of-things-iot-tech-landscape-and-rankings-new-report/|accessdate = 2015-10-01|first = Lisa|last = Brownlee}}</ref>
==Services== # Patent Litigation Consulting # [[Intellectual property|IP]] Strategy # eDiscovery and Litigation Support # [[Patent licensing|Patent Licensing]] # [[Software asset management|Software Asset Management]] # Technology Experts # [[Contract management|Contract Management]] # Research and Compliance
==Notable publications== LexInnova’s analysis of the [[IP portfolio]]s of [[Nokia]] and [[Alcatel-Lucent]] was published in [[USA Today]], [[Computerworld]] and [[Barron's Magazine|Barron’s magazine]] when news broke of the two companies merging<ref>{{cite web|url=http://company.nokia.com/en/news/press-releases/2015/04/15/nokia-and-alcatel-lucent-to-combine-to-create-an-innovation-leader-in-next-generation-technology-and-services-for-an-ip-connected-world|title=NOKIA AND ALCATEL-LUCENT TO COMBINE TO CREATE AN INNOVATION LEADER IN NEXT GENERATION TECHNOLOGY AND SERVICES FOR AN IP CONNECTED WORLD - Nokia|website=Nokia|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> on 14 April 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/04/14/nokia-in-advanced-talks-to-acquire-alcatellucent/25756285/|title=Nokia in|website=Usatoday.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2909751/nokia-alcatel-lucent-deal-would-make-a-complementary-patent-portfolio.html|title=Nokia Alcatel-Lucent deal would make a complementary patent portfolio|first=Matt|last=Hamblen|website=Computerworld.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2015/04/14/nokia-slips-an-alcatel-buy-makes-sense-what-are-the-synergies-asks-street/|title=Nokia Slips: An Alcatel Buy Makes Sense, What are the Synergies? Asks Street|first=Tiernan|last=Ray|website=Blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
LexInnova’s research report and opinions have been featured in a technology article on the Internet of Things (IoT) and has been published in [[Forbes]] in July 2015, CIO Insight, and [[Investor's Business Daily|The Investor's Business Daily]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisabrownlee/2015/07/30/internet-of-things-iot-tech-landscape-and-rankings-new-report/|title=Internet Of Things: IoT Tech Landscape And Rankings - New Report|first=Lisa|last=Brownlee|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cioinsight.com/it-strategy/mobile-wireless/slideshows/patent-filings-reveal-a-growing-interest-in-iot.html|title=Patent Filings Reveal a Growing Interest in IoT|website=Cioinsight.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.investors.com/technology/041015-747347-google-smart-home-business-raises-questions.htm?p=full|title=Google's Nest Spreading Its Wings, But How Far?|date=10 April 2015|website=News.investors.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
Their reports on Chinese [[smartphone]] maker [[Xiaomi]] have featured in [[The Wall Street Journal]], [[CNBC]], [[International Business Times]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/xiaomi-chinas-new-phone-giant-takes-aim-at-world-1433731461|title=Xiaomi, China’s New Phone Giant, Takes Aim at World|first=Eva|last=Dou|date=8 June 2015|accessdate=14 November 2017|website=Wsj.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102705074|title=The Chinese want to challenge Apple on its home turf|first=Arjun|last=Kharpal|date=25 May 2015|website=Cnbc.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/why-xiaomi-not-coming-america-anytime-soon-it-only-has-2-us-patents-1863838|title=Why Xiaomi Is Not Coming To America Anytime Soon: It Only Has 2 US Patents|date=30 March 2015|website=Ibtimes.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
Lexinnova’s report on ‘Network Security: Overview of patent out-licensing opportunities’ evaluated the information-security portfolios of information-security vendors and reflected in Australian CSO, WIPR and Fierce Interprise Communications defining the number of patents held by different companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cso.com.au/article/578941/australia-world-fourth-largest-holder-network-security-patents-analysis-finds/|title=Australia is world's fourth-largest holder of network-security patents, analysis finds|website=Cso.com.au|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fierceenterprisecommunications.com/story/cisco-holds-broadest-network-security-patent-portfolio-loses-quality/2015-06-22 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723173301/http://www.fierceenterprisecommunications.com/story/cisco-holds-broadest-network-security-patent-portfolio-loses-quality/2015-06-22 |archivedate=2015-07-23 |df= }}</ref>
Fierce Wireless Tech cited LexInnova’s Wireless Power analysis on the biggest amount of patent applications filed and received for technology related to wireless power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercewireless.com/tech/story/samsung-qualcomm-lead-charge-wireless-power-patent-activities/2015-06-03|title=Samsung, Qualcomm lead the charge in wireless power patent activities - FierceWireless|website=Fiercewireless.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
In Enterprise Tech publication (May 2015) LexInnova’s report on 3D memory was mentioned in accordance to the allusion that the majority of R&D in SSD technology has been in 3D NAND, which is the most important technology for increasing the capacity and lowering the cost per gigabyte of storage drives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprisetech.com/2015/05/08/patents-show-whos-winning-the-ssd-race/|title=Who's Winning the SSD Race? Ask the Patents|date=8 May 2015|website=Enterprisetech.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
LexInnova’s observation of Virtual reality patent race taken from the same report was mentioned in Hypergrid Business article ‘Sony leads virtual reality patent race’.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hypergridbusiness.com/2015/05/sony-leads-virtual-reality-patent-race/|title=Sony leads virtual reality patent race –|website=Hypergridbusiness.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
Insights from LexInnova's report on Wireless Power have been featured by [[Qualcomm]], American global semiconductor company, in its company blog.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Qualcomm is first to announce wireless charging for metal smartphones and more [VIDEO] {{!}} Qualcomm|url = https://www.qualcomm.com/news/onq/2015/07/28/qualcomm-first-announce-wireless-charging-metal-smartphones|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
==Certifications== LexInnova is certified for [[Information security|Information Security]] ([[ISO 27001]]) and [[Quality management system|Quality Management Systems]] ([[ISO 9001]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsigroup.com/en-IN/Our-services/Certification/Certificate-and-Client-Directory-search/Certificate-Client-Directory-search-results/?searchkey=country=India&company=LexInnova&city=gurgaon&licencenumber=IS+607655|title=Certificate Client Directory search results - BSI India|website=Bsigroup.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsigroup.com/en-IN/Our-services/Certification/Certificate-and-Client-Directory-search/Certificate-Client-Directory-search-results/?searchkey=country=India&company=LexInnova&city=gurgaon&licencenumber=FS+614196|title=Certificate Client Directory search results - BSI India|website=Bsigroup.com|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.lex-innova.com}}

The following is a '''list of winners of the [[Harvey Award]]''', sorted by category.<ref>[http://www.harveyawards.org/ Harvey Awards] official website. Accessed on August 22, 2015. [https://web.archive.org/web/20150818170308/http://www.harveyawards.org/ Archived] from the original on August 18, 2015.</ref>
==People==
===Best Writer=== *1988 [[Alan Moore]], for ''[[Watchmen]]'' (DC) *1989 [[Gilbert Hernandez]], for ''[[Love and Rockets (comics)|Love and Rockets]]'' (Fantagraphics Books) *1990 Gilbert Hernandez, for ''[[Love and Rockets (comics)|Love and Rockets]]'' (Fantagraphics Books) *1991 [[Neil Gaiman]], for ''[[The Sandman (DC Comics Modern Age)|The Sandman]]'' (DC) *1992 Neil Gaiman, for ''[[The Sandman (DC Comics Modern Age)|The Sandman]]'' (DC) *1993 [[Will Eisner]], for ''Invisible People'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1994 [[Scott McCloud]], for ''[[Understanding Comics]]'' (Tundra/Kitchen Sink Press) *1995 Alan Moore, for ''[[From Hell]]'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1996 Alan Moore, for ''From Hell'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1997 [[Daniel Clowes]] for ''[[Eightball (comics)|Eightball]]'' (Fantagraphics Books) *1998 [[Kurt Busiek]], for his body of work in 1997, including ''[[Astro City|Kurt Busiek's Astro City]]'' (Image/Homage), ''[[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]'' (Marvel Comics), and ''[[Thunderbolts (comics)|Thunderbolts]]'' (Marvel Comics) *1999 Alan Moore, for his body of work in 1998, including ''From Hell'' (Kitchen Sink Press) and ''[[Supreme (comics)|Supreme]]'' ([[Awesome Comics|Awesome]]) *2000 Alan Moore, for ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'' (ABC) *2001 Alan Moore, for ''[[Promethea]]'' (ABC) *2002 [[Brian Azzarello]], ''[[100 Bullets]]'' (DC) *2003 Alan Moore, for ''[[Promethea]]'' (ABC) *2004 [[Chester Brown]], for ''[[Louis Riel (comics)|Louis Riel]]'' (Drawn & Quarterly Publishing) *2005 Daniel Clowes, for ''Eightball'' (Fantagraphics Books) *2006 [[Ed Brubaker]], for ''[[Captain America]]'' (Marvel Comics) *2007 Ed Brubaker, for ''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' (Marvel Comics) *2008 [[Brian K. Vaughan]], for ''[[Y: The Last Man]]'' (DC/Vertigo)<ref name="comicsjournal295">[[Eric Millikin|Millikin, Eric]] and staff. "Journal Datebook: August, 2008 — October, 2008", p. 25, ''[[The Comics Journal]]'' Seattle, January 2009.</ref> *2009 [[Grant Morrison]], for ''[[All-Star Superman]]'' (DC) *2010 [[Robert Kirkman]], for ''[[The Walking Dead (comics)|The Walking Dead]]'' (Image) *2011 [[Roger Langridge]], for ''[[Thor (Marvel Comics)|Thor]]: The Mighty Avenger'' (Marvel Comics) *2012 [[Mark Waid]], for ''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' (Marvel Comics) *2013 [[Brian K. Vaughan]], for ''[[Saga (comic book)|Saga]]'' (Image Comics) *2014 Brian K. Vaughan, for ''[[Saga (comic book)|Saga]]'' (Image Comics) *2015 Mark Waid, for ''Daredevil'' (Marvel Comics) *2016 Brian K. Vaughan, for ''[[Saga (comic book)|Saga]]'' (Image Comics)<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Harvey Award Winners Announced|url=https://www.previewsworld.com/Article/183556-2016-Harvey-Award-Winners-Announced/|website=Previews World|date=Sep 6, 2016}}</ref>
===Best Artist or Penciller=== *1988 [[Dave Gibbons]], for ''[[Watchmen]]'' (DC) *1989 [[Brian Bolland]], for ''[[Batman: The Killing Joke]]'' (DC) *1990 [[Mark Schultz (comics)|Mark Schultz]], for ''[[Xenozoic Tales]]'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1991 [[Steve Rude]], for ''[[World's Finest Comics|World's Finest]]'' (DC) *1992 Mark Schultz, for ''Xenozoic Tales'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1993 Mark Schultz, for ''Xenozoic Tales'' (Kitchen Sink Press) *1994 [[Alex Ross]], for ''[[Marvels]]'' (Marvel Comics) *1995 [[Mike Mignola]], for ''[[Hellboy]]'' (Dark Horse Comics) *1996 Mike Mignola, for ''Hellboy'' (Dark Horse Comics) *1997 [[Alex Ross]] for ''[[Kingdom Come (comics)|Kingdom Come]]'' (DC) *1998 (tie) [[P. Craig Russell]], for his body of work such as ''[[Elric (comics)|Elric]]: Stormbringer'' (Dark Horse Comics/[[Topps Comics]]), and ''[[Dr. Strange: What Is It That Disturbs You, Stephen?]]'' (Marvel Comics) *1999 [[Jaime Hernandez]], for his body of work in 1998, including ''[[Love and Rockets (comics)|Penny Century]]'' (Fantagraphics Books) *2000 Mike Mignola, for ''Hellboy: Box Full of Evil'' (Dark Horse Comics/Maverick) *2001 [[Jaime Hernandez]], for ''[[Love and Rockets (comics)|Penny Century]]'' (Fantagraphics Books) *2002 [[Eduardo Risso]], for ''[[100 Bullets]]'' (DC) *2003 Eduardo Risso, for ''100 Bullets'' (DC) *2004 [[Craig Thompson]], for ''[[Blankets (comics)|Blankets]]'' (Top Shelf Productions) *2005 [[Darwyn Cooke]], for ''[[DC: The New Frontier]]'' (DC) *2006 [[J. H. Williams III]], for ''[[Promethea]]'' (DC/ABC/WildStorm) *2007 [[Frank Quitely]], for ''[[All-Star Superman]]'' (DC) *2008 Frank Quitely, for ''[[All-Star Superman]]'' (DC)<ref name="comicsjournal295"/> *2009 [[Gabriel Bá]], for ''[[The Umbrella Academy]]'' (Dark Horse Comics) *2010 [[Robert Crumb]], for ''[[The Book of Genesis (comics)|The Book of Genesis]]'' *2011 [[Darwyn Cooke]], for ''[[Richard Stark's Parker: The Outfit]]'' (IDW) *2012 [[J. H. Williams III|J. H. page.title: List of feminist avant-garde artists of the 1970s
