revision.text:
{{Muisca sidebar}} [[File:Museo Del Oro, Bogota (24546916613).jpg|thumb|right|235px|An example of the interaction of the art of nature and the famous goldworking of the Muisca is the precious '''golden sea snail''' in the collection of the [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]] in Bogotá]] [[File:Sabana de Bogota.png|thumb|235px|right|The flat '''Bogotá savanna''', the southern territory of the [[Muisca Confederation]], not only provided fertile agricultural lands, but also many different clays for the production of ceramics, rock shelters where petroglyphs and petrographs were made and a central strategic access to the regions around it. This made trade with various neighbouring indigenous groups possible by which the Muisca obtained feathers, cotton, pigments and the vast amounts of gold and copper used for their fine ''tunjos'', jewelry, and other golden and ''[[tumbaga]]'' artefacts]] This article describes the '''art''' produced by the '''Muisca'''. The [[Muisca people|Muisca]] established one of the four grand civilisations of the [[pre-Columbian era|pre-Columbian]] Americas on the [[Altiplano Cundiboyacense]] in present-day central [[Colombia]]. Their various forms of art have been described in detail and include pottery, textiles, body art, hieroglyphs and rock art. While their architecture was modest compared to the [[Inca Empire|Inca]], [[Aztec Empire|Aztec]] and [[Maya civilization|Maya civilisations]], the Muisca are best known for their skilled goldworking. The [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]] in the Colombian capital [[Bogotá]] houses the biggest collection of golden objects in the world, from various Colombian cultures including the Muisca.
The first art in the [[Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)|Eastern Ranges]] of the Colombian [[Andes]] goes back several millennia. Although this predates the Muisca civilisation, whose onset is commonly set at 800 AD, nevertheless, some of these styles persevered through the ages.
During the [[Andean preceramic|preceramic]] era, the people of the highlands produced petrographs and petroglyphs representing their [[Muisca religion|deities]], the abundant [[List of flora and fauna named after the Muisca|flora and fauna]] of the area, abstract motives and anthropomorphic or anthropo-zoomorphic elements. The self-sufficient sedentary [[Muisca agriculture|agricultural]] society developed into a culture based on ceramics and the extraction of [[Nemocón|salt]] in the [[Herrera Period]], usually defined as 800 BC to 800 AD. During this time, the oldest existing form of constructed art was erected; the [[archaeoastronomy|archaeoastronomical]] site called ''[[El Infiernito]]'' ("The Little Hell") by the catholic Spanish [[List of conquistadors in Colombia|conquistadors]]. The Herrera Period also marked the widespread use of pottery and textiles and the start of what would become the main motive for the [[Spanish conquest of the Muisca|Spanish conquest]]; the skilled fine goldworking. The golden age of Muisca metallurgy is represented in the [[Muisca raft]], considered the masterpiece of this technology and depicts the initiation ritual of the new ''[[zipa]]'' of [[Bacatá]], the southern part of the [[Muisca Confederation]]. This ceremony, performed by ''xeques'' (priests) and ''caciques'' wearing feathered golden crowns and accompanied by [[Muisca music|music and dance]], took place on a raft in [[Lake Guatavita]], in the northern part of the flat [[Bogotá savanna]]. Accounts of such ceremonies created the [[Muisca mythology|legend]] of ''[[El Dorado]]'' among the Spanish, leading them on a decades-long quest for this mythical place.
The rich art elaborated by the Muisca has inspired modern artists and designers in their creativity. Muisca motives are represented as murals, in clothing and as objects found all over the former Muisca territories as well as in animated clips and video games. The art of the indigenous inhabitants of the Altiplano Cundiboyacense is well studied by many different [[List of Muisca scholars|researchers]] who published their work right from the beginning of colonial times. The conquistador who made first contact with the Muisca, [[Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada]], wrote in his memoires about a skilled and well-organised civilisation of traders and farmers. [[Friar]] [[Pedro Simón]] described the relation between art and the [[Muisca religion|religion]] and later contributions in the analysis of the various artforms have been made by [[Alexander von Humboldt]], [[Joaquín Acosta]] and [[Liborio Zerda]] in the 19th century, [[Miguel Triana]], [[Eliécer Silva Celis]] and [[Sylvia M. Broadbent]] in the 20th century and modern research is dominated by the work of [[Carl Henrik Langebaek|Carl Henrik Langebaek Rueda]], [[Javier Ocampo López]] and many others.
== Background == [[File:Rocas de Suesca 1.JPG|thumb|right|235px|The rock shelters of '''Suesca''' at the northern edge of the Bogotá savanna were inhabited early in history and characterised by artistic expressions in the form of rock art and a collection of 150 mummies, found in the early colonial period]] [[File:Golden Fishing Hooks.jpg|thumb|right|235px|The Muisca were fishermen and caught the fish of the many lakes and rivers of the Altiplano using '''golden hooks''']] The central highlands of the [[Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)|Eastern Ranges]] of the Colombian [[Andes]], called [[Altiplano Cundiboyacense]], was inhabited by indigenous groups from 12,500 BP, as evidenced from archaeological finds at rock shelter [[El Abra]], presently part of [[Zipaquirá]]. The first human occupation consisted of hunter-gatherers who foraged in the valleys and mountains of the Andean high plateau. Settlement in the early millennia of this [[Andean preceramic]] age was mainly restricted to caves and rock shelters, such as [[Tequendama]] in present-day [[Soacha]], [[Piedras del Tunjo Archaeological Park|Piedras del Tunjo]] in [[Facatativá]] and [[Nemocón#Checua|Checua]] that currently is part of the municipality [[Nemocón]]. Around 3000 BC, the inhabitants of the Andean plains started to live in open space areas and constructed primitive circular houses where they elaborated the [[stone tool]]s used for hunting, fishing, [[Muisca cuisine|food preparation]] and primitive art, mostly [[rock art]]. The [[type locality (archaeology)|type site]] for this transition is the [[List of Muisca and pre-Muisca sites|archaeological site]] [[Aguazuque]], in the northwest of Soacha, close to [[Bogotá]].
Abundant evidence for the domestication of [[guinea pig]]s has been found at Tequendama and Aguazuque where the small rodents formed part of the diet of the people, who consumed mainly [[white-tailed deer]], hunted on the plains surrounding the various lakes and rivers. The diet was greatly expanded when early [[Muisca agriculture|agriculture]] was introduced, possibly influenced by migrations from the south; present-day [[Peru]]. The main cultivated product was [[maize]] in various forms and colours, while [[tubers]] formed a significant other part of the food source. The fertile soils of especially the [[Bogotá savanna]] proved advantageous for the development of this agriculture, still evidenced today by the widespread farmfields outside the Colombian capital.
{{Timeline of inhabitation of the Altiplano Cundiboyacense|state=collapsed}}
== Pre-Muisca art == [[File:Monumento el Infiernito.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The phallic monoliths of archaeoastronomical observatory '''''El Infiernito''''' are the oldest remaining constructed art on the Altiplano Cundiboyacense]] {{see also||El Abra|Piedras del Tunjo Archaeological Park|Tequendama|Herrera Period|El Infiernito}} The first forms of art recognised on the Altiplano are [[petrograph]]s and [[petroglyph]]s in various locations on the Altiplano, mainly at the rock shelters of the Bogotá savanna. El Abra, Piedras del Tunjo and Tequendama are among the oldest sites where rock art has been discovered.<ref name=ICANH>{{es}} [http://www.icanh.gov.co/?idcategoria=5157 Siteos arqueológicos] - [[ICANH]]</ref> The Herrera Period, commonly defined from 800 BC to 800 AD, was the age of the first ceramics. The oldest Herrera pottery has been discovered in [[Cachipay, Cundinamarca|Tocarema]] and dates to 800 BC.<ref>Argüello García, 2015, p.56</ref> Herrera art is also represented by the [[archaeoastronomy|archaeoastronomical site]], called ''[[El Infiernito]]'' by the Spanish. On a field outside [[Villa de Leyva]], [[menhir]]s in the shape of aligned phalluses were erected. This site, the oldest remaining of constructed art, dated at 500 BC, formed an important place for [[Muisca religion|religious]] rituals and festivities where great quantities of the alcoholic drink [[Chicha#Colombia|chicha]] was consumed. The evidence for festivities at this site are from a later date, already in the Muisca Period.<ref>Langebaek Rueda, 2005, p.290</ref>
The goldworking in the northern parts of South America, mainly in present-day Colombia, is thought to originate from regions more to the south; the north of Peru and Ecuador, during a large timespan from 1600 to 1000 BC. The development of different goldworking cultures in southern Colombia happened around 500 BC.<ref name=Lleras_p183>Lleras et al., 2009, p.183</ref> The late Herrera Period showed the first evidences of goldworking on the Altiplano. Golden artefacts have been found in [[Tunja]] and [[Cómbita]] in Boyacá and Guatavita in Cundinamarca with estimated ages ranging from 250 to 400 AD.<ref name=Lleras_p179>Lleras et al., 2009, p.179</ref>
== Muisca art == [[File:Colombia, muisca, tre serpentelli, X-XVI sec, oro fuso.JPG|thumb|right|300px|'''Serpentiform golden figures''' were common in the Muisca art]] The Muisca period is commonly set commencing from 800 AD and lasting until the [[Spanish conquest of the Muisca]] in 1537, although regional variations of the start dates are noted. The Early Muisca Period, roughly defined from 800 to 1000 AD, showed an increase in long-distance trade with the Caribbean coastal indigenous populations, mummification and the introduction of goldworking.<ref name=Langebaek2003_p263>Langebaek Rueda, 2003, p.263</ref> The transition between Early Muisca and Late Muisca is defined by a more complex society, interregional trade of pottery, population growth and settlements of larger sizes closer to the [[Muisca agriculture|agricultural lands]]. When the Spanish conquistadors arrived on the Altiplano, they described a concentration of settlements on the flatlands of the Bogotá savanna.<ref name=Langebaek2003_p263/>
===Zoomorphic figurines=== As the [[Tairona]] of the Colombian Caribbean coast, the Muisca made the zoomorphic figurines based on the [[List of flora and fauna named after the Muisca|fauna]] with their habitat of the area. Main animals used for their figures were the frog and serpents. The serpents were made in zig-zag shapes with eyes on top of the head. Many serpentiform objects have the typical forked tongue of the snake represented as well as the fawns clearly added. Some of the snakes have beards, moustaches or even a human head.<ref name=Legast_p28>Legast, 2000, p.28</ref> [[List of Muisca scholars|Researcher]] [[Gerardo Reichel-Dolmatoff]] theorised in his book ''Orfebrería y chamanismo'' in 1988 that the basis for the beards and moustaches may have been the abundant fish present on the Altiplano and essential part of the [[Muisca cuisine|diet]] of the Muisca and their ancestors, as evidenced in [[Aguazuque]]; ''[[Eremophilus mutisii]]''.<ref name=Legast_p29>Legast, 2000, p.29</ref><ref>García, 2012, p.133</ref><ref name=Aguazuque_p80>Correal Urrego, 1990, p.80</ref>
Frogs (''iesua'', meaning "food from the Sun" in [[Chibcha language|Muysccubun]]) and toads were important animals in the concept of nature and the relation with the spiritual world for the Muisca.<ref name=Bohorquez_p170>Bohórquez Caldera, 2008, p.170</ref> They represented the start of the rainy season, which is illustrated in the use in the [[Muisca calendar]]; the symbols for the first (''ata''), ninth (''aca'') and holy twentieth (''gueta'') month of the years are derived from toads. The common year of the complex lunisolar calendar consisted of twenty months.<ref name=Izquierdo_p30>Izquierdo Peña, 2009, p.30</ref> The frogs are shown in many different settings and forms of art; painted on ceramics, in the hieroglyphs of the rock art and as figurines. In many cases they are shown in combination with everyday activities and were used to represent humans, mostly [[Women in Muisca society|women]].<ref name=Bohorquez_p171>Bohórquez Caldera, 2008, p.171</ref>
=== Goldworking === [[File:Muisca Gold and Wax Working Tools - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|right|thumb|300px|'''Gold- and waxworking tools''' of the Muisca, Museo del Oro, Bogotá]] The Muisca were famous for their goldworking. Although in the [[Muisca Confederation]] gold deposits were not abundant, the people obtained a lot of gold through [[Muisca economy#Trade|trading]], mainly in [[Barrancabermeja|La Tora]] (called Barrancabermeja today) and other locations at the [[Magdalena River]].<ref name=Ocampo_p216>Ocampo López, 2007, p.216</ref> The earliest [[carbon dating|radiocarbon]] dates of goldworking of the Muisca are derived from carbon traces in the cores of golden noserings and provided ages of between 600 and 800 AD. The oldest evidences for Muisca goldworking were found in [[Guatavita]], [[Fusagasugá]] and [[El Peñón, Cundinamarca|El Peñon]], all in present-day Cundinamarca. The goldwork bears similarity but is not identical to the metallurgy of the [[Quimbaya culture|Quimbaya]] of the [[Cauca River|Cauca]] and [[Magdalena River|Magdalena Valleys]].<ref name=Langebaek2003_p264>Langebaek Rueda, 2003, p.264</ref>
Based on the stylistic variability and metallurgic technology analysed in Muisca goldworking, three processes have been concluded;
*the Herrera people elaborated golden and copper objects such as crowns, and other offering figures from [[alluvial]] resources using the first molds and hammers and possibly matrixes. *Around 400 AD, the metallurgy became more advanced, using the ''[[tumbaga]]'' alloy and an increase in the production of offering figures is noted. *The last phase of skilled goldworking is characterised by more detailed goldworking using gold from [[Muisca economy#Trade|trade]] with other indigenous groups.<ref name=Lleras_p184>Lleras et al., 2009, p.184</ref>
With the [[indigenous peoples of Colombia|indigenous groups]] closer to the [[Caribbean Sea|Caribbean Coast]], the people [[Muisca economy#Trade|traded]] highly valuable sea snails. Ironically, the sea snails were worth more than the price of gold to the Muisca, due to the distance from their location far inland high in the [[Andes]]. The skilled goldworking of the Muisca formed the basis for the [[Muisca mythology|legend]] of ''[[El Dorado]]'' that became widespread among the Spanish [[conquistador]]s; this eventually drew them into the heart of Colombia—an ill-fated expedition that took almost a year and cost the lives of about 80% of their men.<ref name=ConquistaGonzalo>{{es}} [http://letras-uruguay.espaciolatino.com/aaa/bolivar_grimaldos_rafael/conquista_rapida_y_saqueo.htm Conquista rápida y saqueo cuantioso de Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada]</ref><ref name=BancoList>{{es}} [http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/historia/gennrgun/gennrgun9x.htm List of conquistadors led by Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada] - [[Banco de la República]]</ref>
==== ''Tunjos'' ==== [[File:Muisca Tunjo Ceramic - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|right|thumb|300px|While most ''tunjos'' were made of gold or ''tumbaga'', some were small '''ceramic''' figurines]] {{main article|Tunjo}} ''Tunjos'' (from [[Chibcha language|Muysccubun]]: ''tunxo'')<ref>{{es}} [http://muysca.cubun.org/Muisquismo/tunjo ''Tunjo''] - Muysccubun dictionary online</ref> are small votive offering figures produced in great quantities by the Muisca. They are found in various places on the Altiplano, mainly in lakes and rivers, and are the most common object housed in museum collections outside Colombia.<ref>{{es}} [http://artesanias-colombia.blogspot.com.co/2008/02/los-tunjos-muiscas.html ''Tunjos'' found in caves and other places]</ref><ref>[http://images.library.amnh.org/digital/index.php/items/show/40807 ''Tunjo'' in American Museum of Natural History]</ref><ref>[http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/artist/Muisca ''Tunjos'' in the Art Institute Chicago]</ref><ref>[http://collection.artbma.org/emuseum/view/objects/aslist/search@?t:state:flow=f883947a-3a30-4b0b-b2b6-f750b4419ab5 ''Tunjos'' in the Baltimore Museum of Art]</ref><ref>[http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/themes/lost_kingdoms_of_south_america/muisca_and_tairona.aspx ''Tunjo'' in the British Museum]</ref><ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/97014/Standing_Human_Figure ''Tunjo'' in the Brooklyn Museum]</ref><ref>[http://www.clevelandart.org/art/collection/search?collection_search_query=Muisca&op=search&form_build_id=form-3WgOItA0qaUGYiZm6xMQ6LfA3trcjs3GrhBh06xEja4&form_id=clevelandart_collection_search_form ''Tunjos'' in the Cleveland Art Museum]</ref><ref>[https://www.dma.org/collection/search?color_hex_exact=%23edc9af&medium_exact=tumbaga&artist_creator_exact=muisca ''Tunjos'' in the Dallas Museum of Art]</ref><ref>[http://www.huntmuseum.com/collection/collection-items/hcm-309.aspx ''Tunjo'' in Hunt Museum]</ref><ref>[http://metmuseum.org/art/collection/search#!/search?artist=Chibcha ''Tunjos'' in the Metropolitan Museum of Art]</ref><ref>[https://collections.mfah.org/art/search?culture=Muisca&artist=Muisca&show=50 ''Tunjos'' in the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]</ref><ref>[http://artmuseum.princeton.edu/collections/objects/30948 ''Tunjo'' in the Princeton University Art Museum]</ref><ref>[http://nmai.si.edu/exhibitions/infinityofnations/andes/178022.html ''Tunjo'' in the Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian]</ref> The word ''tunjo'' was used first in the literature about the Muisca in 1854, by [[List of Muisca scholars|scholar]] [[Ezequiel Uricoechea]].<ref>Londoño, 1989, p.107</ref> The figurines are mostly [[anthropomorphic]] with other examples being [[zoomorphic]]. The ''tunjos'' were mostly elaborated using ''[[tumbaga]]''; an alloy of [[gold]], [[copper]] and [[silver]], some with [[trace element|traces]] of [[lead]] or [[iron]].<ref name=Museo/> The majority of ceramic or stone ''tunjos'' has been described from [[Mongua]], close to [[Sogamoso]].<ref>Sánchez, s.a., p.3</ref> The ''tunjos'' served three purposes; as decoration of temples and shrines, for offering rituals in the sacred lakes and rivers in the [[Muisca religion]], and as pieces in funerary practices; to accompany the dead to the afterlife.<ref name=Museo>{{es}} [http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/historia/meaneg/meaneg8.htm Description and metallurgy of ''tunjos''] - [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]] - [[Bogotá]]</ref> Ceramic human ''tunjos'' were kept in the houses (''bohíos'') of the Muisca, together with [[emerald]]s.<ref name=Pena_p8>Peña Gama, p.8</ref>
The precious metals silver and gold were not common in the Eastern Ranges, while copper was mined in [[Gachantivá]], [[Moniquirá]] and in the mountains to the south of the Bogotá savanna at [[Sumapaz]]. The process of elaborating the fine [[filigree]] figures took place by creating a mold of obsidian, shale or clay, filling the open space with bee wax, obtained through [[Muisca economy#Trade|trade]] with the neighbouring indigenous peoples from the [[Orinoquía Region|Llanos Orientales]] to the east of the Altiplano; the [[Achagua people|Achagua]], [[Tegua people|Tegua]] and [[Guayupe people|Guayupe]]. The bee wax occupied the voids of the mold and the mold was heated by fires. The bee wax would melt, leaving an open space where the ''tumbaga'' or sometimes gold was poured into, a process called [[lost-wax casting]].<ref name=Museo/> Using this method, modern ''tunjos'' are still fabricated in the centre of Bogotá.<ref name=CooperLangebaek>Cooper & Langebaek Rueda, 2013</ref>
Between 1577 and 1583, various colonial writers have reported in their chronicles the use of ''tunjos'' for offering pieces. The descriptions from the early colonial period of the [[New Kingdom of Granada]] have been collected first by Vicenta Cortés Alonso in 1958 and later by Ulises Rojas in 1965. The reports of the late 16th century show that the religious practices of the Muisca were still alive, despite the intensive catholic conversion policies.<ref>Londoño, 1989, p.93</ref> ''Caciques'' of [[Tuta, Boyacá|Tuta]], [[Toca, Boyacá|Toca]], [[Duitama]], [[Lake Iguaque|Iguaque]], [[Ramiriquí]], [[Paz de Río|Chitagoto]], [[Onzaga]], [[Tunja]] and [[Cucunubá]] participated in these rituals.<ref>Londoño, 1989, p.94-117</ref> The religious leader of [[Sogamoso]] was still the most important in these days.<ref>Londoño, 1989, p.98</ref>
<gallery mode=packed heights=150px> File:Museo del oro, Bogotá, Colombia - Muisca Votives Figures.jpg|Collection of ''tunjos'' File:BOG 04 2012 Museo de Oro 1237.JPG|''Tunjo'' formed by parents with children File:Muisca Tunjo 2 - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|''Tunjo'' File:Musée del Oro (23).JPG|''Tunjo'' decorated with earrings File:Museo del oro, Bogotá, Colombia - Muisca Votive Figure.jpg|''Tunjo'' of a mother with baby in her arms File:Muisca Tunjo Animal - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|Zoomorphic ''tunjo'' in the Museo del Oro File:Muisca Molds 2 - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|Mold used for the elaboration of ''tunjos'' </gallery>
==== Muisca raft ==== [[File:Muisca raft - detail - Museo del Oro, Bogotá.jpg|right|300px|thumb|'''Muisca raft''' in the Museo del Oro, Bogotá]] {{main article|Muisca raft}} The Muisca raft is the masterpiece of the Muisca goldworking and has become illustrative for the fine techniques used. The {{convert|19.1|cm|in}} by {{convert|10|cm|in}} object was found in 1969 in a ceramic pot hidden in a cave in the municipality of [[Pasca, Cundinamarca|Pasca]], in the southwest of the Bogotá savanna and has become the centerpiece in the [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]] in Bogotá.<ref>{{es}} [http://banrep.org/museo/esp/expo_bogota4.htm Exposición del Museo del Oro en Bogotá] - [[Banco de la República]]</ref><ref>{{es}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZcXgRApLxfM Explanation of the metallurgy of the Muisca raft by Eduardo Londoño] - [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]]</ref> The raft is interpreted as picturing the initiation ritual of the new ''[[zipa]]'' in the sacred [[Lake Guatavita]], where the new ruler would cover himself in gold dust and jump from a small boat into the waters of the {{convert|3000|m|ft}} high post-glacial lake to honour the gods. This ceremony was accompanied by priests (Muysccubun: ''xeque'') and formed the basis for the ''[[El Dorado]]'' legend that drew the Spanish [[List of conquistadors in Colombia|conquistadors]] towards the high Andes. The raft has been constructed using the lost-wax casting method and is made of ''tumbaga'' of around 80% gold, 12% silver and 8% copper.<ref name=secrets2013>{{Cite AV media|title=Secrets: Golden Raft of El Dorado|year=2013|publisher=Smithsonian Channel|time=27 minutes, 11 seconds}}</ref> It contains 229 grams of gold.
The Muisca raft is also featured in the coat of arms of two municipalities of Cundinamarca; [[Sesquilé]], where Lake Guatavita is located, and Pasca, where the raft was found.<ref>{{es}} [http://www.sesquile-cundinamarca.gov.co/nuestromunicipio.shtml?apc=M1d1--&m=f&s=m#simbolos Official website Sesquilé]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{es}} [http://pasca-cundinamarca.gov.co/nuestromunicipio.shtml?apc=mfxx1-&m=f#simbolos Official website Pasca]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{multiple image | align = center
| image1 = Escudo de Sesquilé.svg | width1 = 150 | alt1 = Sesquilé | link1 = Sesquilé | caption1 = <center>Coat of arms of Sesquilé</center>
| image2 = Diosa Guatavita.jpg | width2 = 440 | alt2 = Lake Guatavita | link2 = Lake Guatavita | caption2 = <center>Lake Guatavita</center>
| image3 = Escudo de Pasca (Cundinamarca).svg | width3 = 150 | alt3 = Pasca, Cundinamarca | link3 = Pasca, Cundinamarca | caption3 = <center>Coat of arms of Pasca</center>
| footer = <center>The Muisca raft is thought to represent the initiation ritual of the new ''zipa'' in '''Lake Guatavita, Sesquilé''' and has been found hidden in a cave in '''Pasca''', both in [[Cundinamarca Department|Cundinamarca]]</center> }} {{clearboth}}
==== Jewelry ==== [[File:TISQUESUSA1.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The rich jewelry is shown in a 19th-century interpretation of ''zipa'' '''Tisquesusa''', the ruler of ''Bacatá'' in 1537, when the Spanish arrived]] The Muisca society was in essence egalitarian with slight differences in terms of use of jewelry. The [[guecha warrior]]s, priests and ''caciques'' were allowed to wear multiple types of jewelry, while the common people used less jewels. Golden or ''tumbaga'' jewelry existed of [[diadem]]s, nose pieces, breast plates, earrings, pendants, [[tiara]]s, bracelets and masks.<ref name=Pena_p8/>
{{center|<gallery mode=packed> File:BOG 04 2012 Museo de Oro Gold Mask 1219.jpg|Golden Muisca mask, Museo del Oro File:Muisca Nariguera - Nose Piece - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|Golden Muisca ''nariguera'' (nose piece) displayed in the Museo del Oro File:Museo Del Oro, Bogota (24799274060).jpg|The Muisca wore golden bracelets File:Estatua a los indígenas 2014-09-13.JPG|Guecha warriors wore jewelry </gallery>}}
=== Architecture === [[File:ParqueArqueológicoSogamoso.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The '''''bohíos''''' of the Muisca were circular and constructed on a slightly elevated platform against flooding. The roofs were made of plant material and the houses did not have rooms, yet one open space]] [[File:Malay Archipelago Dyak crossing a bamboo bridge.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The many rivers were crossed by the Muisca using vines and '''bamboo''']] {{main article|Muisca architecture}} While the other three grand pre-Columbian civilisations—the Maya, Aztec and Inca—are known for their grand architecture in the form of pyramids, stelae, stone cities and temples, the modest Muisca architecture has left very little traces in the present.<ref name=Langebaek2003_p265>Langebaek Rueda, 2003, p.265</ref> The houses (called ''bohíos'' or ''malokas'') and temples of the people, where spiritual gatherings took place honouring the gods and sacrificing ''tunjos'', emeralds and children, were made of degradable materials such as wood, clay and reed. The circular structures were built on top of slightly elevated platforms to prevent them from flooding on the frequently inundated plains; small settlements of ten to one hundred houses were surrounded by wooden poles forming an enclosure, called ''ca'' in [[Chibcha language|Muysccubun]].<ref>Broadbent, 1974, p.120</ref><ref>{{es}} [http://muysca.cubun.org/ca ''ca''] - Muysccubun dictionary online</ref> Two or more gates gave entrance to the villages.<ref>Langebaek Rueda, 1995a, p.8</ref> The houses and temples themselves were built around a central pole of wood attached to the roof; the temples were constructed using the wood of ''[[Guaiacum officinale]]'' tree, giving high quality construction.<ref>Henderson & Ostler, 2005, p.156</ref> The floors of the open spaced houses were covered with straw or, for the ''caciques'', with ceramic floors.<ref>Ocampo López, 2007, Ch.V, p.203</ref><ref>Cardale de Schrimpff, 1985, p.116</ref> Cloths were attached to the roof and painted with red and black colours. The houses and sacred places were adorned with ''tunjos'' and emeralds, and in some cases with the remains of [[Muisca religion#Sacrifice|human sacrifices]].<ref>Henderson & Ostler, 2005, p.157</ref>
====Roads==== The roads the Muisca merchants and ''xeques'' used to traverse the Altiplano and access surrounding areas, were dug in the top soil without pavement, making them hard to recognise in the archaeological record. The roads leading to the religious sites, such as [[Lake Tota]], were marked with stones surrounding the pathway, which are still visible today.<ref>Cristancho Mejía, 2008, p.4</ref> Cable bridges of vines and [[Olyra (plant)|bamboo]] connected the banks of the many rivers of the Andes. The roads crossing the mountains of the Eastern Ranges were narrow, which created a problem for the [[List of conquistadors in Colombia|Spanish conquistadors]] who used horses to travel long distances.<ref>Langebaek Rueda, 1995b, Ch.1</ref>
====Remaining antiquities==== A few structures built by the Muisca still exist today; the [[Cojines del Zaque]] ("cushions of the zaque") in [[Tunja]] are two round stones with inclined upper parts used for religious ceremonies. Of the [[Goranchacha Temple]], a circle of pillars remained, located on the terrains of the [[UPTC]], also in Tunja. The holiest temple of the Muisca, the [[Sun Temple (Sogamoso)|Sun Temple]] in sacred City of the Sun [[Sogamoso|Suamox]] had been destroyed by fire when the Spanish conquerors looted the shrine and has been rebuilt based on archaeological research by [[Eliécer Silva Celis]]. The temple is part of the [[Archaeology Museum, Sogamoso|Archaeology Museum]] of the city in Boyacá.<ref name=PueblosSogamoso>{{es}} [http://pueblosoriginarios.com/sur/caribe/muisca/sogamoso.html Temple of the Sun - Sogamoso] - Pueblos Originarios</ref>
<gallery mode=packed> File:Templo del sol.jpg|The Sun Temple in ''Suamox'' was the most important temple for the Muisca File:Cojines del Zaque. Vista actual (2015).JPG|The Cojines del Zaque in Tunja (''Hunza'') File:Escudo de Sopó.jpg|Muisca ''bohíos'' are depicted in the upper right of the seal of [[Sopó]] </gallery>
=== Mummies === [[File:Momia-museo-del-oro-2500px.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The '''Muisca mummies''' were placed in a typical position, with the hands in front of the chin and the legs folded onto the abdomen]] {{main article|Muisca mummification}} Mummification was a tradition that many other pre-Columbian civilisations practiced. On the Altiplano, the habit of conserving the dead started in the Herrera Period, around the 5th century AD.<ref name=Ortega_p8/> The Muisca continued this culture and prepared their deceased beloved members of the society by putting the bodies above fires. The heat would dry the body and the [[phenol]] conserve the organs and protect them from decomposition, a process that took up to eight hours.<ref name=Martinez2012_p71>Martínez & Martínez, 2012, p.71</ref> After drying, the bodies were wrapped in cotton cloths and placed in caves, buried, or in some cases placed on elevated platforms inside temples, such as the [[Sun Temple (Sogamoso)|Sun Temple]].<ref name=Martinez2012_p68/><ref>Rodríguez Cuenca, 2007, p.115</ref><ref>Izquierdo Peña, 2009, p.13</ref> The position of the mummies was with their arms folded across the chest and the hands around the chin, while the legs were placed over the abdomen. During the preparation of the mummies, the Muisca played music and sang songs honouring their dead. The habit of mummification continued well into the [[New Kingdom of Granada|colonial period]]; the youngest mummies found date from the second half of the 18th century.<ref name=Martinez2012_p68>Martínez & Martínez, 2012, p.68</ref><ref>Henderson & Ostler, 2005, p.149</ref><ref>García, 2012, p.27</ref><ref name=Martinez2012_p74>Martínez & Martínez, 2012, p.74</ref>
To prepare the dead for the afterlife, the mummies were surrounded with ceramic pots containing food, ''tunjos'' and cotton bags and mantles.<ref name=Ortega_p8>Ortega Loaiza et al., 2012, p.8</ref> The [[guecha warrior]]s were richly venerated with golden arms, crowns, emeralds and cotton.<ref name=Martinez2012_p72>Martínez & Martínez, 2012, p.72</ref> When the ''caciques'' and ''zaque'' and ''zipa'' died, their mummified bodies were placed in mausoleums and surrounded with golden objects. The highest regarded members of society were accompanied by their [[Women in Muisca society#Polygamy|many wives]], by [[Muisca warfare|slaves]] and their children. The mummy of a baby described from a cave in [[Gámeza]], Boyacá, had a [[teether]] around the neck.<ref name=Martinez2012_p69>Martínez & Martínez, 2012, p.69</ref> Other mummies of children were richly decorated with gold and placed in caves, as was the case with a young girl described by [[Liborio Zerda]].<ref name=Martinez2012_p71/>
The art of mummification was also practiced by other [[Chibcha language|Chibcha-speaking]] groups in the Eastern Ranges; the [[Guane people|Guane]] mummies are well studied, and also the [[U'wa people|U'wa]] and farther north the [[Chitarero people|Chitarero]] of the department of [[Norte de Santander]] mummified their dead.<ref name=BancoMomia>{{es}} [http://www.banrepcultural.org/museo-del-oro/coleccion/D00009 Momia] - [[Banco de la República]]</ref><ref name=Villa_p52>Villa Posse, 1993, p.52</ref> The Carib-speaking [[Muzo people|Muzo]] buried their mummies with the head towards the west, while the [[Zenú]] and [[Panche people|Panche]], like the Muisca commonly oriented the faces of their mummies to the east. Some of the Muisca mummies were directed towards the south.<ref name=GranEpoca>{{es}} [http://www.lagranepoca.com/archivo/30748-estudio-tumbas-muiscas-evoca-mito-leyenda-del-dorado.html Estudio de tumbas Muiscas evoca el mito de la Leyenda del Dorado]</ref>
When the guecha warriors fought battles with neighbouring groups, most notably the Panche, and also against the Spanish conquistadors, they carried the mummies of their ancestors on their backs, to impress the enemy and receive fortune in battle.<ref name=Martinez2012_p68/><ref name=Martinez2012_p72/><ref>Martínez Martín, s.a., p.3</ref><ref>Correa, 2005, p.204</ref><ref>Trimborn, 2005, p.305</ref>
<gallery mode=packed heights=150px> File:Muisca Mummy Textile Bag - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|Cotton Muisca textile bag, accompanying the Muisca mummy File:Museo Del Oro, Bogota (25094844355).jpg|Small ceramic pots surrounded the mummies and contained food for the afterlife File:Corn spiral steps.jpg|Maize </gallery>
=== Music and dance === [[File:Golden Trumpet - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|right|thumb|300px|'''Trumpets''' were made of ceramics or of '''gold''' as in this case in the Muisca exhibition of the Museo del Oro]] {{main article|Muisca music}} The Muisca played music, sang and danced mainly as part of religious, burial and initiation rituals, with harvests and sowing and after the victory in [[Muisca warfare|battles]].<ref name=Ocampo_p230>Ocampo López, 2007, Ch.V, p.230</ref><ref name=Ocampo_p231>Ocampo López, 2007, Ch.V, p.231</ref> Also during the construction of their houses, the Muisca performed music and dances. The early Spanish chronicles noted that the music and singing was monotonous and sad.<ref>{{es}} [http://tierradevientos.blogspot.com.co/2011/06/musica-andina-en-colombia.html Monotonous music of the Muisca]</ref> As musical instruments they used drums, flutes made of shells or ceramics, trumpets of gold, [[Siku (instrument)|zampoñas]] and ocarinas.<ref>{{es}} [http://www.banrepcultural.org/bogot/evento/ritual-m-sica-y-sacrificios-humanos-en-los-muiscas-del-siglo-xvi Music of the Muisca] - [[Banco de la República]]</ref> At the rituals, the people would be dressed in feathers, animal skins (mainly [[jaguar]]) and decorated their bodies with paint. At the dances the women and men held hands and both the commoners and the higher social classes participated in these activities. The main [[Muisca religion|deities]] associated with the dances were [[Huitaca (goddess)|Huitaca]] and [[Nencatacoa]].<ref name=Escobar>Escobar, 1987</ref><ref>Ocampo López, 2007, Ch.V, p.221</ref><ref>{{es}} [http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-5089300 Huitaca, la diosa muisca en el Palacio Liévano] - [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]</ref>
=== Ceramics === [[File:Múcuras precolombinas.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Collection of '''ceramic vases''' (''múcuras'') made by the Muisca]] {{see also|Muisca economy#Ceramics}} The use of ceramics on the Altiplano started in the Herrera Period, with the oldest evidences of ceramic use dated at 3000 BP. The many different clays of the rivers and lakes of the valleys on the high plateau made a variety of ceramic types possible.
The Muisca constructed ceramic pottery for cooking, the extraction of [[halite|salt]] from brines, as decorative ritual pieces and for the consumption of their alcoholic beverage; [[Chicha#Colombia|chicha]]. Large ceramic jars were found around the sacred [[Muisca astronomy|archaeoastronomical site]] of ''[[El Infiernito]]'', used for massive rituals where the people celebrated their festivities drinking chicha.<ref name=Langebaek_p291>Langebaek Rueda, 2005, p.291</ref> Also [[Muisca music|musical instruments]] such as [[ocarina]]s were made of ceramics. The ceramic pots and sculptures were painted with zoomorphic figures that were common in the Muisca territory; [[frog]]s, [[armadillo]]s, [[snake]]s and [[lizard]]s. Main ceramic production centres were located close to the abundance of clays, in [[Tocancipá]], [[Gachancipá]], [[Cogua]], [[Guatavita]], [[Guasca]] and [[Ráquira]].<ref name=Pena_p8/>
<gallery mode=packed heights=180px> File:Muisca Ceramic + Tunjos - Museo del Oro - Bogotá.jpg|Ceramic bowl and ''tunjos'', Museo del Oro, Bogotá File:Mascara precolombina.JPG|Ceramic mask of the Muisca, Museo Nacional, Bogotá File:Museo Del Oro, Bogota (24976513622).jpg|Muisca ceramics is characterised by the typical shapes of eyes and mouth </gallery> {{clearboth}}
=== Textiles === [[File:Curaca, Autoridad Tradicional Indígena, Zippasgo Inga Chibcha Wuanentá Hunzaá, Gobernante Zaque Orinoco Amazonía, Centro y Sur Andino.jpg|right|300px|thumb|'''Precious feathers''' were obtained through trading with more tropical areas and '''cotton mantles''' elaborated by the Muisca from raw cotton traded with mainly the [[Guane people|Guane]] in the north]] [[File:Bixa orellana fruit roucou kourou 2.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The red fruits of the '''achiote''' plant (''Bixa orellana'') were widely used as paint; for textiles, rock art and tattoos]] {{see also|Muisca economy#Weaving}} The Muisca, as the indigenous groups in the west of Colombia, developed a variety of textiles from [[fique]] or [[cotton]].<ref>Ocampo López, 1970, p.88</ref><ref name=Fernandez_p289>Fernández Sacama, 2013, p.289</ref> Cords were made of fique or human hair.<ref name=Fernandez_p289/> The people of the cold climate Altiplano did not have a major [[cotton]] production, yet traded most of their cotton with their neighbours; the [[Muzo people|Muzo]] in the west, [[Panche people|Panche]] in the southwest, [[Guane people|Guane]] in the northwest, and the [[Guayupe people|Guayupe]] in the east.<ref name=Fernandez_p289/> From the raw cotton, the [[Women in Muisca society|Muisca women]] made fine cotton mantles that were traded on the many markets in the Muisca territory.<ref>Francis, 1993, p.39</ref>
The mantles of the Muisca were decorated with various colours. The colours were obtained from seeds; the seed of the [[avocado]] for green, flowers; [[saffron]] for orange and [[Baptisia australis|indigo weed]] for blue, fruits, crust and roots of plants, from animals as the [[cochineal]] insect producing purple colours, and minerals as the blue and green clays of [[Siachoque]], the coloured earth of [[Sutamarchán|Suta]] and the yellow sediments of [[Soracá]].<ref name=Fernandez_p290>Fernández Sacama, 2013, p.290</ref> Also [[curuba]], the flowers of the [[potato]] plant (''[[Solanum andigenum]]'') and other colouring materials (''[[Rumex obtusifolia]]'', ''[[Bixa orellana]]'', ''[[Arrabidaea chica]]'' and more) were used.<ref name=Cortes_p62>Cortés Moreno, 1990, p.62</ref> The colours were applied using pencils, applying coloured threads or using stamps.<ref name=Fernandez_p291>Fernández Sacama, 2013, p.291</ref> The textiles were produced using various techniques, similar to the [[Aymara people|Aymara]] of southern South America and the Mesoamerican cultures.<ref name=Cortes_p64>Cortés Moreno, 1990, p.64</ref> Small textiles functioned as money, just like the ''[[Muisca economy#Trade|tejuelos]]'' of gold or [[Nemocón|salt]] was used.<ref>Francis, 1993, p.44</ref>
The culture of mantle-making in the [[Muisca mythology]] is said to have been taught by [[Bochica]], who trained the people in the use of [[spindle (textiles)|spindles]].<ref name=Fernandez_p287>Fernández Sacama, 2013, p.287</ref> [[Nencatacoa]] protected the weavers and painters of the mantles.<ref name=Fernandez_p288>Fernández Sacama, 2013, p.288</ref>
{{left|<gallery mode=packed heights=180px> File:Dactylopius coccus (Barlovento) 04 ies.jpg|Cochineal lice were used to obtain purple colours File:Ruana.JPG|The [[ruana]] was a special kind of Muisca mantle, similar to the poncho<br>''note: this is a modern version'' File:Atuendo Guane, Algodón Crudo.jpg|As the Guane, the Muisca made long mantles to protect them from the cold climate File:Muisca spindle whorl.jpg|The Muisca used spindle whorls to keep the mantles in place </gallery>}} {{clearleft}}
=== Hieroglyphs === [[File:Muisca cyphers acc acosta humboldt zerda.svg|thumb|right|300px|While the Muisca didn't have a formal script, they used hieroglyphs for their '''numerals''', depicted as rock art, on ceramics and textiles]] {{main article|Muisca numerals}} A script for text was not used by the Muisca, but the numerals were written with hieroglyphs. They have been analysed by various authors, such as [[Joaquín Acosta]], [[Alexander von Humboldt]] and [[Liborio Zerda]], and appear as rock art and on textiles. The frog is the most important and is represented in the numbers from one (''ata'') to twenty (''gueta'') five times, because the Muisca didn't have hieroglyphs for the numbers 11 to 19, so used the numerals one to nine again in combination with ten; fifteen was thus ten-and-five; ''qhicħâ hɣcſcâ''.<ref name=Humb1>Humboldt, 1807, Part 1</ref><ref name=Lugo>{{es}} [http://www.cubun.org/desarrollos/numeros.php Muisca numbers according to Bernardo de Lugo]</ref>
=== Body art === Tattoos were common for the Muisca and an expression of their identity.<ref>Pineda Camacho, 2005, p.26</ref><ref>{{es}} [http://loschibchasomuiscas.blogspot.com.co/ Los Chibchas o Muiscas]</ref> The people used ''[[Bixa orellana]]'' to paint their bodies, just like the [[Arawak peoples|Arawak]], [[Island Caribs|Carib]] and [[Tupi people|Tupi]].<ref name=Uscategui_p336>Uscategui Mendoza, 1961, p.336</ref>
=== Rock art === [[File:Chía Bogotá May 2016.jpg|thumb|right|300px|'''Chía''', the Moon goddess, was one of the most important deities for the Muisca and represented as circles in their rock art]] [[File:Nicotiana tabacum 003.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The '''tobacco plant''', used by the Muisca and their neighbours, is represented in petrographs]] [[File:Facatativa vandalized pictograph.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The rock art of the '''Piedras del Tunjo''' Archaeological Park in Facatativá is heavily '''vandalised''']] Many examples of rock art by the Muisca have been discovered on the Altiplano. The first rock art has been discovered by [[conquistador]] [[Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada]] during the [[Spanish conquest of the Muisca]].<ref name=Munoz_p5>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.5</ref> The [[rock art]] consists of [[petroglyphs]] (carvings) and [[petrograph]]s (drawings). The petrographs were made using the [[index finger]].<ref name=Rico_p88>Rico Ramírez, 2013, p.88</ref> Pioneer in the study of the rock art has been [[Miguel Triana]].<ref>Triana, 1922</ref> Later contributions have been done by Diego Martínez, [[Eliécer Silva Celis]] and others.<ref name=Rico_p87>Rico Ramírez, 2013, p.87</ref> It is theorised that the rock art has been made under the influence of [[ayahuasca]] (yahé).<ref name=Rico_p84>Rico Ramírez, 2013, p.84</ref>
The rock art of Soacha-Sibaté, in the southwest of the Bogotá savanna, has been studied in detail between 1970 and 2006, after initial studies by Triana.<ref name=Munoz_p5/><ref name=Munoz_p2>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.2</ref> In these petrographs certain motives have been described; ''triangular heads'' are pictographs of human figures where the heads are painted in a triangular shape. They are applied using red colours and demonstrate various sizes. Similar motives are noted in [[Mongua]], [[Tenjo]] and [[Tibacuy]].<ref name=Munoz_p14>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.14</ref> In most cases of the rock art on the Altiplano, the body extremities, such as hands, are shown in simple shapes. In some cases however, the hands are elaborated with much more detail using spirals, concentric circles and more strokes, identified as ''complex hands''. Apart from Sibaté, these shapes are encountered also in [[Saboyá]] and [[Tibaná]] in Boyacá.<ref name=Munoz_p15>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.15</ref> A third class of petrographs has been named ''radial representations''. This motive shows the main figures with concentric square or circular lines drawn around them.<ref name=Munoz_p16>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.16</ref> The concentric circular drawings have been interpreted as representing the main deities of the Muisca religion; [[Chía (goddess)|Chía]] (the Moon) and [[Sué]], her husband the Sun.<ref name=Contreras_p148>Contreras Díaz, 2011, p.148</ref> ''Rhomboidal motives'' are found in Sibaté, but their exact purpose has not yet been concluded.<ref name=Munoz_p17>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.17</ref> Both in Soacha and in Sibaté a fifth type of petrographs has been identified; ''winged figures''. These motives resemble the birds that are described in ''tunjos'' and ceramics of the Altiplano.<ref name=Munoz_p17/>
The same scholar has performed detailed analysis of the rock art in Facatativá; the [[Piedras del Tunjo Archaeological Park]]. The many petrographs in this location are painted using red, yellow, ochre, blue, black and white colours.<ref name=Munoz2013_p42>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.42</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p44>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.44</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p45/><ref name=Munoz2013_p55>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.55</ref> The motives show a possible [[tobacco]] plant, commonly used by the Muisca, zig-zag patterns, anthropomorphic figures, concentric lines similar to those in Soacha and Sáchica, zoomorphic motives and anthropo-zoomorphic composites in the shape of frogs.<ref name=Munoz2013_p45>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.45</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p55/><ref name=Munoz2013_p43>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.43</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p48>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.48</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p49>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.49</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p58>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.58</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p59>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.59</ref><ref name=Munoz2013_p63>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.63</ref>
Research in the 1960s by [[Eliécer Silva Celis]] on the rock art of Sáchica showed [[Plant morphology|phytomorphic]] designs, masked human figures, singular and concentric rings, triangulated heads, and faces where the eyes and noses were drawn, but the mouths absent.<ref>Silva Celis, 1962, p.14</ref> The majority of the petrographs found here are abstract figures.<ref>Silva Celis, 1962, p.19</ref> The colours red, black and white dominate the rock paintings in Sáchica. The black has been analysed also at ''El Infiernito'' and is though to refer to a pre-Muisca origin.<ref>Silva Celis, 1962, p.20</ref> Radial structures drawn on the heads of the anthropomorphic petrographs are interpreted as feathers.<ref>Silva Celis, 1962, p.23</ref> Feathers were precious objects for the Muisca and used by the ''xeques'' and ''caciques'' during the ''El Dorado'' ritual in Lake Guatavita.<ref>Silva Celis, 1962, p.27</ref>
Hand imprints, similar to the famous [[Cueva de las Manos]] in Argentina, yet less pronounced and in quantity, have been discovered on rock faces in Soacha and [[Motavita]].<ref>Martínez & Botiva, 2004b, p.13-14</ref>
==== Muisca rock art on the Altiplano ==== As of 2006, 3487 locations of rock art had been discovered in Cundinamarca alone, of which 301 on the [[Bogotá savanna]].<ref name=Munoz_p10>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.10</ref> Other locations have been found over the years.<ref name=ICANH/><ref name="Munoz_p10"/><ref name=Botiva>Martínez & Botiva, 2004a</ref><ref>López Estupiñán, 2011</ref><ref>Martínez & Botiva, 2004b, p.15</ref> The rock art of the Archaeological Park of Facatativá is heavily vandalised.<ref name=Munoz2013_p11>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.11</ref> Plans for the preservation of the unique cultural heritage have been formulated since the mid 2000s.<ref name=Munoz2013_p23>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2013, p.23</ref> The petrographs of [[Soacha]] are endangered by the [[mining]] activities in the fastly growing [[suburb]] of [[Bogotá]], as is happening with other mining districts; [[Chía, Cundinamarca|Chía]], [[Sibaté]], [[Tunja]], [[Sáchica]] and others.<ref name=Munoz_p3>Muñoz Castiblanco, 2006, p.3</ref>

== Modern Muisca-based art == [[File:Mural titulado "Teogonía de los Dioses Chibchas" del maestro Luis Alberto Acuña, ubicado en el Hotel Tequendama.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Detail of the '''mural''' in the lobby of [[Hotel Tequendama]], Bogotá; showing a seated [[Bochica]] and various other deities of the [[Muisca religion]]]] In the centre of Bogotá the process of production of ''[[tunjo]]s'' is still alive. Using the same methods as the Muisca must have used, the votive offer figurines are crafted.<ref name=CooperLangebaek/> Artistic representations of Muisca creativity are not as common as the Maya, Aztec and Inca. Still, modern interpretations of their art are produced. In [[Bosa (Bogotá)|Bosa]], a locality in the west of [[Bogotá]], a [[mural]] depicts the various [[Muisca religion#Deities|deities]]. Another mural showing the gods and goddesses of the Muisca is made in the [[Hotel Tequendama]], named after [[Andean preceramic|preceramic]] archaeological site and rock shelter [[Tequendama]], in the centre of Bogotá. Other stylistic art of these deities are produced by professional graphic designers in Colombia.<ref>Guzmán, 2012</ref> The Muisca are featured as one of the [[List of Europa Universalis IV playable nations|playable nations]] in the videogame ''[[Europa Universalis IV]]'', where a specially developed expansion set ''[[El Dorado]]'' can be played; seven cities of gold in the Americas with the leaders of the main civilisations represented.<ref name=EUDorado>[https://www.paradoxplaza.com/europa-universalis-iv-el-dorado ''El Dorado'' expansion set] - [[Paradox Interactive]] - ''[[Europa Universalis IV]]''</ref> In the main game, all the [[Muisca rulers]], from [[Michuá]] and [[Meicuchuca]] till [[Tisquesusa]], [[Sagipa]] and [[Aquiminzaque]] are included. [[Conquest of Paradise (DLC)]], about the conquest of the New World, is another expansion for the world diplomacy and strategy game. Other names are [[Bogotá|Bacatá]], [[Busbanzá]], [[Cerinza]], [[Charalá]], [[Chipatá, Santander|Chipatá]], Cuxininegua, [[Duitama]], [[Guecha warrior|Guecha]], ''[[iraca]]'', [[Onzaga]], [[Paipa]], [[Saboyá]], [[Soacha]], [[Tenza Valley|Tenza]], [[Tibaná|Tibana]], [[Tibiritá|Tibirita]], [[Toca, Boyacá|Toca]], [[Thomagata|Tomagata]], [[Tunduma]], [[Thomagata|Tutazúa]], [[Sutagao people|Uzathama]], ''[[zaque]]'', ''[[zipa]]'', [[Tibacuy]], [[Aguazuque]] and [[Zipacón]].<ref name=NamesMuiscaEU4>[https://github.com/Stigni/EU/blob/master/common/countries/Muisca.txt Muisca names Europa Universalis IV] - GitHub</ref> Artist [[Zamor (artist)|Zamor]] has published about the Muisca and Colombian-Australian artist [[María Fernanda Cardoso]] made a piece about the importance of frogs within the culture, called "Dancing Frogs". In the 19th century, writer and later Colombian president [[Santiago Pérez de Manosalbas]] published a work called ''Nemequene'', about ''[[zipa]]'' [[Nemequene]]. <gallery mode=packed> File:CULTURA MUISCA.jpg|Mural in Bosa showing the different deities in the Muisca religion File:DiosaAguaBachue.jpg|Modern sculpture of Earth goddess [[Bachué]] File:Al Dios Cuitiva.JPG|Statue honouring messenger god [[Bochica]] in [[Cuítiva, Boyacá]] File:Goranchacha El hijo del Sol.jpg|Statue of the [[Muisca mythology|mythical]] [[Goranchacha]] in [[Tunja]] File:Tunjo - Club Colombia.jpg|The Colombian beer brand Club Colombia uses a ''tunjo'' as symbol File:Escudo guatativa.jpg|The seal of Guatavita bears a Muisca against a shining [[Sué]] </gallery>
{{clearboth}}

Manual of rock art of Cundinamarca |publisher=[[Colombian Institute of Anthropology and History|ICANH]] |pages=1-60 |isbn=958-8181-07-0 |language=es}} * {{cite LSA |last=Martínez Celis |first=Diego |last2=Botiva Contreras |first2=Álvaro |year=2004b |title=Introducción al arte rupestre |publisher=[[Colombian Institute of Anthropology and History|ICANH]] |pages=1-28 |language=es}} * {{cite LSA |last=Muñoz Castiblanco |first=Guillermo |year=2013 |title=Catalogación, registro sistemático y diagnóstico de las pinturas rupestres del Parque Arqueológico de Facatativá |publisher=GIPRI |pages=1-89 |language=es}} * {{cite LSA |last=Muñoz Castiblanco |first=Guillermo |year=2006 |title=Pinturas rupestres en el Altiplano Cundiboyacense, Colombia - concentración y diversidad en la Sabana de Bogotá: Municipio de Suacha-Sibaté Cundinamarca - Rock paintings on the Altiplano Cundiboyacense, Colombia - concentration and diversity on the Bogotá savanna: municipality of Soacha-Sibaté, Cundinamarca |pages=1-22 |language=es}} * {{cite LSA |last=Rico Ramírez |first=Mónica Sofía |year=2013 |title=Arte rupestre muisca, cultura e ingenio humano - Muisca's ruspestrian art, culture and human wit |journal=Revista de Tecnología |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=83-90 |publisher=[[Pontificia Lateranensis di Roma]] |language=es}} * {{cite LSA |last=[[Eliécer Silva Celis|Silva Celis]] |first=Eliécer |year=1962 |title=Pinturas rupestres precolombinas de Sáchica, Valle de Leiva - Pre-Columbian rock art of Sáchica, Leyva Valley |url=http://kt.micrositios.net/action.php?kt_path_info=ktcore.actions.document.view&fDocumentId=14208&forceopen |journal=Revista Colombiana de Antropología |volume=X |pages=9-36 |language=es |accessdate=2016-07-08}} * {{cite LSA |last=[[Miguel Triana|Triana]] |first=Miguel |year=1922 |title=La civilización Chibcha |url=https://books.google.com.co/books/about/La_civilizacion_chibcha.html?id=-uVlAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y |pages=1–222 |language=es |accessdate=2016-07-08}}
==== Modern Muisca-based art ==== * {{cite LSA |last=Guzmán |first=Daniel |year=2012 |title=Demonios & Deidades Muiscas |url=https://www.behance.net/gallery/4734781/Demonios-Deidades-Muiscas |accessdate=2016-07-08}}
== External links == {{commons category|Muisca art}} * {{es}} [http://www.banrepcultural.org/museo-del-oro/sociedades/muisca/en-el-museo Muisca art] - [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]], [[Bogotá]] * {{es}} [http://www.pueblosoriginarios.com/sur/caribe/muisca/arte.html Muisca art] - Pueblos Originarios

revision.comment: /* United States */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} '''Censorship of music''' refers to the practice of editing of [[music|musical works]] for various reasons, stemming from a wide variety of motivations, including moral, political, or religious reasons. Censorship can range from the complete government-enforced legal prohibition of a musical work, to private, voluntary removal of content when a musical work appears in a certain context.
==Motivations== ===Decency=== Songs are commonly edited for broadcast on [[radio]] and [[television]] to remove content that may be considered objectionable to an outlet's [[target audience]]—such as [[profanity]], or references to subjects such as [[sexual activity|sex]] and [[recreational drug|drug usage]]. This is typically done to comply with any relevant [[broadcast law]] or [[codes of conduct]], and to make the songs more marketable to a mainstream audience.<ref name=MIAcensdoubstandard/><ref name="npr-artofclean"/> Songs edited for content in this manner by are often referred to as a "[[clean version]]" or a "[[radio edit]]" (the latter also referring to songs that may be edited for length on radio airplay, and in the past, space limitations on 45 RPM [[vinyl record]]s).<ref name=cp-attentionspans>{{cite news|title=QuickHitz offers radio hit parade edited for short attention spans|url=http://www.theprovince.com/news/QuickHitz+offers+radio+parade+edited+short+attention+spans/10102495/story.html|accessdate=20 August 2014|agency=Canadian Press}}</ref><ref name="bbc-relaxban">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3395823.stm|title=Banned on the run|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref> Common editing techniques include distorting vocals to obscure offending words (including muting, [[bleep censor|bleeping]], and [[backmasking]]), or replacing them with alternative lyrics.<ref name="guardian-sandm">{{cite web|last=Ewing|first=Tom|title=How pop is provoking the censors again|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2011/feb/09/rihanna-lyrics-censorship-radio-one|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=July 23, 2011}}</ref>
The amount of censorship required may vary between broadcasters, depending on [[standards and practices]] and their target audience; for example, [[Radio Disney]] imposes stricter content guidelines than conventional U.S. radio stations, as it primarily targets a youth audience and family listening.<ref name="bbc-relaxban"/><ref name="npr-artofclean">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/11/08/454606994/the-art-of-the-clean-version|title=The Art Of The 'Clean Version'|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref> By contrast, some radio stations may relegate unedited versions of tracks containing objectionable content to airplay during [[Watershed (broadcasting)|time periods deemed appropriate]], such as late-night hours.<ref name="bbc-relaxban"/> Joel Mullis, an Atlanta sound engineer who became well-known in the industry for his work on radio edits, noted that his job was often complicated by differing standards between broadcasters (such as [[BET]] and [[MTV]]), requiring different edits to meet their individual needs. Mullis' edit of the [[Ying Yang Twins]]' "[[Wait (The Whisper Song)]]" was constructed by splicing in vocals from other Ying Yang Twins songs, but Mullis eventually had to bring the group back to his studio after facing demands for additional edits.<ref name="npr-artofclean"/>
In some cases, a [[record label]] may choose to withhold a release entirely if they believe that its subject matter would be too controversial; [[Ice-T]] and [[Paris (rapper)|Paris]] both had [[gangsta rap]] albums withheld or indefinitely delayed by [[Warner Bros. Records]] over content concerns, with Ice-T's [[Home Invasion (album)|''Home Invasion'']] delayed due to the [[1992 Los Angeles riots]] and controversy over "[[Cop Killer (song)|Cop Killer]]"—a song by Ice-T's metal band [[Body Count (band)|Body Count]], and Paris's ''[[Sleeping with the Enemy (album)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]'' over its songs "[[George H. W. Bush|Bush]] Killa" and "Coffee, Doughnuts, & Death". [[Insane Clown Posse]] faced similar issues after they signed to [[Disney]]-owned [[Hollywood Records]]; despite compliance with the label's demands to censor specific songs and lyrics, ''[[The Great Milenko]]'' was recalled almost immediately after its release (but not before selling 18,000 copies out of 100,000 shipped). All three acts moved to different labels (including [[Priority Records]] and [[Island Records]]), which released their respective albums without objections.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/violent-j-breaks-down-insane-clown-posses-joker-card-lps-20150213/the-great-milenko-1997-20150213|title=Violent J Gives the Twisted Stories Behind ICP's Best LPs|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/1997/07/25/great-milenko/|title=The Great Milenko|date=1997-07-25|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/09/controversial-rap-album-covers/paris-sleeping-with-the-enemy|title=A History of Scandalous Rap Album Covers: Paris, Sleeping with the Enemy (1992)|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref>
==== Notable examples ==== Multiple edits of [[CeeLo Green]]'s song "[[Fuck You (CeeLo Green song)|Fuck You]]" exist, including one which changed the titular lyric to "Forget You", and one which muted "fuck" without replacing it. Green also performed a [[Parody music|parody]] of the song about [[Fox News]] in an appearance on ''[[The Colbert Report]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2010/11/10/cee-lo-green-colbert-fox-news/|title=Cee-Lo Green swaps 'Fox News' for 'F--k You' on 'Colbert'|last=|first=|date=2010-11-10|work=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129454158|title=Cee Lo's Viral Hit: Blunt and Sweet|date=August 26, 2010|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=August 27, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/web/08/30/cee.lo.song.video/index.html|title=Cee Lo's YouTube hit you won't hear on radio|last=Brown|first=Damon|date=August 30, 2010|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 30, 2010}}</ref> [[The Black Eyed Peas]] re-wrote "Let's Get Retarded"—a song from their album ''[[Elephunk]]'', as "[[Let's Get It Started]]" to serve as a promotional song for television coverage of the [[2004 NBA Playoffs]]. "Let's Get It Started" was subsequently released as a standalone single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1487022/black-eyed-peas-collaborating-with-darkness.jhtml|title=Black Eyed Peas To Make Their Own 'Walk This Way' — With The Darkness|date=14 May 2004|publisher=MTV|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref><ref name="billboard-jingles">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/super-bowl-xlvii/481117/10-hits-you-didnt-know-were-jingles|title=10 Hits You Didn't Know Were Jingles|website=Billboard|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref> When performing his song "[[Power (Kanye West song)|Power]]" on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', [[Kanye West]] similarly replaced an entire verse, which contained profanities as well as lyrics directly criticising the program (such as "Fuck ''SNL'' and the whole cast") with newly-written lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/kanye-west-power-lyrics-changed-saturday-night-live-performance-nbc-article-1.186295|title=Kanye uses 'Power' to change lyrics on 'SNL'|work=New York Daily News|access-date=2017-06-30|language=en}}</ref>
Songs containing potentially objectionable [[double entendre]]s or [[mondegreen]]s have also been subject to censorship. For example, the title and chorus of [[Britney Spears]]' single "[[If U Seek Amy]]" was intended to be misheard as "[[Sexual intercourse|F-U-C-K me]]"; her label issued a radio edit which changed the word "seek" to "see", in order to remove the wordplay.<ref name=nzherald>{{cite web | author=Guy Adams | title=Britney forced to rerecord 'sexually offensive' song | work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]| date=January 21, 2009 | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10552846 | accessdate=December 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="mtvone">{{cite web | author=Gil Kaufman | title=Britney Spears' 'If U Seek Amy' Poses Censorship Problems For Radio | work=MTV.com |publisher=MTV Networks| date=February 12, 2009 | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1602458/20090109/spears_britney.jhtml | accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref> Similar concerns were raised by radio stations over The Black Eyed Peas' "[[Don't Phunk With My Heart]]" upon its release, as the word "phunk" (a deliberate misspelling of "funk") could be misinterpreted by listeners as sounding like the word "fuck".<ref name=mtvone/> [[Meghan Trainor]] recorded an alternate version of her debut single "[[All About That Bass]]" for Radio Disney and conservative [[adult contemporary]] stations, which removed the song's suggestive metaphors.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6266667/ac-radio-disney-are-all-about-that-edited-bass|title=AC, Radio Disney Are All About That (Edited) 'Bass'|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref><ref name="npr-artofclean"/>
Censorship of music is not limited to lyrical content; [[MTV]] edited the [[M.I.A. (rapper)|M.I.A.]] song "[[Paper Planes]]" to replace sounds of gunfire in its chorus with alternative sound effects, and remove a reference to cannabis. Similar sound edits occurred when M.I.A. performed the same song on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' (broadcast by then-corporate sibling [[CBS]]). M.I.A. subsequently criticized both MTV and ''Late Show'' for censoring her song.<ref name=MIAcensdoubstandard>{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Breihan |title=M.I.A. and the Double Standard of MTV Censorship|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/statusainthood/archives/2007/12/mia_and_the_dou.php|archivedate=February 19, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219004257/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/statusainthood/archives/2007/12/mia_and_the_dou.php|dead-url=yes|work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=October 25, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="MIAPlanesBlognytobserver">{{cite web | url=http://observer.com/2007/12/tube-surfing-mias-paper-planes/ | title=Tube Surfing: M.I.A.'s 'Paper Planes' | author=Gillian Reagen | work=[[The New York Observer]] | date=December 17, 2007 | accessdate=August 29, 2008 }}</ref>
==== Criticism ==== Some listeners have expressed dissatisfaction over the editing of songs for radio airplay, arguing that it compromises the artistic integrity of the original song, and encourage listeners to seek out alternative platforms that are not subject to such censorship, such as digital streaming. At the same time, edits are considered a necessary concession to receive the radio airplay that can influence a song's overall performance.<ref name="npr-artofclean"/> [[N.W.A.]]'s debut album ''[[Straight Outta Compton]]'' (which had attracted controversy for its song "[[Fuck tha Police]]") contains a song entitled "[[Express Yourself (N.W.A song)|Express Yourself]]", which criticizes radio censorship of music as inhibiting [[free expression]], and also criticizes other rappers for releasing inoffensive songs without profanity in order to receive radio airplay. Despite its themes, "Express Yourself" is the only song on the album to not contain profanities.<ref name="smh-expressyourself"/>
=== Sensitivity === Some songs may be pulled or downplayed by broadcasters if they are considered to be inappropriate to play in the aftermath of specific events. Following the [[September 11 attacks]], many broadcasters altered their music programming for these reasons,<ref>{{cite news | last = Strauss | first = Neil | title = The Pop Life; After the Horror, Radio Stations Pull Some Songs | work= [[The New York Times]]| date = November 19, 2001 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9906E2D9153BF93AA2575AC0A9679C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all| accessdate = August 4, 2008}}</ref> such as [[iHeartMedia|Clear Channel]], whose program directors compiled an [[2001 Clear Channel memorandum|internal list]] of "lyrically questionable" songs. The list included all [[Rage Against the Machine]] songs, as well as various songs with themes related to war, destruction, flight, or [[New York City]]. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' noted several unusual choices on the list, including "[[Walk Like an Egyptian]]", two [[Cat Stevens]] songs (Stevens had converted to the [[Islamic faith]] and changed his name to Yusuf Islam), and [[John Lennon]]'s "explicitly pacifist anthem '[[Imagine (John Lennon song)|Imagine]]'".<ref>{{cite web|last=Truitt|first=Eliza|title=It's the End of the World as Clear Channel Knows It|work=[[Slate.com|Slate]]|date=September 17, 2001|url=http://slate.com/id/1008314/|accessdate=September 17, 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071015200337/http://slate.com/id/1008314/| archivedate= October 15, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="austin-imagine">{{cite web | last = Bertin | first = Michael | title = Imagine: The music business in a post-911 world | work = | publisher = ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' | date = November 30, 2001 | url = http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2001-11-30/83800/ | accessdate = April 17, 2011 }}</ref>
Following the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disaster]] in February 2003, [[Mark Wills]]' "[[19 Somethin']]" was temporarily pulled by some radio stations as it contains a lyric referencing the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|''Challenger'' disaster]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=March 2003|title=Singles minded|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OA8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA55&lpg=PA55&dq=19+Somethin+pulled+columbia+disaster&source=bl&ots=0AH0eUw4-7&sig=3-MHmFYaADmGOfeiaIBV_wn0K4Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixmsaT0ObUAhUo34MKHbvADQ4Q6AEIODAE#v=onepage|journal=Billboard|volume=|pages=55|via=}}</ref> Also that month, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s then-upcoming music video for "[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" generated controversy due to its politicized and "unpatriotic" imagery (such as a [[fashion show]] featuring women dressed in military equipment, and a scene where the singer throws a [[grenade]]-shaped [[lighter]] to a [[George W. Bush]] lookalike to light his [[cigar]]), which were considered to be especially sensitive in the wake of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Iraq war]]. Due to the negative response, Madonna pulled the video prior to its planned premiere, as she did not want to "risk offending anyone who might misinterpret the meaning of this video".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2003/04/01/madonna-pulls-controversial-american-life-video/|title=Madonna pulls controversial ''American Life'' video|date=2003-04-01|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/feb/10/antiwar.artsfeatures|title=Madonna takes swipe at Bush|last=Child|first=Ben|date=2003-02-10|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
In 2006, after [[Gary Glitter]] was convicted of child sexual abuse in [[Vietnam]], the [[National Football League]] banned the original recording of his song "[[Rock and Roll (Gary Glitter song)|Rock and Roll]]" (which was popularly played at U.S. sporting events)<ref name="SIV">{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/11/30/127693/the-vibes-of-victory-sports-fans-know-that-the-strains-of-rock-and-roll-part-ii-can-turn-chumps-to-champs|title=Sports fans know that the strains of 'Rock and Roll Part II' can turn chumps to champs|publisher=Time Inc.|author=Lisa Twyman Bessone|work=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> from being played at its games. While the NFL still allowed a [[cover version]] of the song to be played, in 2012 the league instructed its teams to "avoid" playing the song entirely, following negative reception from British media over its continued use by the [[New England Patriots]], and the possibility it could be played during [[Super Bowl XLVI]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/6273999/why-convicted-child-sex-offender-gary-glitters-hey|title=Why Convicted Child-Sex Offender Gary Glitter’s ‘Hey Song’ Is Still Getting Played|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/gary-glitter-10-1269123|title=NFL bosses ban Gary Glitter's 'Rock And Roll Part II' from the Super Bowl|date=2012-02-02|work=NME|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
Following [[Chris Brown]]'s alleged physical altercation with his then-girlfriend [[Rihanna]], various radio stations began to voluntarily pull Brown's music from their playlists as a condemnation of his actions.<ref name="mtv-willmore">{{cite web|title=Will More Radio Stations Stop Playing Chris Brown?|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1604845/will-more-radio-stations-stop-playing-chris-brown/|website=MTV.com|accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chris Brown's songs, TV appearances yanked from air|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1604786/chris-browns-songs-tv-appearances-yanked-from-air/|website=MTV.com|accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref> In December 2013, [[HMV]] removed the entire catalogue of [[Lostprophets]] from its stores after the band's lead singer [[Ian Watkins (Lostprophets)|Ian Watkins]] was charged with thirteen sexual offences against children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/nov/29/lostprophets-removed-hmv-ian-watkins|title=Lostprophets' music removed from HMV following Ian Watkins trial|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2013-11-29|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== Legal issues === Songs and albums may, in some cases, be censored due to [[copyright]] problems (particularly related to [[Sampling (music)|sampling]]) or other legal issues. [[The KLF|The JAMs]] album ''[[1987 (What the Fuck Is Going On?)]]'' was withdrawn from distribution following complaints by [[ABBA]], whose music was sampled on the album without permission.<ref name=sweden87>[[James Brown (editor)|Brown, J.]], "Thank You For The Music", ''[[New Musical Express]]'', 17 October 1987.</ref> [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]'s album ''[[Ready to Die]]'' was similarly pulled following a lawsuit by [[Bridgeport Music]] over unauthorized samples.<ref name=bryantimes>{{cite news|agency=AP|title=Judge halts sales of Notorious B.I.G. album after jury finds song snippet used without permission|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VvkvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iUkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5587%2C2536180|accessdate=5 October 2013|newspaper=The Bryan Times|date=24 March 2006}}</ref><ref name=slate-sampletroll>{{cite web|last1=Wu|first1=Tim|title=Jay-Z Versus the Sample Troll: The shady one-man corporation that's destroying hip-hop|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2006/11/jayz_versus_the_sample_troll.html|website=Slate|accessdate=25 January 2016}}</ref>
By request of [[Atlantic Records]], parody musician [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] did not commercially release "[[You're Pitiful]]"—his parody of [[James Blunt]]'s song "[[You're Beautiful]]", even though Blunt himself had approved of the satire. It was subsequently released as a free single instead.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5482774| title=Free 'Weird Al' Yankovic!|accessdate=September 22, 2006 |last=Thompson| first=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Thompson (producer)|date=June 13, 2006|work=Mixed Signals|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]}}</ref>
== By country == === Australia === {{see also|Censorship in Australia}} The [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) and the Australian Music Retailers Association (AMRA) maintain a self-regulatory system known as the "Recorded Music Labelling Code of Practice", which utilizes a three-tier ratings system for objectionable content in music recordings. "Level 1" applies to content of a "moderate impact" (including "infrequent aggressive or strong coarse language; or moderate-impact references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes"), "Level 2" for "strong impact" ("frequent aggressive or strong coarse language", or strong references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes), and "Level 3" for "high impact" content (graphic and high-impact references to drug use, violence, sexual activity or themes). The Level 3 classification was introduced in March 2003, and requires purchasers to be over the age of 18. The code bans the distribution or sale of any recording with material that exceeds Level 3 classification, which includes content "which promote, incite, instruct or exploitatively or gratuitously depict drug abuse, cruelty, suicide, criminal or sexual violence, child abuse, incest, bestiality or any other revolting or abhorrent activity in a way that causes outrage or extreme disgust."<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2453315.stm |title= Australia plans CD 'censorship' |work= BBC News |date= 2002-11-12|access-date= 2018-03-22 |language= en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.aph.gov.au/parliamentary_business/committees/senate/legal_and_constitutional_affairs/completed_inquiries/2010-13/classificationboard/report/~/media/wopapub/senate/committee/legcon_ctte/completed_inquiries/2010-13/classification_board/report/c09.ashx |title= Inquiry |last=|first= |date= |website= Parliament of Australia |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date= March 21, 2018}}</ref>
Australian customs law also bans the import of any product that "describe[s], depict[s], express[es] or otherwise deal[s] with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-singapore-pornography/singapore-pilot-fined-in-australia-for-laptop-child-porn-idUKSIN10289320080213|title=Singapore pilot fined in Australia for laptop child porn|agency=Reuters|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> In 2003, copies of an album by [[grindcore]] band Intense Hammer Rage were seized by the [[Australian Customs Service]], and the three band members were each fined [[Australian dollar|AUD$]]500 each for violating customs law. The violations centred upon the abhorrent subject matter of the album's artwork and printed lyrics; the albums had been manufactured in the United States by their record label, and imported into Australia for their distribution. The band criticized the seizure as being a dilution of [[freedom of speech]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/arts/music/stories/s885891.htm|title=Does Freedom of Speech Exist in Australia?|last=|first=|date=|website=ABC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070129133906/http://www.abc.net.au/arts/music/stories/s885891.htm|archive-date=January 29, 2007|dead-url=|access-date=March 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2003-05-15/court-rules-cd-unfit-for-shelves/1854120|title=Court rules CD unfit for shelves|date=2003-05-15|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-AU}}</ref>
In May 1990, Nick Franklin, acting news director of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]'s radio station [[Triple J]], was suspended by the ABC's management after having played a portion of [[N.W.A.]]'s song "[[Fuck tha Police]]". The song had received airplay on the station for several months, but ABC Radio head Malcom Long requested that the song be given a "rest"; in the offending segment, Franklin discussed the song's vulgar lyrics and subject matter. In protest of the suspension, Triple J staff went on strike, and the station [[stunting (broadcasting)|stunted]] by playing the N.W.A. song "Express Yourself" on a loop. The stunt ended after the ABC resolved the dispute and reinstated Long.
