The song was ultimately played 82 times in a row.<ref name="smh-expressyourself">{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/express-yourself-the-day-triple-j-played-the-same-nwa-song-82-times-in-a-row-20150902-gjdk0d.html|title=Express yourself: The day Triple J played the same N.W.A. song 82 times in a row|last=Casimir|first=Paul Chamberlin and Jon|date=2015-09-02|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref>
=== Canada === {{See also|Censorship in Canada}}
In Canada, content broadcast by radio and television is self-regulated under the code of ethics of the [[Canadian Association of Broadcasters]] by a group known as the [[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] (CBSC), which acts upon complaints submitted by the general public. The [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC) can intervene in more substantial cases.<ref name=":9" />
In 2011, the [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic]] panel of the CBSC, in response to a complaint against [[CHOZ-FM]], ruled that the original version of [[Dire Straits]]' 1985 single, "[[Money for Nothing (song)|Money for Nothing]]" violated the ethics code, because of its use of the word "[[Faggot (slang)|faggot]]"—a homophobic slur. However, the CRTC called upon the CBSC to review the decision with a national panel, as it "elicited a strong public reaction and created uncertainty for private radio stations across the country." In particular, the CRTC asked the CBSC to consider the overall context of the slur in relation to the rest of the song, as well as how the word was used at the time of the song's release.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/CRTC+asks+review+Dire+Straits+song/4144591/story.html|title=CRTC asks for review of Dire Straits song ban|last=Abma|first=Derek|agency=Postmedia News|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-ca}}</ref> The CBSC overturned the ruling; while panellists agreed that the slur was inappropriate, it was considered to be satirical and non-hateful in context. It was also noted that lead singer [[Mark Knopfler]] had substituted the word himself with alternatives (such as "queenie") during live performances, which was considered an admission that his original choice in words was in bad taste. The CBSC stated that it was up to individual stations whether or not they would play the unedited version.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
The ruling and controversy were ridiculed by critics; veteran Canadian radio personality [[Alan Cross]] commented that the controversy made Canada look "silly", remarking that "I talked to people from the U.S. and the U.K. and they were like, 'What's wrong with you people? Don't you get it? It's a joke. It's a satire. You didn't understand the context?" ''[[National Post]]'' columnist Chris Selley described the CBSC's new ruling as a "comedy classic" and "colossal waste of time", explaining that "it's one thing for a censor to decide whether something is legitimately artistic; it's another for it to declare whether or not it enjoys the art, as if it somehow mattered."<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/opinion/chris-selley-broadcast-standards-ruling-on-money-for-nothing-a-comedy-classic|title=Chris Selley: Broadcast Standards ruling on Money for Nothing a comedy classic|date=2011-09-01|work=National Post|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/canada-lifts-ban-on-dire-straits-money-for-nothing-20110901|title=Canada Lifts Ban on Dire Straits' 'Money for Nothing'|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref>
=== China === {{See also|Censorship in China}} During the rule of [[Mao Zedong]], "[[Yellow Music]]" became subject to criticism and censure, since the [[Communist Party of China]] saw Shanghai ''[[shidaiqu]]'' [[C-pop|pop music]]<ref name="shanghai">{{cite web |url=http://www.scmp.com/article/367361/shanghai-love |title=From Shanghai with love |date=31 December 2001 |work=South China Morning Post }}</ref> as indecent, and critics saw the sentiments of love songs as appealing only to the ''[[petite bourgeoisie]]''. The genre was also criticized over its connections to American [[jazz]] music, due to [[Anti-American sentiment]] from the [[Korean War]]. This resulted in many artists associated with shidaiqu, including [[Li Jinhui]] (who had been credited as a leading figure in the genre) and [[Chen Gexin]], being branded as "[[Right-wing politics|rightists]]" and persecuted. Shanghai pop was displaced by [[Political music in China|revolutionary music]] that promoted [[Maoism]] and other ideologies of the Communist Party. In 1966, [[Tian Han]]—writer of the Chinese national anthem "[[March of the Volunteers]]"—was imprisoned over his allegorical play ''Xie Yaohuan'' (which was critical of Mao's regime) in one of the opening salvos of the [[Cultural Revolution]]. His works were banned, leading to "[[The East Is Red (song)|The East is Red]]"—a song which glorified Mao's [[cult of personality]], being used as the ''de facto'' national anthem at this time.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wiQJmCxVICcC&pg=PA226#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Jazz Planet |editor= E. Taylor Atkins |page=226 |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year= 2004 |isbn= 978-1578066094 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Wagner |first=Rudolf G. |authorlink=Rudolf G. Wagner |title=The Contemporary Chinese Historical Drama: Four Studies |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7zFiHwkpo88C&pg=PA137 |year=1990 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-05954-2}}</ref><ref name="Jones">Jones. Andrew F. [2001] (2001). Yellow Music – CL: Media Culture and Colonial Modernity in the Chinese Jazz Age. Duke University Press. {{ISBN|0-8223-2694-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=FMU2DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA456&lpg=PA456&dq=%22yellow+music%22+%22cultural+revolution%22&source=bl&ots=0YHKEPp_t7&sig=Oa62wTJdvgOmd9qgxjJnwHq18Zo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4nO6qlZLaAhVI7oMKHSLuB9wQ6AEIeDAJ#v=onepage&q=%22yellow%20music%22%20%22cultural%20revolution%22&f=false|title=The Oxford Handbook of Music Censorship|last=Hall|first=Patricia|date=2017-09-27|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190850586|language=en}}</ref>
In contemporary times, musical works criticizing the Chinese government have also been subject to censure. [[Guns N' Roses]]' album ''[[Chinese Democracy]]'' was banned in the country, as its [[Chinese Democracy (song)|title track]] criticizes the Chinese government and contains references to the [[Falun Gong]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20081124/11883296 |title=內地封殺 GN'R 唱片 |language=Chinese |trans-title=Mainland blocked GN'R album |work=[[Apple Daily]] |location=China |publisher=[[Next Media]] |date=November 24, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626140806/http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20081124/11883296 |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |accessdate=June 26, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/chinese-media-calls-guns-n-roses-chinese-democracy-attack-article-1.334957|title=Chinese media calls Guns 'N Roses 'Chinese Democracy' an attack|author=Laura Johnston|date=November 24, 2008|accessdate=November 24, 2008|work=New York Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/rock-album-an-attack-on-china-1033811.html|title=Rock album 'an attack on China'|accessdate=November 25, 2008|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London | first=Christopher | last=Bodeen | date=November 25, 2008}}</ref> The song "Legacy" on [[Pet Shop Boys]]' 2009 album ''[[Yes (Pet Shop Boys album)|Yes]]'' was changed to an instrumental for its Chinese release, as it contains the lyric "governments fall".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/dance/8329075/The-Most-Incredible-Thing-Pet-Shop-Boys-interview-for-the-ballet.html|title=The Most Incredible Thing: Pet Shop Boys interview for the ballet|last=Garratt|first=Sheryl|date=2011-02-17|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> In July 2017, it was reported that [[Justin Bieber]] had been banned from performing in the country, citing "a series of bad behaviours, both in his social life and during a previous performance in China, which caused discontent among the public."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/21/justin-bieber-banned-from-china-bad-behaviour-purify-discontent|title=Justin Bieber banned from China for 'bad behaviour'|last=Phillips|first=Tom|date=2017-07-21|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
China has historically condemned or banned any musician who publicly supports [[Tibetan independence movement|Tibetan independence]] or otherwise interacts with the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]]; in 2008, [[Björk]] chanted "Tibet, Tibet" to the audience whilst performing "[[Declare Independence]]" during a concert in [[Shanghai]]. [[Zhou Heping]] stated that the song, which was not cleared by Chinese authorities, had caused "dissatisfaction among the broader Chinese audience". He described Björk's case as an isolated incident, and denied that the [[Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Culture]] was wanting to further restrict performances by [[Western world|Western]] acts in the country in response to the incident, since China wanted international musicians to perform there for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7293605.stm|title=Western acts 'welcome' in China|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> In 2013, German electronic music band [[Kraftwerk]] were denied [[travel visa|entry visa]]s over their intent to perform at a 1999 [[Free Tibet]] concert in [[Washington, D.C.]], which was cancelled due to inclement weather.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/mar/29/kraftwerk-denied-china-visa-tibet|title=Kraftwerk denied China visa over 1999 Free Tibet concert|last=Kaiman|first=Jonathan|date=2013-03-29|website=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> [[Maroon 5]] had concerts cancelled in the country after bandmember [[Jesse Carmichael]] posted a [[Twitter]] message for the Dalai Lama's 80th birthday, and [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] concerts in China were cancelled after lead singer [[Noel Gallagher]] performed at a Free Tibet concert in New York City. In 2016, the [[Publicity Department of the Communist Party of China|Publicity Department]] banned [[Lady Gaga]] after she posted a video of her meeting with the Dalai Lama prior to a conference in [[Indianapolis]].<ref name="guardian-m5ban">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/17/maroon-5-dalai-lama-tweet-may-have-led-to-cancelled-china-concerts|title=Maroon 5 Dalai Lama tweet may have led to cancelled China concerts|website=The Guardian|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-gagaban">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jun/28/china-lady-gaga-ban-list-hostile-foreign-forces-meeting-dalai-lama|title=China 'bans Lady Gaga' after Dalai Lama meeting|date=27 June 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, [[South Korea]]n [[Music of South Korea|music]] and entertainment products became subject to a voluntary boycott in China, in retaliation for its stationing of a [[THAAD]] missile defence system to protect against attacks by [[North Korea]] (which has diplomatic ties with China).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/asia/china-ban-on-korea-culture-anniversary-1202537823/|title=China’s Blockade of Cultural Korea Marks Troublesome Anniversary|last=Kil|first=Sonia|date=2017-08-24|work=Variety|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> [[K-pop]] groups, as well as soprano [[Sumi Jo]], had performances cancelled in the country due to the sentiment. Share prices of [[S.M. Entertainment]] and [[YG Entertainment]] also fell, as South Korean entertainment companies had increasingly invested in China to take advantage of the [[Korean Wave]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/08/world/asia/china-korea-thaad.html|title=South Korean Missile Defense Deal Appears to Sour China’s Taste for K-Pop|last=Qin|first=Amy|date=2016-08-07|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-18|last2=Sang-Hun|first2=Choe|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/politics/7708963/china-blocks-korean-streaming-platforms-thaad|title=China Blocks Korean Entertainment on Streaming Platforms Over THAAD Row|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/23/world/asia/sumi-jo-soprano-maria-callas.html|title=3 Performances by Sumi Jo, Korean Soprano, Canceled in China|last=Qin|first=Amy|date=2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/asia/china-confirms-ban-on-korean-content-talent-1201830391/|title=China Reportedly Bans Korean TV Content, Talent|last=Frater|first=Patrick|date=2016-08-04|work=Variety|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3045116|title=Thaad retaliation slashes Olympics visitors from China|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2018-03-03}}</ref> In November 2017, following the settlement of the THAAD dispute, Chinese media outlets began to ease their censure of K-pop content.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/hallyu-ban-over-korea-chinese-tv-music-program-content-song-wedding-livestream-19234|title=Is 'hallyu' ban over in China?|last=Maala|first=Jon|date=2017-11-03|work=International Business Times, Singapore Edition|access-date=2018-03-03|language=en}}</ref>
=== Israel === {{main|Censorship in Israel}} The German composers [[Richard Strauss]] and [[Richard Wagner]] have been considered controversial figures in Israel due to their associations with [[Nazi Germany]], in addition to Wagner's [[Wagner controversies#Antisemitism|displays of antisemitism]] towards the Jewish faith. Although the works of Strauss have since been performed in the country, there is still an [[Wagner controversies#Wagner's music in Israel|informal "ban" on the live performance of Wagner's works]], with concerts intending to do so having faced resistance and protests by Israelis. Despite this, local broadcasters such as radio stations have still played Wagner's music without controversy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1428634.stm|title=Barenboim breaks Wagner taboo|date=2001-07-08|access-date=2018-06-07|work=BBC News|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/05/tel-aviv-wagner-concert-cancelled|title=Tel Aviv Wagner concert cancelled after wave of protest|last=Sherwood|first=Harriet|date=2012-06-05|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-case-for-wagner-in-israel|title=The Case for Wagner in Israel|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/israelis-ready-to-sing-along-with-richard-strauss-but-not-wagner-1166534.html|title=Israelis ready to sing along with Richard Strauss but not Wagner|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Malaysia === {{see also|Censorship in Malaysia}} In Malaysia, a Muslim-majority country, local law prohibits radio stations from playing songs that are "offensive to public feeling" or "violate good taste and decency". References to [[LGBT]] topics were censored from [[Lady Gaga]]'s "[[Born This Way (song)|Born This Way]]" by local radio stations because [[LGBT rights in Malaysia|homosexual acts]] are illegal in the country,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/malaysia/8403613/Lady-Gaga-takes-on-Malaysias-censors.html|title=Lady Gaga takes on Malaysia's censors|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/mar/18/lady-gaga-born-this-way-malaysia|title=Lady Gaga 'gay anthem' censored in Malaysia|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2011-03-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> while "[[Despacito]]" was pulled by Malaysia's state-owned radio stations following listener concerns over its "[[Haram|un-Islamic]]" lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40665528|title=Despacito censored: Malaysia bans 'unsuitable' hit from state stations|date=2017-07-20|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-21/malaysia-ban-spanish-language-song-despacito-from-state-tv-radio/8731894|title=Malaysia bans Despacito over 'obscene lyrics'|date=2017-07-21|work=ABC News|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-AU}}</ref>
Concerts in Malaysia have also been subject to censorship to comply with the country's moral values; [[Avril Lavigne]] was instructed to not wear revealing clothing, jump, shout, or include any "negative elements" in a 2008 concert in Kuala Lumpur,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/aug/22/avril.lavigne.too.sexy.malaysia|title=Avril Lavigne 'too sexy' to perform in public|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2008-08-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Muslim citizens were initially banned from attending a Black Eyed Peas concert in 2009 due to its [[Guinness]] sponsorship, as alcohol is banned under [[Sharia law]] (the ban was lifted after Guinness agreed to cease advertising its involvement nor sell its products at the event),<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/sep/03/black-eyed-peas?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487|title=Ban on Muslims attending Black Eyed Peas concert reversed|last=Michaels|first=Sean|date=2009-09-03|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> and [[Adam Lambert]] agreed to make changes to a 2010 concert due to concerns that he would promote "[[gay culture]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/oct/12/adam-lambert-tone-down-act|title=Adam Lambert to tone down act for Malaysia concert|last=Martin|first=Dan|date=2010-10-12|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== North Korea === {{see also|Censorship in North Korea}} [[Music of North Korea]] is typically limited to state-sanctioned performers and ensembles, whose [[Propaganda in North Korea|propaganda]] music promotes the regime's ideologies and the [[North Korean cult of personality|cult of personality]]. Foreign music, and older North Korean music that do not meet the government's standards, is generally banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/7x9x8d/north-koreas-secret-weapon-is-terrible-synth-pop|title=North Korea's Secret Weapon Is Terrible Synth Pop|website=Vice|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> In July 2015, it was reported that [[Kim-jong Un]] had issued a directive calling for inspectors to destroy music CDs and cassettes containing prohibited content, as well as adding additional songs to the blacklist (such as the entire soundtrack of the historical drama ''[[Im Kkeokjeong|Im Kkeok Jeong]]'').<ref name="guardian-nkmusicban">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/28/north-korea-music-bans-dissent|title=North Korea orders house-to-house searches to confiscate banned music|last=Min|first=Choi Song|date=2015-07-28|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-05|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6648329/north-korea-reportedly-orders-new-crackdown-on-banned-music|title=North Korea Reportedly Orders New Crackdown on Banned Music|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref>
Critics have argued that Kim Jong-un's regime was selectively becoming more open to having some [[Western world|Western]] influence over its culture, citing the inclusion of Western music (such as selections from the soundtrack of the film ''[[Rocky (film)|Rocky]]'', and the song "[[My Way]]") and imagery in the July 2012 debut performance of the [[Moranbong Band]]—an all-female military ensemble.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/articles/271e6e43-bf76-4517-89cf-64759c6a40d6|title=6 extraordinary facts about music in North Korea|work=BBC Music|date=2018-01-24|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=North Korea: Kim Jong-un entertained by Rocky soundtrack and My Way|work=Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9393212/North-Korea-Kim-Jong-un-entertained-by-Rocky-soundtrack-and-My-Way.html|language=en|accessdate=2017-09-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/07/still-my-way-or-the-highway-for-north-koreas-kim-analysts-say.html|title=It's still 'My Way' or the highway under North Korea's Kim|date=2012-07-13|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> In July 2015, it was announced that Slovenian band [[Laibach (band)|Laibach]] would perform in [[Pyongyang]] as part of celebrations of the 70th anniversary of the end of Japanese rule. It was the first ever [[rock music]] concert in the country; the band stated that they planned to perform covers of traditional songs and selections from ''[[The Sound of Music]]''.<ref name="guardian-nkmusicban"/><ref name="nk-firstconcert">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/22/north-korea-laibach-pyongyang-concert|title=Laibach to play Sound of Music covers at Pyongyang's first rock concert|last=Hotham|first=Oliver|date=2015-07-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-05|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== South Korea === {{see also|Censorship in South Korea}}
Due to tense [[History of Japan–Korea relations|relations between Japan and South Korea]] following the end of [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese rule]], the Korean government imposed [[Censorship of Japanese media in South Korea|various restrictions]] on the importation of cultural works from other countries—laws ostensibly meant to target Japan.<ref name="ritsumei">中村知子 (Tomoko Nakamura) [http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/acd/re/k-rsc/ras/04_publications/ria_ja/22_09.pdf "韓国における日本大衆文化統制" (Control of Japanese popular culture in Korea)] {{ja icon}}. [[Ritsumeikan University]]. March 2004.</ref> In September 1999, South Korea lifted its ban on live performances of Japanese music, but only in venues with a capacity smaller than 2000. In June 2000, it became legal to perform Japanese music in larger venues, and to sell music recordings originating from Japan. However, until January 2004, it remained illegal to sell recordings containing [[Japanese-language]] lyrics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2000/06/28/national/seoul-eases-ban-on-culture-from-japan/|title=Seoul eases ban on culture from Japan|date=2000-06-28|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}}</ref><ref name="IIST-japanban">{{Cite magazine | title = Ban Lifted on Japanese Popular Culture in South Korea | first = Hitoshi | last = Suzuki | magazine = IIST World Forum | publisher = Institute for International Studies and Training | date = 2004-03-15 | accessdate = 2016-07-05 | url = http://www.iist.or.jp/wf/magazine/0241/0241_E.html }}</ref><ref name="Demick">{{Cite web | title = South Korea Makes Way for Anime | last = Demick | first = Barbara | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 28 December 2003 | accessdate = 2016-07-05 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2003/dec/28/world/fg-japanculture28 }}</ref> It remains illegal to broadcast Japanese music over terrestrial radio and television in South Korea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2011/09/01/2011090101778.html?news_Head1|title=日, 정치인까지 反한류 감정에 편승|work=Chosun|access-date=2018-06-28|language=ko}}</ref>
To appeal to the country's conservatism, television broadcasters have sometimes [[List of banned K-pop videos|pulled music videos from airplay]] for containing content they deem to be inappropriate, such as violent or sexually suggestive content. While Korea's three major television networks—[[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]], and [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS]]—have all banned videos at some point, the [[public broadcasting|public broadcaster]] KBS is known for doing so more often due to its stricter regulations, which additionally forbid songs that encourage inappropriate behaviour (especially among youth), or contain references to brand names or Japanese words. This results in some songs, such as [[Psy (rapper)|Psy]]'s "[[Gentleman (Psy song)|Gentleman]]" (which was banned by KBS for a scene in which the singer kicks over a [[traffic cone]]) being banned only by KBS, but still receiving airplay by other networks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/6531811/gain-hawwah-interview-religion-south-korea|title=Gain Goes In on New 'Hawwah' EP, Religion and South Korea's Conservative Music Industry|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170614000718|title=G-Dragon, NCT 127 songs deemed unsuitable for KBS|work=The Korea Herald|date=2017-06-14|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/04/11/10-songs-banned-korean-broadcast|title=10 songs banned from Korean broadcast|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2014/04/03/crayon-pops-uh-ee-banned-for-shiny-japanese-word/|title=Crayon Pop’s ‘Uh-ee’ Banned for Shiny Japanese Word|last=Gale|first=Alastair|date=2014-04-03|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/01/25/kbs-bans-one-shinees-jonghyuns-new-songs|title=KBS bans one of SHINee's Jonghyun's new songs|website=SBS PopAsia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2013/04/18/south-korean-tv-network-bans-psys-video/|title=South Korean TV Network Bans Psy’s Video|last=Kwaak|first=Jeyup S.|date=2013-04-18|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>
In 2010, the [[Supreme Court of South Korea]] ruled that it was illegal under the [[National Security Act (South Korea)|National Security Act]] to possess music that praises North Korea, even if instrumental, as it constitutes an "enemy-benefiting expression".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/songs-praising-north-korea-breach-law-20101108-17kbj.html|title=Songs praising North Korea breach law|date=2010-11-08|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === [[File:Sex_Pistols_in_Paradiso.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sex Pistols]]' "[[God Save the Queen (Sex Pistols song)|God Save the Queen]]" was banned by radio stations, and allegedly suppressed from being the number-one song in the UK, due to its criticism of the British government and monarchy.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" />]] {{See also|Censorship in the United Kingdom}} The telecommunications regulator [[Ofcom]] has the power to reprimand broadcasters for playing songs and music videos that breach its guidelines on harmful or offensive content pre-watershed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-15525591|title=Ofcom warns radio broadcasters over explicit lyrics|date=2011-10-31|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/may/09/rihanna-sm-video-too-explicit-for-daytime-broadcast?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Rihanna's S&M video 'too explicit for daytime broadcast'|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2011-05-09|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI) adopted the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) [[Parental Advisory|Parental Advisory label]] program; in July 2011, the BPI published guidance for use of the logo on digital streaming platforms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jun/02/parental-warnings-online-music|title=Parental warnings to be introduced for online music|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2011-06-02|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
The [[BBC]] was historically known for [[List of songs banned by the BBC|censoring]] various songs from being played on its [[BBC Radio|radio]] and [[BBC Television|television]] stations; from the 1930s through 1960s, the BBC had banned songs such as "[[Hold My Hand (1953 song)|Hold My Hand]]" for its religious references, pop arrangements of classical tunes (though barring "[[Sabre Dance]]" because it was "not a well-loved classic whose perversion we would be encouraging"), and during [[World War II]], songs that were "slushy in sentiment", such as "[[I'll Be Home for Christmas]]", due to concerns that it would affect the morale of soldiers. "[[Mack the Knife]]" was also banned from airplay outside of ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'', as the BBC felt it would be offensive outside of the context of the play.<ref name="Unfit for aunties">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/unfit-for-aunties-airwaves-the-artists-censored-by-the-bbc-765106.html|title=Unfit for Auntie's airwaves: The artists censored by the BBC|date=14 December 2007|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|accessdate=17 December 2008}}</ref> [[The Kinks]]' "[[Lola (song)|Lola]]" was briefly banned under the BBC's anti-[[product placement]] rules, as its lyrics contain references to the brand name [[Coca-Cola]]. In the midst of an American tour, lead singer [[Ray Davies]] flew back to [[London]] to re-record the offending lyric as "cherry cola".<ref name="New Zealand Herald-bbc">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/radio-industry/news/article.cfm?c_id=295&objectid=10483279|title=Banning songs not a rare occurrence for the BBC|last=|first=|date=19 December 2007|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=15 October 2011|location=Auckland}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RICQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=ray+davies+cherry+cola&source=bl&ots=S6Kt3TJHP_&sig=uXTjv1fCZSUrfTU002NGXZjyJ9Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nLyNU77WGo7NsQSN0oHIBQ&ved=0CHsQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=ray%20davies%20cherry%20cola&f=false|title=Ray Davies: Not Like Everybody Else|last=Kitts|first=Thomas M.|date=2008-01-23|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135867959|language=en}}</ref>
The [[Sex Pistols]]' 1977 single "[[God Save the Queen (Sex Pistols song)|God Save the Queen]]" was controversial upon its release, as it was critical of the British government and monarchy (among other things, referring to the United Kingdom as a "fascist regime"), and was released during the year of [[Queen Elizabeth II]]'s [[Silver Jubilee of Elizabeth II|silver jubilee]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1219770.stm |title= Sex Pistols cover tops chart |publisher= BBC |accessdate= 17 July 2013}}</ref> "God Save the Queen" was banned by the BBC and all [[independent local radio]] stations, but still peaked at #2 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] during the week of the official Jubilee celebration. It was alleged that the chart's rules were changed for that week only to exclude sales from record shops that sold their own records (in this case, [[Virgin Records|Virgin]]), in a deliberate effort to prevent the controversial song from reaching the number-one spot and causing wider offence.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2010060.stm|title=Bragg attacks Pistols' royal views|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/apr/12/artsfeatures.popandrock|title=Leaders of the banned|last=Petridis|first=Alexis|date=2002-04-12|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/music-charting-the-number-ones-that-somehow-got-away-1145809.html|title=Music: Charting the number ones that somehow got away|date=1998-02-20|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-GB}}</ref>
The [[Frankie Goes to Hollywood]] song "[[Relax (song)|Relax]]" generated controversy due to its suggestive lyrics; the chorus contained double entendres such as "when you want to suck to it" and "when you want to come", which were interpreted as being oblique references to [[oral sex]] and [[ejaculation]] respectively.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jan/27/radio-1-relax-ban-john-peel-1984-archive|title=Shake-up planned at Radio 1 after Relax ban|last=Harron|first=Mary|date=1984-01-27|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-06-30|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> On 11 January 1984, Radio 1 morning DJ [[Mike Read]] stopped the song on-air during a chart rundown to point out its "obscene" lyrics, and announced that he would no longer play the song during his show. The BBC subsequently restricted the song to evening airplay. When the band made statements in a ''[[Daily Express]]'' interview confirming the possibility of sexual connotations in the lyrics, the BBC banned "Relax" entirely. The ban only [[Streisand effect|increased interest]] in the single, causing it to become the number-one song in Britain only two weeks later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/959284.stm|title='Banned' Frankie tops chart|date=6 October 2000|work=BBC News|accessdate=4 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="bbc-relaxban" /><ref name=":0" />
In December 2007, BBC Radio 1 began to play a version of [[The Pogues]]' popular Christmas song "[[Fairytale of New York]]" that censored the words "faggot" and "slut" from one of its verses. The BBC cited concerns over the homophobic slurs as reasoning, despite the song having historically been played without censorship. The BBC reversed the decision after it was criticized by listeners, the band itself, and the mother of the song's featured vocalist [[Kirsty MacColl]]. Radio 1 controller [[Andy Parfitt]] argued that "While we would never condone prejudice of any kind, we know our audiences are smart enough to distinguish between maliciousness and creative freedom. In the context of this song, I do not feel that there is any negative intent behind the use of the words, hence the reversal of the decision."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/dec/18/bbc.radio|title=Radio 1 censors Christmas standard|last=MacInnes|first=Paul|date=2007-12-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7150693.stm|title=Radio 1 backs down in Pogues row|website=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref>
As the song's [[Sadomasochism|subject matter]] was deemed too inappropriate for airplay pre-watershed, BBC Radio 1 played an edited version of [[Rihanna]]'s song "[[S&M (song)|S&M]]" during the daytime hours, and referred to the song using the alternate title "Come On". As Rihanna objected to the censorship of the song's title, the BBC later compromised by referring to the song as "S&M (Come On)".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1657491/rihanna-s-and-m-renamed.jhtml|title=Rihanna's 'S&M' Renamed Again By BBC Radio|last=Montgomery|first=James|date=2011-08-02|work=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/music/854875-rihannas-s-m-outrage-exposed-as-pr-stunt|title=BBC Radio 1 ban 'S&M' from daytime radio|date=2011-07-02|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=2011-05-06}}</ref> For the same reasons, Ofcom deemed the song's music video to be unfit for broadcast pre-watershed.<ref name=":1" />
After the 2013 death of former Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]], "[[Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead]]" from the film [[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|''The Wizard of Oz'']] reached #2 on the UK Singles Chart, as the result of a social media campaign celebrating the death of the controversial PM. BBC Radio 1 did not play the full song during ''[[The Official Chart]]'' programme, and instead played a short snippet accompanied by a ''[[Newsbeat]]'' report about the campaign. The action led to complaints that the BBC were deliberately censoring the song due to its negativity in this context, noting that "[[I'm in Love with Margaret Thatcher]]" (which also charted, albeit lower, as part of a campaign to counter the aforementioned "Witch" campaign)<ref>{{Citation|title="I'm In Love with Margaret Thatcher" anthem aiming to rival 'witch' song in charts|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/margaret-thatcher/9990386/Im-In-Love-with-Margaret-Thatcher-anthem-aiming-to-rival-witch-song-in-charts.html|work=Daily Telegraph|language=en|accessdate=2017-07-28}}</ref> was played in full earlier in the show. The BBC Trust's Editorial Standards Committee upheld its decision not to play the song, due to its context as a celebration of Thatcher's death.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/apr/14/ding-dong-witch-dead-broadcast|title=Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead: what the BBC broadcast|last=staff|first=Guardian|date=2013-04-14|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-27|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/dec/03/bbc-censorship-margaret-thatcher-protest-song-ding-dong|title=BBC rejects complaint over 'censorship' of Margaret Thatcher protest song|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2013-12-03|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-27|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
"[[Liar Liar GE2017]]", a song released during the run-up to the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]] that is critical of prime minister [[Theresa May]], was not played by British radio stations due to broadcasting regulations in force during electoral campaigns, which forbid political advertising and require impartial coverage.<ref name="wp-liarliar">{{cite web|date=31 May 2017|last=Taylor|first=Adam|title=A song that calls Britain’s Theresa May a liar is climbing the charts — but it isn’t being played on the radio|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/05/31/a-song-that-calls-britains-theresa-may-a-liar-is-climbing-the-charts-but-it-isnt-being-played-on-the-radio/|website=Washington Post|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611100420/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/05/31/a-song-that-calls-britains-theresa-may-a-liar-is-climbing-the-charts-but-it-isnt-being-played-on-the-radio/|archive-date=11 June 2017|dead-url=no|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref> Despite the suppression, the song still managed to reach #4 on the UK Singles Chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/40129621/theresa-may-protest-track-liar-liar-ge2017-number-four-on-official-singles-chart|title=Theresa May protest track, Liar Liar GE2017, number four on Official Singles Chart|date=2017-02-06|website=BBC Newsbeat|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref>
=== United States === [[File:Parental_Advisory_label.svg|thumb|right|The [[Parental Advisory]] label was voluntarily adopted by the U.S. music industry to designate recordings that may contain objectionable content.]]{{See also|Censorship in the United States}}
While music can be classified as a [[Freedom of speech|protected form of expression]] under the [[First Amendment]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Munkittrick|first=David|date=|title=Music as Speech: A First Amendment Category Unto Itself|url=http://www.repository.law.indiana.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1568&context=fclj|journal=Federal Communications Law Journal, Indiana University Maurer School of Law|volume=62|pages=|via=}}</ref> there have still been instances of voluntary censorship within the music industry, particularly in regards to [[Think of the children|protecting children from being exposed to age-inappropriate subject matter]], corporate objections to an artist's work, and by radio and television stations to remain in compliance with the regulations of the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC). The 1978 [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] case ''[[FCC v. Pacifica Foundation]]'' established that the FCC had the power to regulate the broadcast of content considered "indecent" on terrestrial radio and television.<ref name="firstinstitute-indecent">{{Cite web|url=https://www.freedomforuminstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/FirstReport.Indecency.Levi_.final_.pdf|title=The FCC’s Regulation of Indecency|last=Levi|first=Lili|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/arts/fcc-rules-on-indecent-programming.html|title=F.C.C. Rules on Indecent Programming|last=Molotsky|first=Irvin|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1990/07/13/fcc-bans-all-indecent-broadcasts/9a34a1e9-474d-4761-b4fe-0d998ef87493/|title=FCC BANS ALL 'INDECENT' BROADCASTS|date=1990-07-13|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
In 1985, the [[Parents Music Resource Center]] (PMRC), founded by [[Tipper Gore]], published the "Filthy Fifteen"—a list of fifteen songs it deemed to be the most objectionable due to their references to drugs and alcohol, sexual acts, violence, or "[[occult]]" activities.<ref name="NPR-pal" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/pmrcs-filthy-15-where-are-they-now-20150917|title=PMRC's 'Filthy 15': Where Are They Now?|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref> The group pushed for the adoption of a [[Content rating|ratings system]], and for lyrics to be printed on the back covers of albums so they could be previewed by parents.<ref name="NPR-pal" /><ref name=":2" /> The [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) opposed these proposals; during a [[United States Senate|Senate]] hearing on the matter in September, musicians such as [[John Denver]] and [[Frank Zappa]] argued that such guidelines would inhibit [[free expression]]. Zappa, in particular, argued that the PMRC's proposal for a method to "assist baffled parents in the determination of the 'suitability' of records listened to by 'very young children'" would reduce American music to "the intellectual level of a [[Saturday morning cartoon]]".<ref name="NPR-pal" />
Following the hearings, the RIAA introduced a standard [[Parental Advisory]] label (which took its current form, reading "Parental Advisory — Explicit Content", in 1994 following subsequent hearings), which is designed to be applied to the cover art of songs and albums which may contain objectionable content; the RIAA recommends that it be used on releases containing "strong language or depictions of violence, sex, or substance abuse to such an extent as to merit parental notification." The Parental Advisory label is a voluntary scheme; some retailers—particularly [[Walmart]]—adopted policies to enforce the label program by not stocking music releases which carried it.<ref name="Program">{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/toolsforparents.php?content_selector=parental_advisory|title=Parental Advisory Label ("PAL") Program|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=July 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701220958/http://riaa.com/toolsforparents.php?content_selector=parental_advisory|archivedate=July 1, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="NPR-pal">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2010/10/29/130905176/you-ask-we-answer-parental-advisory---why-when-how|title=You Ask, We Answer: 'Parental Advisory' Labels — The Criteria And The History|last=Cole|first=Tom|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=October 29, 2010|accessdate=July 4, 2014}}</ref>
[[Gangsta rap]] generated controversies due to its often-provocative subject matter. "[[Fuck tha Police]]", a song from [[N.W.A.]]'s debut album ''[[Straight Outta Compton]]'', proved to be particularly controversial. The song criticized [[police brutality]] and [[racial profiling]], and contained lyrics condoning violence against police officers.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/08/the-worst-moments-of-the-90s-worst-band-names-worst-lyrics-worst-video/130809-worst-of-the-90s-c-delores/|title=A Decade in Rap Censorship (1990-1999)|website=Spin|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref><ref name="The FBI as music critic">{{cite web|last1=Harrington|first1=Richard|title=The FBI as music critic|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1989/10/04/the-fbi-as-music-critic/3f9abdb7-bed1-45b2-83ca-7a6e7da59fa9/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> Civil rights activist [[C. Delores Tucker]] was also notable for her opposition to gangsta rap. She was known for distributing flyers outside record stores, buying stock in media companies so she could protest the songs at shareholders' meetings. Tucker was notably [[Diss (music)|dissed]] in other songs over her criticism of the genre, including [[Tupac Shakur|Tupac]]'s "[[How Do U Want It]]"—which prompted Tucker to sue Tupac's estate for emotional distress and slander. The suit was later dismissed.<ref>Welte, Jim. [http://www.mp3.com/news/stories/6565.html Court rejects Tupac critic case] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929101858/http://www.mp3.com/news/stories/6565.html |date=2007-09-29 }}. [[MP3.com]]: October 2, 2006.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/06/us/c-delores-tucker-a-voice-for-minorities-and-women-is-dead-at-78.html|title=C. DeLores Tucker, a Voice for Minorities and Women, Is Dead at 78|last=Martin|first=Douglas|date=2005-11-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":5" /><ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/13/AR2005101300024.html|title=C. Delores Tucker Dies at 78; Rights and Anti-Rap Activist|last=Lamb|first=Yvonne Shinhoster|date=2005-10-13|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=2007-08-24|pages=B4}}</ref>
In 1990, Floridan political activist [[Jack Thompson (activist)|Jack Thompson]] targeted the Miami-based [[2 Live Crew]] and their album ''[[As Nasty As They Wanna Be]]'' (which featured songs such as "[[Me So Horny]]"), claiming that it was [[obscene]].<ref name="nyt-2livecrewseized"/> In March 1990, the group filed a lawsuit in a U.S. district court to overturn a [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]] ruling that declared the album obscene, but it was upheld by Judge [[Jose Alejandro Gonzalez Jr.]]<ref name="nyt-2livecrewseized">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/us/rap-singers-seized-on-obscenity-charge.html|title=Rap Singers Seized on Obscenity Charge|last=LeMoyne|first=James|date=1990-06-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/06/11/25-years-ago-2-live-crew-were-arrested-for-obscenity-heres-the-fascinating-back-story/|title=25 years ago, 2 Live Crew were arrested for obscenity. Here’s the fascinating back story.|last=Schwarz|first=Hunter|date=2015-06-11|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1989/10/04/the-fbi-as-music-critic/3f9abdb7-bed1-45b2-83ca-7a6e7da59fa9/|title=The FBI as music critic|last=Harrington|first=Richard|date=1989-10-04|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref name="The 'Batman who took on rap">{{cite news|last=Philips|first=Chuck|title=The 'Batman' Who Took On Rap|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-06-18/entertainment/ca-87_1_jack-thompson|accessdate=5 November 2013|newspaper=LA Times|date=June 18, 1990}}</ref> In 1992, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit|Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals]] overturned the Gonzalez ruling, as the case presented insufficient evidence that the album met the [[Miller test|definition of obscenity]] set by the Supreme Court (which includes a lack of artistic merit).<ref>{{cite news|last=Philips|first=Chuck|title=Appeals Court Voids Obscenity Ruling on 2 Live Crew Album|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-05-08/news/mn-1911_1_live-crew|accessdate=5 November 2013|newspaper=LA Times|date=May 8, 1992}}</ref>
The television channel [[MTV]] was also known for [[Censorship on MTV|censoring]] objectionable content from [[music video]]s, and restricting some particularly-controversial videos to [[Watershed (broadcasting)|late-night airplay]]—such as [[The Prodigy]]'s "[[Smack My Bitch Up]]" due to its violent imagery and [[Misogyny|misogynistic]] lyrics, and [[Sir Mix-a-Lot]]'s "[[Baby Got Back]]" for its suggestive subject matter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hot-mtv-ten-controversial-music-64410|title=Too Hot For MTV: Ten Controversial Music Videos That Got Banned|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-07-27|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/music/pop-culture-remix-key-moments-in-baby-got-back-history/|title=Pop culture remix: Key moments in ‘Baby Got Back’ history|date=2017-05-03|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2017-07-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1433366/19971222/prodigy.jhtml|title=MTV Explains Decision To Pull Prodigy|date=December 22, 1997|publisher=MTV News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030920042432/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1433366/19971222/prodigy.jhtml|archivedate=September 20, 2003|accessdate=September 1, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/prodigy/news/bitch-banned-from-mtv--12044078|title='Bitch' banned from MTV|date=December 23, 1997|publisher=Yahoo Music|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829022555/http://music.yahoo.com/prodigy/news/bitch-banned-from-mtv--12044078|archivedate=August 29, 2012}}</ref> Several [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] videos have also been banned by the channel, including the sexually-explicit "[[Justify My Love]]" and "[[Erotica (song)|Erotica]]". Due to its violent content, MTV and sister channel [[VH1]] only played "[[What It Feels Like for a Girl]]" once in late-night hours for its world premiere, and subsequently refused to add it to their regular rotation. The women's cable network [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] subsequently provided airplay for the video.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/80295/controversial-madonna-video-hits-oxygen|title=Controversial Madonna Video Hits Oxygen|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref><ref name="ban again">{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/gate/archive/2001/03/23/neva.DTL|title=Madonna's No 'Pussy Cat': MTV bans her latest video, again|last=Chonin|first=Neva|authorlink=|date=2001-03-23|publisher=|dead-url=yes|quote=|coauthors=|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040126165159/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fgate%2Farchive%2F2001%2F03%2F23%2Fneva.DTL|archivedate=January 26, 2004|accessdate=2007-05-26|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On February 1, 2004 during the MTV-produced [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime-show controversy|Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show]] (which was televised by its corporate sister [[NFL on CBS|CBS]]), [[Janet Jackson]]'s breast was exposed by [[Justin Timberlake]] at the conclusion of the show, in an apparent "[[wardrobe malfunction]]".<ref name="rs-ripples">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/nipple-ripples-10-years-of-fallout-from-janet-jacksons-halftime-show-20140130|title=Nipple Ripples: Revisiting Janet Jackson's Wardrobe Malfunction|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-07-28}}</ref> In response to the show, as well as other recent incidents surrounding [[fleeting expletive|unexpected use of profanities]] by those appearing on live television programs (referred to as a "fleeting expletive"), the FCC launched a major crackdown against indecent material broadcast on terrestrial radio and television stations. Some [[Rock music|rock]] radio stations removed or censored certain songs so they would not run afoul of the stricter enforcement,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/media-fights-for-free-speech-20040511|title=Media Fights for Free Speech|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref> while MTV moved several videos with sexually suggestive imagery to late-night hours.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/mtv-under-attack-by-fcc-20040223|title=MTV Under Attack by FCC|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref> [[Viacom (original)|Viacom]], which owned MTV, [[CBS]], and the radio station group [[CBS Radio|Infinity Broadcasting]] at the time, also [[Blacklisting|blacklisted]] Jackson and her music from its properties, and removed her from the CBS-televised [[46th Annual Grammy Awards|46th Grammy Awards]] the following week—where she was scheduled to introduce a tribute to [[Luther Vandross]]. The blacklisting caused Janet Jackson's album ''[[Damita Jo (album)|Damita Jo]]'', which was released the following month, to underperform due to reduced promotion and single airplay.<ref name="rs-ripples"/>
===Iran=== [[File:Googoosh in concert.jpg|thumb]] Although music has been big element when it comes to the pre-Islamic cultures of Iran it became confined in courts or performed by street artists after Iran spread. Music played a large role in the lives of Islamic people. However, they were eventually told they must do without it. In fact it got to the point where music was entirely eliminated meaning no concerts were allowed of any kind and musical instruments were to be destroyed back in the late 70’s. Iran’s reason for eliminating music was because it was believed to be betraying their country and its youth. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leone|first=Massimo|date=November 2012|title=My schoolmate: protest music in present-day Iran|url=http://ky5ry5jk2j.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fsummon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=My+Schoolmate%3A+Protest+Music+in+Present-Day+Iran&rft.jtitle=Critical+Discourse+Studies&rft.au=Leone%2C+Massimo&rft.date=2012&rft.issn=1740-5904&rft.eissn=1740-5912&rft.volume=9&rft.issue=4&rft.spage=347&rft.externalDocID=R04953625&paramdict=en-US|journal=My schoolmate: protest music in present-day Iran|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hemmasi|first=Farzaneh|date=Winter 2013|title=Intimating Dissent: Popular Song, Poetry, and Politics in Pre-Revolutionary Iran|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5406/ethnomusicology.57.1.0057|journal=Intimating Dissent: Popular Song, Poetry, and Politics in Pre-Revolutionary Iran|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{short description|Muisca god of artists}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox deity | type = Muisca | name = Nencatacoa | deity_of = art(ist)s, dance and festivitiesOcampo López, 2013, Ch. 9, p.57 | member_of = [[Muisca religion]] | image = ParqueArqueológicoSogamoso.JPG | alt = | caption = Houses (''bohíos'') Nencatacoa helped being built for the Muisca, allegedly when drunk | other_names = '''Nem-catacoa''' | hiro = | script_name = | script = | affiliation = | cult_center = | abode = | planet = | mantra = | weapon = | battles = | artifacts = | animals = Fox or bear | symbol = | day = | color = | number = | consort = | parents = | siblings = | offspring = | army = | mount = | texts = | Greek_equivalent = [[Pan (god)|Pan]], [[Dionysus]], [[Apollo]] | Roman_equivalent = [[Bacchus]] | Etruscan_equivalent = | Christian_equivalent = ''none'' | Slavic_equivalent = | Hinduism_equivalent = | region = [[Altiplano Cundiboyacense]]
Colombia | ethnic_group = [[Muisca people|Muisca]] | festivals = }} '''Nencatacoa''' or '''Nem-catacoa''' was the [[deity|god]] and protector of the mantle makers, artists and festivities in the [[Muisca religion and mythology|religion of the Muisca]]. The [[Muisca people|Muisca]] and their [[Muisca Confederation|confederation]] were one of the four advanced civilizations of the Americas; as much as the [[Aztec]], [[Maya civilization|Mayas]] and [[Inca Empire|Incas]] but other than the other three, they did not construct grand architecture. Their gold working however was well-known and respected which made Nencatacoa an important deity and protector. == Description == [[File:BOG 04 2012 Museo de Oro 1177.JPG|thumb|260px|left|Golden mask in the [[Gold Museum, Bogotá|Museo del Oro]]
Ritual gold mask]] Nencatacoa was represented in the form of a forest animal, made of gold and covered with a mantle. Nencatacoa looked most like a fox or a bear,{{es}} [http://pueblosoriginarios.com/sur/caribe/muisca/nencatacoa.html Description Nencatacoa] – Pueblos Originarios because as [[Pedro Simón]] noted, "an animal in that shape would appear multiple times". He was the protector god of the weavers, an industry that was very important among the [[Muisca people|Muisca]], who used a great variety of materials but mostly cotton and [[fique]]. [[File:Totuma con chicha.png|thumb|right|260px|''[[Chicha]]''; alcoholic drink from fermented maize, main ingredient of the festivities around '''Nencatacoa''']] Nencatacoa was also the protector of artists and painters who realized their beautiful creations on the cloths, the [[Muisca economy#Ceramics|ceramics]], [[Muisca economy#Gold|gold metallurgy]], [[sculptures]] and [[petroglyph]]s with different [[anthropomorphic]], [[zoomorphic]] and [[ideogram]]atic figures.Ocampo López, 2013, Ch. 9, p.58 Moreover, Nencatacoa was the god of festivities, drunkenness and dance. Traditions tell us that he partied with the people without caring about anything else. The Muisca drank ''[[Chicha#Colombia|chicha]]'', a type of alcoholic drink based on the fermentation and cooking of maize. When the indigenous peoples were constructing their houses he helped them with lifting the heavy poles. Even during the construction of their houses (''bohíos'') and temples, the Muisca drank a lot of chicha. Also to celebrate the completion of temples, houses or roads and with the arrival of new ''[[cacique]]s'' the Muisca drank a lot of ''chicha''. At times of sowing and harvest, they celebrated with dancing, singing, music (with drums and flutes) and honoured the gods, in particular Nencatacoa.Ocampo López, 2013, Ch. 9, p.60 Nencatacoa thus appeared to be similar in style and association to the [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] god [[Dionysus]] and the [[Roman empire|Roman]] [[Bacchus]]. [[List of Muisca scholars|Chronicler]] Pedro Simón described about the Muisca that when they were partying and dancing around the fire and the wind blew that was a sign that Nencatacoa was participating. == References == {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite LSA |last=[[Javier Ocampo López|Ocampo López]] |first=Javier |year=2013 |title=Mitos y leyendas indígenas de Colombia – Indigenous myths and legends of Colombia |location=Bogotá, Colombia |publisher=Plaza & Janes Editores Colombia S.A. |isbn=978-958-14-1416-1 |pages=1-219 |language=es}} {{Muisca navbox|Mythology and religion|state=collapsed}} {{subject bar|portal1=Colombia}} {{authority control}} [[Category:Muisca deities]] [[Category:South American deities]] [[Category:Pre-Columbian mythology and religion]] [[Category:Arts gods]] [[Category:Crafts gods]] [[Category:Textiles in mythology and folklore]] [[Category:Muysccubun]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} [[Image:People's Architect of the USSR.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''People's Architect of the USSR'' medal]] '''People's Architect of the USSR''' ({{lang-ru|Народный архитектор СССР}}), also sometimes translated as '''National Architect of the USSR''', was an honorary title granted to [[architect]]s of the [[Soviet Union]]; it was established on August 12, 1967 by [[Leonid Brezhnev]]. It was bestowed by the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]] of the USSR owing proposals addressed by the ''State Construction Committee'' or by the ''Soviet Architects' Union''. The [[Supreme Soviet]] could possibly refuse these designations.
A diploma of the [[Supreme Soviet]]'s presidency was given to those who were appointed ''People's Architect of the USSR'' jointly with the medal and its concerning certificate. The title was bestowed to architects who had achieved stunning results in Soviet [[architecture]]'s development either applying their expertise and creativity to the [[urban planning]] or to the design of important building compounds for civil, industrial or rural use.
Following the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] (1990), by a decree of the [[Russian presidency]], it was created the new title of ''[[Honorary titles of the Russian Federation|Meritorious Architect of the Russian Federation]]''.
== Design == The medal was made of [[tombac]] and its shape was quadrangular (22,5 x 23,5 mm) with twisted corners. The central part was occupied by the inscription "Народный архитектор СССР" (''People's Architect of the USSR'') and, below, the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol. Symbol and inscription and were embossed, with convex letters. The medal was suspended to a single red silk fringe (18 mm × 21 mm) to whom it was attached by a metallic buckle decorated with [[bay laurel]] leaves.
== Some awardees == * [[Dmitry Chechulin]]; awarded in 1971 * [[Ignaty Ivanovich Fomin]] (1904–1989); awarded in 1971; a prominent member of the Soviet Art Academy.<ref>''Memoirs of Nikita Khrushchev'', Volume 2, Nikita Sergeevich Khrushchev and Sergei Khrushchev, on [https://books.google.com/books?id=uv1zv4FZhFUC&pg=PT311&lpg=PT311&dq=%22People's+Architect+of+the+USSR%22&source=bl&ots=woNHaY6Vcc&sig=bYQPtQAZ4-A2b9TP6yk4FSI6ev8&hl=it&ei=8MIETLKBDJqinQPD_bDVCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCEQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22People's%20Architect%20of%20the%20USSR%22&f=false books.google.com] (accessed in September 2010)</ref> * [[Valentin Alexandrovich Kamensky]] (1907–1975); awarded in 1970; author of significant [[Urban planning|town plans]] among which the [[Leningrad]] city plan; he also directed the post-war reconstruction works in several USSR places.<ref>''Kamensky V.A. (1907–1975), architect'', О. А. Чеканова., on [http://www.encspb.ru/en/article.php?kod=2804007566 www.encspb.ru] (accessed in September 2010)</ref> * [[Vladimir Korol]] (1912–1980); architect, [[Pedagogy|pedagogue]] and later politician of [[Belarus]].<ref>''Architect Korol: creative heritage'', G. I. Shostak, on [http://archives.gov.by/eng/index.php?id=808124 archives.gov.by] (accessed in September 2010)</ref> * [[Boris Iofan]]; awarded 1970; designer of the [[Palace of the Soviets]] * [[Georgi Mikhailovich Orlov]] (1901–1985), awarded in 1970; mainly active in industrial building design, he directed in particular the [[hydroelectric]] exploitation projects of Kakhovskoy ([[Dniester]] river, 1951–1955) and [[Bratsk hydroelectric plant|Bratsk]] (1960–1967); he also was elected first secretary of the USSR Architect Union.<ref name=arch>''Biography Orlova Georgi Mikhailovich'', on [http://peopleofrussia.com/tag/state-architect peopleofrussia.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715063357/http://peopleofrussia.com/tag/state-architect |date=July 15, 2011 }} (accessed in September 2010)</ref> * [[Mikayil Useynov]] (1905–1992); leading architect of [[Azerbaijan]] during its Sovietic period.<ref>''The Soviet Period of Architecture in Azerbaijan'', Ilham Aliyev, on [http://azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/64_folder/64_articles/64_useynov.html azer.com] (accessed in September 2010)</ref> * [[Aleksandr Rochegov]], [[constructivist architecture|constructivist]] architect and designer of the [[Embassy of Russia in Havana|Soviet Embassy in Havana]]; awarded 1991
==References== *The initial version of this article was based on a translation of [http://it.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Architetto_del_Popolo_dell%27Unione_Sovietica&oldid=34792898 its equivalent] on the [[Italian Wikipedia]], as retrieved on September 14, 2010. {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Awards and decorations of the Soviet Union]] * [[People's Artist of the USSR]] * [[People's Doctor of the USSR]] * [[People's Teacher of the USSR]]
{{Soviet awards}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:People's Architect of the Ussr}} [[Category:Soviet honorary titles]] [[Category:Civil awards and decorations of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Awards established in 1967]] [[Category:Architecture awards]] [[Category:Soviet architecture]]

{{ref improve|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Polo |native_name = |mapsize = 200px |pushpin_map = Dominican Republic |pushpin_relief = 1 |coordinates = {{coord|18|04|48|N|71|16|48|W|region:DO|display=inline,title}} |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = [[Dominican Republic]] |subdivision_type1 = Province |subdivision_name1 = [[Barahona Province|Barahona]] |established_title = |established_date = |leader_title = |leader_name = |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = 200.61 |elevation_m =746 |population_total = 7144 |population_as_of = 2012 |population_density_km2 =auto |area_code = |website = |timezone = |utc_offset = |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = }} '''Polo''' is a municipality of the [[Barahona Province]] in southwestern [[Dominican Republic]], known for its green and high mountains and for growing fine coffee. The small town of Polo is also known for having '''El Polo Magnético''' (the magnetic pole), an area on a mountain near the village. If a car is stopped at the right place, and put in neutral, the car seems to be rolling up the hill. This is type of [[optical illusion]] known as a [[gravity hill]] which is caused by the shape of the slope and the surrounding landscape. == Climate == {{Weather box |collapsed = yes |open = yes revision.text:
{{Infobox park | name = | image = Rosiuni.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Rosicrucian University building in the Park | map = <!-- or | map_image = --> | map_width = | type = | location = 1660 Park Ave, [[San Jose, California]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coordinates|37|20|02|N|121|55|23|W}} | area = | created = 1927 | operator = [[Ancient Mystical Order Rosae Crucis]] | visitation_num = | status = | designation = | open = | website = [https://www.rosicrucianpark.org www.rosicrucianpark.org] }} '''Rosicrucian Park''' is the headquarters of the English Grand Lodge for the Americas of the [[Ancient Mystical Order Rosae Crucis]], located in [[San Jose, California]].
==History== The Rosicrucian Park was established in 1927 by [[Harvey Spencer Lewis]]. It grew from one single lot to a 5-acre city block.<ref>Gary Singh, [http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/09.12.02/rosicrucian-0237.html Ring Around the Rosy Cross], ''Metroactive.com'', 9 December 2002</ref> The [[Rosicrucian Egyptian Museum]] was built in 1932, the Planetarium in 1936, the research library opened in June 1939. The Akhenaton Shrine was built in 1949.<ref>[http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h3012.html Rosicrucian Park], ''Us-history.com''</ref>
The Peace Garden was added to the park in 2004 and dedicated by [[Rosicrucian]] [[Imperator]] [[Christian Bernard]]. In 2013, a new Alchemy Museum was announced for 2020.<ref>Gary Singh, [http://www.metroactive.com/features/columns/Alchemy-Museum-Rosicrucian-Park.html Alchemy Museum Coming to Rosicrucian Park], ''Metroactive.com'', 22 October 2013</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rosicrucianpark.org/alchemy-museum|title=New Rosicrucian Alchemy Museum|last=Rosicrucian Order|first=AMORC|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The opening ceremony for the preliminary exhibit in the Lecture Gallery of the [[Rosicrucian Egyptian Museum]] occurred during the Summer solstice of June 2015. The new museum in the former Rose-Croix University International building will include a working alchemy laboratory. The Alchemy garden in front of the new museum is composed of four elemental gardens representing the four elements.<ref>Gary Singh, [http://www.metroactive.com/features/columns/Alchemy-Museum-Rosicrucian-Egyptian-Museum.html Alchemy for You], ''Metroactive.com'', 1 July 2015</ref><ref>Gary Singh, [http://www.metroactive.com/features/columns/Rosicrucian-alchemy-museum-garden.html Alchemy Garden Opens in San Jose], ''Metroactive.com'', 23 December 2014</ref>
From 2009 to 2015, the Park reduced its water consumption by 4.5 million gallons.<ref>[http://www.ecologicalconcerns.com/rosicrucian-park-and-egyptian-museum-reduced-water-usage-by-4-5-million-gallons/ Rosicrucian Park and Egyptian Museum Reduced Water Usage by 4.5 Million Gallons], ''Ecologicalconcerns.com'', 16 April 2015</ref>
==Description== The park takes up nearly an entire city block and includes the [[Rosicrucian Egyptian Museum]], the administration building for the Order, the Rosicrucian Planetarium, the Rosicrucian Peace Garden, the Rosicrucian Research Library, the Grand Temple, and a central fountain plaza and gardens. A [[rose]] garden is incorporated in the Park next to the Research Library. A [[Metasequoia glyptostroboides|dawn redwood]] grows outside of the Rosicrucian Research Library as a memorial to [[Harvey Spencer Lewis|H. Spencer Lewis]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Campbell|first=Clara|date=March 1980|title=Tree from the Dawn of Time|url=|journal=Rosicrucian Digest|volume=58 March 1980|pages=22-23|via=}}</ref> It was planted in 1950 from a seedling from the lot brought from China by Dr. Ralph Chaney,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=May 1951|title=Temple Echoes|url=|journal=Rosicrucian Digest|volume=Vol 29 #5|pages=180|via=}}</ref> and donated by an unnamed donor to H. Spencer Lewis's widow for this purpose.<ref name=":0" />
The park also includes the Akhenaten Shrine (named for the [[18th dynasty]] Pharaoh [[Akhenaten]]), which contains the ashes of AMORC founder [[Harvey Spencer Lewis]] and other former officials of the order.
With the exception of the planetarium, all buildings in Rosicrucian Park were constructed with exteriors inspired by the [[Ancient Egypt]]ian architectural tradition. In tribute to their claimed Egyptian heritage, [[cyperus papyrus]] plants are also incorporated into the landscaping.
==Gallery==
Photographs of various buildings and statuary within the block comprising Rosicrucian Park.
<gallery> Image:Rosicrucian Park tree side.jpg|Tree side Image:Rosicrucian Park pillar.jpg|Park pillar Image:Rosicrucian Park - statues.jpg|Statues Image:Rosicrucian Park.jpg|View on the park Image:Rosicrucian Park walkway.jpg|Walkway Image:Rosicrucian Park statue distance.jpg|Statues Image:Rosicrucian Park flower.jpg|Park flower Image:Rosiuni.jpg|University building </gallery>
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[https://www.rosicrucianpark.org/ Official website]
{{San Jose and Silicon Valley attractions}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox ancient site |name = Russian Geoglyph |native_name = |alternate_name = |image = 3-Russia-geoglyph.jpg |alt = |caption = Outline of the Russian geoglyph |map_type = Russia |map_alt = |map_size = |location = slopes of the [[Zyuratkul National Park|Zyuratkul Mountains]], [[Chelyabinsk]] region |region = |coordinates = {{coord|54.9425|59.1922|display=inline}} |type = [[Geoglyph]] |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = Stone |built = |abandoned = |epochs = [[Neolithic]], [[Eneolithic]] |cultures = |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 2011-2012 |archaeologists = [[Stanislav Grigoriev]] |condition = |ownership = |management = |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} [[File:Geoglyth2.jpg|thumb|Geoglyph on the slope of the Zyuratkul. Stone structure.]] The '''Russian geoglyph''' refers to a [[geoglyph]] on slopes of the [[Zyuratkul National Park|Zyuratkul Mountains]] in the [[Chelyabinsk]] region in [[Russia]].<ref name="Janus">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/49389775/ns/technology_and_science-science/#.UHqQb1Ea6Xn Janus, Owen., Mysterious elk-shaped structure discovered in Russia Huge geoglyph may predate Peru's famous Nazca Lines by thousands of years, Live Science on NBC News, 2012-10-12.] ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPCNtomB?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/49389775/ns/technology_and_science-science/ |date=October 14, 2012 }})</ref>
==Description and discovery==
The geoglyph depicts accurate contours of an animal similar to an [[elk]] or [[moose]], with four legs, two [[antler]]s and a long [[snout]]. It may also have had a [[tail]], however this has now been obscured. It was first detected in 2011 by [[Alexander Shestakov]] using [[satellite imagery]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2820317/World-s-oldest-geoglyph-CHILDREN-Enormous-moose-symbol-visible-space-built-6-000-years-ago-using-tiny-tools.html |title=World's oldest geoglyph was made by CHILDREN: Enormous moose symbol visible from space was built 6,000 years ago using tiny tools |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |first=Will |last=Stewart |date=4 November 2014}}</ref> He notified researchers who surveyed the outline using a [[paraglider]] and [[seaplane]]. Research has continued into the site under [[Stanislav Grigoriev]] from the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] Institute of History and Archaeology. Grigoriev published an article with [[Nikolai Menshenin]] from the State Centre for Monument Protection about the discovery in the ''[[Antiquity (journal)|Antiquity]]'' journal in spring 2011.<ref>[http://www.antiquity.ac.uk/projgall/grigoriev331/ Grigoriev, Stanislav, A. & Menshenin, Nikolai M., Discovery of a geoglyph on the Zjuratkul Ridge in the southern Urals, Antiquity, Volume 086, Issue 331, March, 2012.] ({{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPT1Os6J?url=http://www.antiquity.ac.uk/projgall/grigoriev331/ |date=October 14, 2012 }})</ref>
==Excavation==
Excavations have unearthed stones laying {{convert|4.5|m|ft}} wide, precisely under the contour at a depth of {{convert|30|cm|in}} to {{convert|40|cm|in}}. The borders consist of large stones with a center filled with smaller ones. Builders of the object cut off a soil layer down to virgin clay and placed stones into this trench.<ref name="Janus"/>
The stones are now covered by a layer of patina with a dark shade. Earlier they were lighter and were perfectly visible from the ridge because the huge size of the drawing. It has a width of {{convert|195|m|ft}}, length of {{convert|218|m|ft}}, and a diagonal of {{convert|275|m|ft}}. Excavations in the summer of 2012 have revealed small walls and remains of what are thought to be passageways on the areas around the [[hoof]] and [[snout]] of the animal. Grigoriev remarked that ''"the hoof is made of small crushed stones and clay. It seems to me there were very low walls and narrow passages among them. The same situation in the area of a muzzle: crushed stones and clay, four small broad walls and three passages."'' The geolyph is thought to have been created by a ''"[[megalith]]ic culture"'' operating in the area during the past and connected with other [[Megaliths in the Urals]] and on Vera Island. In the period of its creation the soil layer was only {{convert|10|cm|in}}, and today it is {{convert|40|cm|in}} to {{convert|50|cm|in}}.<ref name="Janus"/>
==Dating==
Grigoriev has found over forty stone tools resembling [[pickaxe]]s during recent excavations that Grigoriev suggests show a style of [[Lithic reduction]] dating to the [[Neolithic]] or [[Chalcolithic]] periods between 4000 and 2000 BCE. Further accuracy regarding the dating of the geoglyph is hoped to be obtained from an ongoing study using [[pollen core]] analysis.<ref name="Janus"/> This suggested dating would place the construction of the {{convert|900|ft|m}} geoglyph many centuries before that of the [[Nazca lines]] in [[Peru]], the [[Blythe geoglyphs]] in [[California]] and several in [[England]], making it one of the oldest examples of [[land art]] in the world.<ref name="Janus"/><ref>[http://www.skynews.com.au/offbeat/article.aspx?id=805328 Sky News Australia, Russian geoglyph may be older than 500BC, 2012-10-13.] ( {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BP4VUIdj?url=http://www.skynews.com.au/offbeat/article.aspx?id=805328 |date=October 14, 2012 }})</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://wikimapia.org/20477251/Geoglyph-Elk Geoglyph "Elk" on Wikimapia] * [http://www.livescience.com/23884-nazca-lines-russia-geoglyphs.html Image Gallery of the Russian Geoglyph on Live Science]
{{European Standing Stones}}

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2015}} {{Postmodernism}}
'''Russian postmodernism''' refers to the [[culture|cultural]], [[art|artistic]], and [[philosophy|philosophical]] condition in [[Russia]] since the downfall of the [[Soviet Union]] and [[dialectical materialism]]. With respect to statements about post-Soviet philosophy or [[sociology]], the term is primarily used by non-Russians to describe the state of [[economic]] and [[political]] uncertainty they observe since the fall of [[communism]] and the way this uncertainty affects Russian identity. 'Postmodernism' is, however, a term often used by Russian [[literary criticism|critics]] to describe contemporary Russian art and [[Russian literature|literature]].
==Artistic origins== In art, [[postmodernism]] entered the Soviet Union in the 1960s after the end of the [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] move toward liberalization with the advent of the [[Russian Conceptualism|Russian conceptualist]] movement. Beginning as an underground political-artistic move against the use of [[Socialist realism]] as a method of social control and becoming a full-fledged movement with the [[Moscow Conceptualists]], Russian conceptualism used the [[symbol]]ism of Socialist realism against the Soviet government.
==See also== * [[History of the Soviet Union (1953–1964)]] * [[History of the Soviet Union (1964–1982)]] * [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–1991)]] * [[History of post-Soviet Russia]] * [[Viacheslav Kuritsyn]] * [[Mark Lipovetsky]] * [[Modernism]] * [[Postmodernism]] * [[Russian literature]] * [[Socialist realism]] * [[Soviet Nonconformist Art]]
==External links== *[http://www.emory.edu/INTELNET/af.rus.postmodernism.html The Origins and Meaning of Russian Postmodernism], [[Mikhail Epstein]] *[http://www.litencyc.com/php/stopics.php?rec=true&UID=1365 Russian Postmodernism] at [http://www.litencyc.com/ Literary Encyclopedia]
{{russia-stub}}
[[Category:Postmodernism]] [[Category:Postmodern art]]
